en: In spite of her income of eighteen thousand francs from landed property, a very considerable fortune in the provinces, she lived on a footing with families who were less rich.When she went to her country-place at Prebaudet, she drove there in an old wicker carriole, hung on two straps of white leather, drawn by a wheezy mare, and scarcely protected by two leather curtains rusty with age.This carriole, known to all the town, was cared for by Jacquelin as though it were the finest coupe in all Paris.Mademoiselle valued it; she had used it for twelve years,—a fact to which she called attention with the triumphant joy of happy avarice.Most of the inhabitants of the town were grateful to Mademoiselle Cormon for not humiliating them by the luxury she could have displayed; we may even believe that had she imported a caleche from Paris they would have gossiped more about that than about her various matrimonial failures.The most brilliant equipage would, after all, have only taken her, like the old carriole, to Prebaudet.Now the provinces, which look solely to results, care little about the beauty or elegance of the means, provided they are efficient.

zh: 第五章 老姑娘的家庭
en: CHAPTER V AN OLD MAID’S HOUSEHOLD

zh: 要完成对这户人家生活习惯的描写，还必须介绍陪伴在科尔蒙小姐和德斯蓬德神父身边的几位仆人——雅克兰、若赛特和厨娘玛丽埃特，是他们三位一直伺候着这位舅舅和外甥女。
en: To complete the picture of the internal habits and ways of this house, it is necessary to group around Mademoiselle Cormon and the Abbe de Sponde, Jacquelin, Josette, and Mariette, the cook, who employed themselves in providing for the comfort of uncle and niece.

zh: 雅克兰是位四十岁的矮矮胖胖的男子汉，他的皮肤红润，棕色头发，脸像是布列塔尼水手，他已经为这家效劳了二十二年。他负责伺候吃饭，洗刷马匹，管理花园，给神父擦皮鞋，跑腿，砍柴，赶车，到普雷博戴给牲口拉燕麦、麦秆和干草。他晚上留在前厅照看，在那里睡得跟睡鼠一样。他爱上了若赛特，一个三十岁的女人。如果她嫁给他，科尔蒙小姐就会把她辞掉。因此这可怜的一对人把他们的工钱积攒起来，偷偷地相爱，等待并盼望着小姐早日成婚，就像犹太人等待弥赛亚一样。若赛特出生在阿郎松与莫尔塔涅之间的一个地方；她身材矮小而丰满，她的脸看上去像沾了泥的杏子，不过她不缺观察力和精明；据说她控制着她的女主人。若赛特和雅克兰相信会有结果的，他们极力将内心的满足感隐藏起来，正是这满足感让他们这对情人能指望着将来。厨娘玛丽埃特在主人家干活已有十五年了，她会做当地所有时兴的菜肴。
en: Jacquelin, a man of forty, short, fat, ruddy, and brown, with a face like a Breton sailor, had been in the service of the house for twenty-two years.He waited at table, groomed the mare, gardened, blacked the abbe’s boots, went on errands, chopped the wood, drove the carriole, and fetched the oats, straw, and hay from Prebaudet.He sat in the antechamber during the evening, where he slept like a dormouse.He was in love with Josette, a girl of thirty, whom Mademoiselle would have dismissed had she married him.So the poor fond pair laid by their wages, and loved each other silently, waiting, hoping for mademoiselle’s own marriage, as the Jews are waiting for the Messiah.Josette, born between Alencon and Mortagne, was short and plump; her face, which looked like a dirty apricot, was not wanting in sense and character; it was said that she ruled her mistress.Josette and Jacquelin, sure of results, endeavored to hide an inward satisfaction which allows it to be supposed that, as lovers, they had discounted the future.Mariette, the cook, who had been fifteen years in the household, knew how to make all the dishes held in most honor in Alencon.

zh: 也许我们在对这户人家的介绍中，还要算上那匹拉着科尔蒙小姐到普雷博戴田庄上去的又肥又老的诺曼底枣红色马，因为这家的五位成员对这牲口都疼爱至极。这匹马名叫珀涅罗珀，在这家服务了十八年了，并被精心照管着，有人按时给它喂料，雅克兰和家中小姐都希望它能再用个十几年。这匹马是科尔蒙小姐永久的谈资和关心的对象，可怜的她没有孩子来寄托自己的母爱，就把这些感情都转移到这个幸运的牲口上了。
en: Perhaps we ought to count for much the fat old Norman brown-bay mare, which drew Mademoiselle Cormon to her country-seat at Prebaudet; for the five inhabitants of the house bore to this animal a maniacal affection.She was called Penelope, and had served the family for eighteen years; but she was kept so carefully and fed with such regularity that mademoiselle and Jacquelin both hoped to use her for ten years longer.This beast was the subject of perpetual talk and occupation; it seemed as if poor Mademoiselle Cormon, having no children on whom her repressed motherly feelings could expend themselves, had turned those sentiments wholly on this most fortunate animal.

zh: 这四个忠仆——珀涅罗珀的聪明智慧已将自己提升到了另外几位善良仆人的水平，而他们却下降到牲口一般默默无言、唯命是从的状态——每天你来我往，始终坚持分毫不差地干着同样的活。不过，正像他们自己说的那样，他们是先甜后苦。像所有被一个固定的念头折磨的人一样，科尔蒙小姐变得挑剔起来，而且唠唠叨叨。这倒不是因为性格使然，而是因为她想找事情打发时间。因为她没有丈夫和孩子可照顾，便求助于无聊琐事。仅仅是橱柜里一打编号为“Z”的餐巾放在编号为“O”的餐巾前面这样的小事，她都能唠叨上好几个小时。
en: The four faithful servants—for Penelope’s intelligence raised her to the level of the other good servants; while they, on the other hand, had lowered themselves to the mute, submissive regularity of the beast—went and came daily in the same occupations with the infallible accuracy of mechanism.But, as they said in their idiom, they had eaten their white bread first.Mademoiselle Cormon, like all persons nervously agitated by a fixed idea, became hard to please, and nagging, less by nature than from the need of employing her activity.Having no husband or children to occupy her, she fell back on petty details.She talked for hours about mere nothings, on a dozen napkins marked “Z,” placed in the closet before the “O’s.”

zh: “若赛特都在想些什么呀？”她大喊道，“她现在越来越马虎了。”就因一次雅克兰喂珀涅罗珀晚了点，科尔蒙小姐足足连续八天，每天追问珀涅罗珀是不是两点钟给马喂了燕麦。她那狭隘的想象力都耗在小事上了。什么地方鸡毛掸子漏掸了一层灰，玛丽埃特有一片面包没有烤好，若赛特没有及时拉上百叶窗导致太阳光照在家具上会让家具褪色等等，所有这些小事都会引来煞有介事的责备和埋怨，让小姐大发雷霆。“什么都不如从前了，”她会大叫道，“我都不了解自己的仆人了，事实上是我把他们给宠坏了！”有一次若赛特本应给她一本《复活节半月经》，却给她一本《基督徒的一日》。那天晚上，全城的人都听说了这件祸事。科尔蒙小姐不得不离开教堂回家一趟，她匆忙离去时还碰到了许多椅子，让人们认为出了什么大事。于是她得向朋友们一一解释这件事。
en: “What can Josette be thinking of?” she exclaimed.“Josette is beginning to neglect things.”Mademoiselle inquired for eight days running whether Penelope had had her oats at two o’clock, because on one occasion Jacquelin was a trifle late.Her narrow imagination spent itself on trifles.A layer of dust forgotten by the feather-duster, a slice of toast ill-made by Mariette, Josette’s delay in closing the blinds when the sun came round to fade the colors of the furniture,—all these great little things gave rise to serious quarrels in which mademoiselle grew angry.“Everything was changing,” she would cry; “she did not know her own servants; the fact was she spoiled them!”On one occasion Josette gave her the “Journee du Chretien” instead of the “Quinzaine de Paques.”The whole town heard of this disaster the same evening.Mademoiselle had been forced to leave the church and return home; and her sudden departure, upsetting the chairs, made people suppose a catastrophe had happened.She was therefore obliged to explain the facts to her friends.

zh: 她语气温和地说：“若赛特，不要再发生这样的事了。”
en: “Josette,” she said gently, “such a thing must never happen again.”

zh: 科尔蒙小姐没有意识到，她在这些小小的挑剔埋怨中得到了快乐，这就相当于她苦难的发泄口。精神也有自己的需求，就像身体需要做体操一样。若赛特和雅克兰只有忍受她的反复无常的脾气，就像农民要忍受天气的变化一样。这三个善良的仆人会说：“今天天气很好”，或者“下雨了”，而其实并不是在说天气。并且，他们大清早的时候就会互相询问小姐早上起床的时候心情如何，就像农民通过黎明时分的薄雾判断天气一样。
en: Mademoiselle Cormon was, without being aware of it, made happier by such little quarrels, which served as cathartics to relieve her bitterness.The soul has its needs, and, like the body, its gymnastics.These uncertainties of temper were accepted by Josette and Jacquelin as changes in the weather are accepted by husbandmen.Those worthy souls remark, “It is fine to-day,” or “It rains,” without arraigning the heavens.And so when they met in the morning the servants would wonder in what humor mademoiselle would get up, just as a farmer wonders about the mists at dawn.

zh: 最后，科尔蒙小姐自然还是在她的生活琐事中自顾自怜地度过每一天。她和上帝，听她忏悔的神父和每周要洗的衣物，她的蜜饯和教会的布道，还有她要照顾的舅舅，这些已占满了她那不发达的大脑。对她来说，她的生活已被夸大了，在天生便自私自利或因某些事成为自私自利的人眼中，生活的小事都成了大事。她很健康，可如果稍微有点消化不良，她就认为得了大病。她生活在我们祖先严格的医学教条之下，每年吃四剂预防药，药效强得足以让珀涅罗珀丧命了，却让这位小姐更显朝气。如果若赛特在给小姐穿衣的时候，发现小姐光滑如缎的肩膀上生了个小脓包，那将会让他们仔细回想前一周吃的各种食物。直到若赛特提醒她的女主人可能是吃了某一道会让人上火的兔子肉，这才长了那该死的脓包的，这是多大的成功啊！他们会兴高采烈地相互说道：“没错，没错，就是那兔子肉!”
en: Mademoiselle Cormon had ended, as it was natural she should end, in contemplating herself only in the infinite pettinesses of her life.Herself and God, her confessor and the weekly wash, her preserves and the church services, and her uncle to care for, absorbed her feeble intellect.To her the atoms of life were magnified by an optic peculiar to persons who are selfish by nature or self-absorbed by some accident.Her perfect health gave alarming meaning to the least little derangement of her digestive organs.She lived under the iron rod of the medical science of our forefathers, and took yearly four precautionary doses, strong enough to have killed Penelope, though they seemed to rejuvenate her mistress.If Josette, when dressing her, chanced to discover a little pimple on the still satiny shoulders of mademoiselle, it became the subject of endless inquiries as to the various alimentary articles of the preceding week.And what a triumph when Josette reminded her mistress of a certain hare that was rather “high,” and had doubtless raised that accursed pimple!With what joy they said to each other: “No doubt, no doubt, it WAS the hare!”

zh: “玛丽埃特调料放得太重了，”小姐会说，“我总叫她给我和舅舅的菜做得清淡些，可她的记性还不如——”“那只兔子呢。”若赛特接话道。
en: “Mariette over-seasoned it,” said mademoiselle.“I am always telling her to do so lightly for my uncle and for me; but Mariette has no more memory than —”“The hare,” said Josette.

zh: “对，”小姐回答道，“她的记性还不如兔子呢，你说得很对。”
en: “Just so,” replied Mademoiselle; “she has no more memory than a hare,—a very just remark.”

zh: 一年四次，每个季节开始的时候，科尔蒙小姐会去她的普雷博戴田庄住些日子。现在已是五月中旬，正是她每年去看那里的苹果树“下雪”的时候——“下雪”是当地对树下落花这一情形的说法。当地上的落花像是一层白雪时，主人就可以盼着苹果酒大丰产了。科尔蒙小姐测量酒桶容积的时候，也注意到过了一冬后有些地方需要修补。她会命人来整理花园和果园，她餐桌上的食物就是从这里供应的。每个季节要做的事都不同。科尔蒙小姐动身前都会请她的密友们来聚餐告别，虽然三个星期后就又会和他们相见。科尔蒙小姐的出游总能成为阿郎松的重大新闻。她所有的常客，尤其是那些曾错过一次拜访的，都会前来与她告别。她家的沙龙宾客满堂，每个人都祝她一路平安，那感觉就像她要去加尔各答似的。第二天，商人们都会站在店门口看着那辆旧马车经过，并且挨家挨户地反复传递着一些消息：
en: Four times a year, at the beginning of each season, Mademoiselle Cormon went to pass a certain number of days on her estate of Prebaudet.It was now the middle of May, the period at which she wished to see how her apple-trees had “snowed,” a saying of that region which expressed the effect produced beneath the trees by the falling of their blossoms.When the circular deposit of these fallen petals resembled a layer of snow the owner of the trees might hope for an abundant supply of cider.While she thus gauged her vats, Mademoiselle Cormon also attended to the repairs which the winter necessitated; she ordered the digging of her flower-beds and her vegetable garden, from which she supplied her table.Every season had its own business.Mademoiselle always gave a dinner of farewell to her intimate friends the day before her departure, although she was certain to see them again within three weeks.It was always a piece of news which echoed through Alencon when Mademoiselle Cormon departed.All her visitors, especially those who had missed a visit, came to bid her good-bye; the salon was thronged, and every one said farewell as though she were starting for Calcutta.The next day the shopkeepers would stand at their doors to see the old carriole pass, and they seemed to be telling one another some news by repeating from shop to shop:—

zh: “科尔蒙小姐这就去普雷博戴了！”
en: “So Mademoiselle Cormon is going to Prebaudet!”

zh: 有人说：“她的面包有人烤着呢。”
en: Some said: “HER bread is baked.”

zh: “嘿，小伙子，”下一个人答道，“她可是个正派人。如果钱都到她这种人手里，我们这地方就看不见一个乞丐了。”
en: “Hey! my lad,” replied the next man.“She’s a worthy woman; if money always came into such hands we shouldn’t see a beggar in the country.”

zh: 另一个人说：“我说，如果葡萄园开花了，我可一点儿也不奇怪，科尔蒙小姐这不动身去普雷博戴了嘛。不过她怎么不结婚呢？”“我倒是愿意娶她，”一个人开玩笑说，“事实上，这婚事只成了一半，因为我愿意，人家还不愿意呢。算了！那烤炉是为迪布斯基耶先生加热的吧。”
en: Another said: “Dear me, I shouldn’t be surprised if the vineyards were in bloom; here’s Mademoiselle Cormon going to Prebaudet. How happens it she doesn’t marry?” “I’d marry her myself,” said a wag; “in fact, the marriage is half-made, for here’s one consenting party; but the other side won’t. Pooh! the oven is heating for Monsieur du Bousquier.”

zh: “迪布斯基耶先生！哎呀，她已经拒绝他了！”那天晚上所有的聚会场合，大家都庄重地相互转告：“科尔蒙小姐走了。”或者：“你们就让科尔蒙小姐走了。”
en: “Monsieur du Bousquier! Why, she has refused him.”That evening at all the gatherings it was told gravely:—“Mademoiselle Cormon has gone.”Or: —“So you have really let Mademoiselle Cormon go.”

zh: 苏珊选择了一个星期三来公布她的丑闻，恰巧是科尔蒙小姐告别宴会的那天。那天科尔蒙小姐为了要带走衣物的事，把若赛特弄得头昏脑胀。就这样，城里发生了一件事，为这次告别集会增添了极大的趣味。正当科尔蒙小姐考虑要带什么东西出游之时，格朗松太太已经拜访了十几户人家，而精明的瓦卢瓦骑士正在阿尔芒德德埃斯格里尼翁小姐家玩皮克牌，这位小姐是显赫的埃斯格里尼翁老侯爵的妹妹，也是贵族沙龙的王后。任何一个人都会对此感兴趣，想知道引诱少女的家伙那天晚上表情会如何。不过对于骑士和格朗松太太来说，最重要的是知道科尔蒙小姐以她的双重身份——适婚女性和妇女协会主席——怎么来看待这个消息了。至于那无辜的迪布斯基耶，则正在林阴大道上散步呢。他开始怀疑自己被苏珊耍了，这个怀疑证实了他对女人的看法是正确的。
en: The Wednesday chosen by Suzanne to make known her scandal happened to be this farewell Wednesday,—a day on which Mademoiselle Cormon drove Josette distracted on the subject of packing.During the morning, therefore, things had been said and done in the town which lent the utmost interest to this farewell meeting.Madame Granson had gone the round of a dozen houses while the old maid was deliberating on the things she needed for the journey; and the malicious Chevalier de Valois was playing piquet with Mademoiselle Armande, sister of a distinguished old marquis, and the queen of the salon of the aristocrats.If it was not uninteresting to any one to see what figure the seducer would cut that evening, it was all important for the chevalier and Madame Granson to know how Mademoiselle Cormon would take the news in her double capacity of marriageable woman and president of the Maternity Society.As for the innocent du Bousquier, he was taking a walk on the promenade, and beginning to suspect that Suzanne had tricked him; this suspicion confirmed him in his principles as to women.

zh: 在这大宴宾客的日子里，科尔蒙小姐家里三点半就已经摆好了桌子。那个时期，阿郎松的时尚之人都是四点开始用餐。帝国时期，他们还是像往昔一样下午两点半开宴，不过那时候他们还吃夜宵呢！科尔蒙小姐极力品味的快乐之一，就是看到自己穿戴成接待客人的女主人的样子，这时她会有一种无法形容的满足感（这种快乐倒没有什么恶意，虽然是建立在自尊自大的基础上的）。当她如此武装起来了以后，她的内心深处又会涌起一线希望：一个声音告诉她，造物主并没有白白地将她造就得这么丰满，会有一位敢作敢为、有事业心的男人出现。她的愿望像她洗过澡的身体一样变得格外清新，她怀着陶醉狂喜的心情欣赏自己魁梧健壮的身体，并带着这种满足感下楼到客厅、餐厅和小客厅，用她令人敬畏的眼睛审视着。然后，她会怀着富人那种认为自己将来会和现在一样永远应有尽有的天真的满足感，在周围走来走去。看着她的那些固定不变的家具、古董和漆器，她心中暗想，所有这些漂亮的东西都需要有一位男主人。她欣赏了饭厅和椭圆形的大桌子，上面铺着雪白的桌布，距离相等地摆着二十份餐具；她检查了她指定的大批酒瓶以及上面的名酒商标；她仔细检查了写在小纸片上的每一个名字，这是神父用他颤抖的手写成的，也是他在这家中所负责的唯一的事，同时负责对每一位客人坐在什么位置进行郑重其事的讨论。在检查完这一切后，科尔蒙小姐便身着盛装，去见她的舅父。此刻是一天当中最好的时光，她的舅舅正在台地上沿着亮河散步，同时还听着树丛中的鸟儿那无须担心猎人或孩子的袭击而尽情地啼叫。在这等待的时间里，她每次走到神父旁边都会问几个滑稽的问题，以便让这老人和她争论些什么，好让他开心。为了让大家明白这位心灵高尚的老姑娘的性格，我们还要知道这一点：
en: On gala days the table was laid at Mademoiselle Cormon’s about half-past three o’clock.At that period the fashionable people of Alencon dined at four.Under the Empire they still dined as in former times at half-past two; but then they supped!One of the pleasures which Mademoiselle Cormon valued most was (without meaning any malice, although the fact certainly rests on egotism) the unspeakable satisfaction she derived from seeing herself dressed as mistress of the house to receive her guests.When she was thus under arms a ray of hope would glide into the darkness of her heart; a voice told her that nature had not so abundantly provided for her in vain, and that some man, brave and enterprising, would surely present himself.Her desire was refreshed like her person; she contemplated herself in her heavy stuffs with a sort of intoxication, and this satisfaction continued when she descended the stairs to cast her redoubtable eye on the salon, the dinner-table, and the boudoir.She would then walk about with the naive contentment of the rich,—who remember at all moments that they are rich and will never want for anything.She looked at her eternal furniture, her curiosities, her lacquers, and said to herself that all these fine things wanted was a master.After admiring the dining-room, and the oblong dinner-table, on which was spread a snow-white cloth adorned with twenty covers placed at equal distances; after verifying the squadron of bottles she had ordered to be brought up, and which all bore honorable labels; after carefully verifying the names written on little bits of paper in the trembling handwriting of the abbe (the only duty he assumed in the household, and one which gave rise to grave discussions on the place of each guest),—after going through all these preliminary acts mademoiselle went, in her fine clothes, to her uncle, who was accustomed at this, the best hour in the day, to take his walk on the terrace which overlooked the Brillante, where he could listen to the warble of birds which were resting in the coppice, unafraid of either sportsmen or children.At such times of waiting she never joined the Abbe de Sponde without asking him some ridiculous question, in order to draw the old man into a discussion which might serve to amuse him.And her reason was this,—which will serve to complete our picture of this excellent woman’s nature:—

zh: 科尔蒙小姐认为说话是她的一项义务，倒不是说她话多，相反，她的思想很贫乏，她的词汇有限，讲不了几句话。但是她认为她是在完成宗教规定的一项社会义务，因为宗教教导我们要与人为善。这项义务对她来说是很难的事，她甚至专门咨询了她的神师库蒂里耶神父对于这个幼稚而诚实的礼仪问题的意见。尽管忏悔的人老老实实地向神父承认，她需要费尽心思来找话说，这位对宗教信条坚定不移的老神父，还是给她读了《圣弗朗索瓦·德萨勒传》中的一段。这一段讲的是交际场合妇女的义务和虔诚的女基督教徒应该怎样既对自己要求严格，又在家中显得和蔼可亲，而且还要使自己周围的人过得开心。因此，科尔蒙小姐对自己的义务深信不疑，并且愿意无论如何都顺从神师的教导，于是她努力制造愉快的对话。每次她看到对话冷场的时候，这可怜的姑娘穿着她的紧身衣直冒汗，想尽办法说些什么让对话再次热烈起来。往往这种时候，她都会发表一些最愚蠢的言论，比如“除了小鸟外，任何人都不能同时存在于两个地方”之类的话。有一天她成功地用这一句话挑起了关于传教的始祖所说“耶稣无所不在”的争论，不过她一点儿也听不懂。在谈话里的这一类成功让她赢得了“好心的科尔蒙小姐”的雅号。这个称呼从有头脑的人口中说出，意思其实是指她极其无知，甚至有点笨。但是有许多和她一样笨的人只能理解字面上的意思，并且回答道：
en: Mademoiselle Cormon regarded it as one of her duties to talk; not that she was talkative, for she had unfortunately too few ideas, and did not know enough phrases to converse readily.But she believed she was accomplishing one of the social duties enjoined by religion, which orders us to make ourselves agreeable to our neighbor.This obligation cost her so much that she consulted her director, the Abbe Couturier, upon the subject of this honest but puerile civility.In spite of the humble remark of his penitent, confessing the inward labor of her mind in finding anything to say, the old priest, rigid on the point of discipline, read her a passage from Saint-Francois de Sales on the duties of women in society, which dwelt on the decent gayety of pious Christian women, who were bound to reserve their sternness for themselves, and to be amiable and pleasing in their homes, and see that their neighbors enjoyed themselves.Thus, filled with a sense of duty, and wishing, at all costs, to obey her director, who bade her converse with amenity, the poor soul perspired in her corset when the talk around her languished, so much did she suffer from the effort of emitting ideas in order to revive it.Under such circumstances she would put forth the silliest statements, such as: “No one can be in two places at once—unless it is a little bird,” by which she one day roused, and not without success, a discussion on the ubiquity of the apostles, which she was unable to comprehend.Such efforts at conversation won her the appellation of “that good Mademoiselle Cormon,” which, from the lips of the beaux esprits of society, means that she was as ignorant as a carp, and rather a poor fool; but many persons of her own calibre took the remark in its literal sense, and answered:—

zh: “是呀，是呀，科尔蒙小姐人真好！”
en: “Yes; oh yes! Mademoiselle Cormon is an excellent woman.”

zh: 有时，为了履行社会义务，向她的客人表示和蔼可亲，她会提些很荒谬的问题，惹得大家哄堂大笑。例如，她问，政府征了那么长时间的税，钱都派什么用场了；或是，既然《圣经》是摩西写的，为什么没有在耶稣基督的时代印出来。科尔蒙小姐的思想和英国的一位“乡绅”属于同一类。那英国乡绅总是听人在乡村议会上谈论什么后世、后代，于是有一天他站起来发表了一次演讲：“先生们，我在这里听了很多谈论后世、后代的话，我想知道这股力量为英国做了哪些事情？”后来这一演说变得非常有名。在这种场合，英雄般的德瓦卢瓦骑士只要看到了那些聪明人冷酷无情的微笑时，他就会用他全部机智的外交手段来解救这位老小姐。这位喜欢给予女人援助的老绅士，会似是而非地支持科尔蒙小姐的话，借此赋予她的话一些智慧。他通常掩护她撤退得非常好，以至于让人感觉那善良的小姐当时并没有说什么蠢话。有一晚她很郑重其事地承认她看不出阉牛和公牛之间有什么区别。这位可爱的骑士马上回答说，两者只存在羊与羊羔之间的区别，从而止住了大家的哄堂大笑。
en: Sometimes she would put such absurd questions (always for the purpose of fulfilling her duties to society, and making herself agreeable to her guests) that everybody burst out laughing.She asked, for instance, what the government did with the taxes they were always receiving; and why the Bible had not been printed in the days of Jesus Christ, inasmuch as it was written by Moses.Her mental powers were those of the English “country gentleman” who, hearing constant mention of “posterity” in the House of Commons, rose to make the speech that has since become celebrated: “Gentlemen,” he said, “I hear much talk in this place about Posterity. I should be glad to know what that power has ever done for England.”Under these circumstances the heroic Chevalier de Valois would bring to the succor of the old maid all the powers of his clever diplomacy, whenever he saw the pitiless smile of wiser heads.The old gentleman, who loved to assist women, turned Mademoiselle Cormon’s sayings into wit by sustaining them paradoxically, and he often covered the retreat so well that it seemed as if the good woman had said nothing silly.She asserted very seriously one evening that she did not see any difference between an ox and a bull.The dear chevalier instantly arrested the peals of laughter by asserting that there was only the difference between a sheep and a lamb.

zh: 不过德瓦卢瓦骑士算是在为一位不懂感激的女人效劳，因为科尔蒙小姐永远也不明白骑士这些颇有风度的解围。看到谈话又热闹起来了，她还觉得自己并没有那么蠢呢。结果，她自鸣得意，完全失去了自知之明，不再胆怯，并且变得泰然自若，让她的话带有某种庄重严肃的味道，正如英国人庄重严肃地发表爱国的谬论一般——可以说是一种自命不凡的愚蠢。
en: But the Chevalier de Valois served an ungrateful dame, for never did Mademoiselle Cormon comprehend his chivalrous services.Observing that the conversation grew lively, she simply thought that she was not so stupid as she was,—the result being that she settled down into her ignorance with some complacency; she lost her timidity, and acquired a self-possession which gave to her “speeches” something of the solemnity with which the British enunciate their patriotic absurdities,—the self-conceit of stupidity, as it may be called.

zh: 现在她一面迈着威严的步伐走到她的舅舅身边，一面反复思考着向他提个什么问题，好打破他的沉默。舅舅的默默无言总是让她困扰，因为她担心舅舅有些迟钝。
en: As she approached her uncle, on this occasion, with a majestic step, she was ruminating over a question that might draw him from a silence, which always troubled her, for she feared he was dull.

zh: “舅舅，如果说地上一切都是上帝的旨意，那么，任何事物的存在都有其道理了？”她挽住他的胳膊，靠在他身上说（这是她的幻想之一，她心里想道：“如果我有丈夫的话，我就要这样做。”）。
en: “Uncle,” she said, leaning on his arm and clinging to his side (this was one of her fictions; for she said to herself “If I had a husband I should do just so”),—“uncle, if everything here below happens according to the will of God, there must be a reason for everything.”

zh: “那当然。”老神父一本正经地答道。这位好先生很疼爱他的侄女，总是怀着天使般的耐心任凭她打断自己的沉思。
en: “Certainly,” replied the abbe, gravely.The worthy man, who cherished his niece, always allowed her to tear him from his meditations with angelic patience.

zh: “那如果我一直当姑娘，假设是这样的话，也是上帝的旨意吗？”
en: “Then if I remain unmarried,—supposing that I do,—God wills it?”

zh: “是的，我的孩子。”神父说道。
en: “Yes, my child,” replied the abbe.

zh: “然而，如果我选择无论什么也阻挡不了我明天结婚，可以说我的意志可以摧毁上帝的意志吗？”
en: “And yet, as nothing prevents me from marrying to-morrow if I choose, His will can be destroyed by mine?”

zh: “如果我们知道上帝的真正旨意是什么，那有可能是真的。”这位前索邦修道院院长回答道。“要注意，我的女儿，你可是加了一个‘如果’哦。”
en: “That would be true if we knew what was really the will of God,” replied the former prior of the Sorbonne.“Observe, my daughter, that you put in an IF.”

zh: 这可怜的姑娘本来指望用这么一个强有力的论据将他舅舅引入婚姻的讨论中，结果听到这样的回答，她目瞪口呆了。不过，头脑迟钝的人总会按着孩子的可怕逻辑思考，从回答再转到问题，这样的逻辑总是让人为难。
en: The poor woman, who expected to draw her uncle into a matrimonial discussion by an argument ad omnipotentem, was stupefied; but persons of obtuse mind have the terrible logic of children, which consists in turning from answer to question,—a logic that is frequently embarrassing.

zh: “可是，舅舅，上帝创造了女人并不是要让他们一直当姑娘的；不然的话他们应该都一直不结婚，或者他们全都应该结婚。要是分配的角色不同，那就太不公平了。”“女儿呀，”善良的神父说道，“教会规定独身是接近上帝的最好方式，你这是在责怪教会了啊。”
en: “But, uncle, God did not make women intending them not to marry; otherwise they ought all to stay unmarried; if not, they ought all to marry. There’s great injustice in the distribution of parts.”“Daughter,” said the worthy abbe, “you are blaming the Church, which declares celibacy to be the better way to God.”

zh: “但如果教会是对的，并且世上所有的人都是忠诚的天主教徒，那人类不是要绝种了吗，舅舅？”
en: “But if the Church is right, and all the world were good Catholics, wouldn’t the human race come to an end, uncle?”

zh: “你想得太多了，罗丝，你想这么多是不会开心的。”
en: “You have too much mind, Rose; you don’t need so much to be happy.”

zh: 这样的话让这可怜的姑娘嘴角泛起满意的微笑，这说明她开始对自己形成的良好看法是对的。这个世界、我们的朋友和我们的敌人就是这样成为我们缺点的帮凶的！
en: That remark brought a smile of satisfaction to the lips of the poor woman, and confirmed her in the good opinion she was beginning to acquire about herself.That is how the world, our friends, and our enemies are the accomplices of our defects!

zh: 这时，客人陆续来到，他们的谈话因此打住了。在这样的大宴宾客的日子里，家中的仆人与应邀的客人之间也会相互问候。玛丽埃特见到法院院长走过厨房，于是说道：
en: At this moment the conversation was interrupted by the successive arrival of the guests.On these ceremonial days, friendly familiarities were exchanged between the servants of the house and the company.Mariette remarked to the chief-justice as he passed the kitchen:—

zh: “哦，迪龙瑟雷先生，我特意为您准备了干酪丝烤菜花。我家小姐知道您特爱吃这道菜，并且对我说‘玛丽埃特，千万别忘了今天迪龙瑟雷先生会来。’”
en: “Ah, Monsieur du Ronceret, I’ve cooked the cauliflowers au gratin expressly for you, for mademoiselle knows how you like them; and she said to me: ‘Now don’t forget, Mariette, for Monsieur du Ronceret is coming.’”

zh: “科尔蒙小姐真是太好了！”当地的法官放声说道，“玛丽埃特，你是把菜花浸在卤汁里而不是高汤里吧？这样味道会更浓。”法院院长才不愿走进玛丽埃特主持的议事室呢，他只是以美食家的眼光看了看，提供一点往日烹饪专家的意见而已。
en: “That good Mademoiselle Cormon!” ejaculated the chief legal authority of the town.“Mariette, did you steep them in gravy instead of soup-stock? it is much richer.”The chief-justice was not above entering the chamber of council where Mariette held court; he cast the eye of a gastronome around it, and offered the advice of a past master in cookery.

zh: “您好，太太，”若赛特对一直讨好小姐的格朗松太太说道，“我家小姐可想您啦，晚餐给您准备了一条鱼呢。”
en: “Good-day, madame,” said Josette to Madame Granson, who courted the maid.“Mademoiselle has thought of you, and there’s fish for dinner.”

zh: 至于德瓦卢瓦骑士，他则用大老爷的那种故意表示和蔼可亲的轻松语气对玛丽埃特说道：
en: As for the Chevalier de Valois, he remarked to Mariette, in the easy tone of a great seigneur who condescends to be familiar:—

zh: “哎呀，亲爱的手艺高明的厨师，我真应该奖励你我这十字勋章！晚上有为我准备什么精致好菜吗？”
en: “Well, my dear cordon-bleu, to whom I should give the cross of the Legion of honor, is there some little dainty for which I had better reserve myself?”

zh: “有的，有的，德瓦卢瓦先生！有一只从普雷博戴送来的兔子，足有十四磅重呢！”
en: “Yes, yes, Monsieur de Valois,—a hare sent from Prebaudet; weighs fourteen pounds.”

zh: 迪布斯基耶是不在邀请之列的。科尔蒙小姐一直坚持着我们都已知道的择偶原则，她总是以很怠慢的态度对待那位五十多岁的追求者。不过在内心，她对他总有一种难以解释的情感。她已经拒绝了他的求婚，可有时她又感到后悔，并且她有一种预感，觉得最后还是会嫁给他，因此她又感到害怕，以至于她不敢去想这桩婚事。这些想法让她对迪布斯基耶难以忘怀。虽然她没有意识到，但其实她深受这个赫尔克里斯式体型的共和党人的影响。虽然格朗松太太和德瓦卢瓦骑士不能理解科尔蒙小姐的自相矛盾，但是他们都见过小姐对迪布斯基耶天真地暗送秋波。其中的意思很明显，所以这两人都下决心要设法毁灭那已被拒绝的商人的希望——虽然他已遭拒绝，但很明显他还是不死心。
en: Du Bousquier was not invited.Mademoiselle Cormon, faithful to the system which we know of, treated that fifty-year-old suitor extremely ill, although she felt inexplicable sentiments towards him in the depths of her heart.She had refused him; yet at times she repented; and a presentiment that she should yet marry him, together with a terror at the idea which prevented her from wishing for the marriage, assailed her.Her mind, stimulated by these feelings, was much occupied by du Bousquier.Without being aware of it, she was influenced by the herculean form of the republican.Madame Granson and the Chevalier de Valois, although they could not explain to themselves Mademoiselle Cormon’s inconsistencies, had detected her naive glances in that direction, the meaning of which seemed clear enough to make them both resolve to ruin the hopes of the already rejected purveyor,—hopes which it was evident he still indulged.

zh: 有两位客人迟到了，但是一说出他们的职务，人们就会原谅因为他们而没有按时开席了。一位是抵押物品保管人迪库德赖先生，另一位是德埃斯格里尼翁府上的前总管、高等贵族公证人舒瓦内尔先生。舒瓦内尔先生德高望重，高等贵族都是恭恭敬敬地接待他，他本人也是非常富有。当雅克兰见到这两位姗姗来迟的客人径直走向客厅时，对他们说道：
en: Two guests, whose functions excused them, kept the dinner waiting.One was Monsieur du Coudrai, the recorder of mortgages; the other Monsieur Choisnel, former bailiff to the house of Esgrignon, and now the notary of the upper aristocracy, by whom he was received with a distinction due to his virtues; he was also a man of considerable wealth.When the two belated guests arrived, Jacquelin said to them as he saw them about to enter the salon:—

zh: “大家都在花园里呢。”
en: “THEY are all in the garden.”

zh: 这位抵押物品保管人是城里最没有缺点的人了，唯一的缺点就是为了钱财而娶了一个脾气特别大的老女人，加上他专爱说俏皮话，并且每次自己都是第一个笑出声的。毫无疑问大家的肚子都已经等得不耐烦了，一见到他来，人群中立即出现一阵轻轻的喧哗，迟到的人总是要受到这样的欢迎的。客人们在等待正式宣布开席的时候，都在亮河的台地上散步。他们一边看着水中镶嵌的水草，一边细细观赏着河流对岸成排的房屋。那里有着古老的木头长廊，窗台塌陷的窗户，晾衣服的小花园，细木工的作坊等等。总之，这些细致小景，加上倾斜的垂柳、朵朵鲜花、蔷薇丛，更加增添了一种意境之美，非常值得风景画家来这里作画。
en: No doubt the assembled stomachs were impatient; for on the appearance of the register of mortgages—who had no defect except that of having married for her money an intolerable old woman, and of perpetrating endless puns, at which he was the first to laugh—the gentle murmur by which such late-comers are welcomed arose.While awaiting the official announcement of dinner, the company were sauntering on the terrace above the river, and gazing at the water-plants, the mosaic of the currents, and the various pretty details of the houses clustering across the river, their old wooden galleries, their mouldering window-frames, their little gardens where clothes were drying, the cabinet-maker’s shop,—in short, the many details of a small community to which the vicinity of a river, a weeping willow, flowers, rose-bushes, added a certain grace, making the scene quite worthy of a landscape painter.

zh: 骑士观察着所有人的表情，因为他知道他放出的火已经成功地蔓延到了当地的显赫人家中。但目前还没有人公开地谈论这件关于苏珊和迪布斯基耶的大新闻。外省人非常了解如何一点一点传开闲言闲语的艺术，现在还不是谈论这件奇闻的时候，得等到每一个人都想好了该如何评论之后才行。所以现在大家都只是在悄声细语地议论着：
en: The chevalier studied all faces, for he knew that his firebrand had been very successfully introduced into the chief houses of the place.But no one as yet referred openly to the great news of Suzanne and du Bousquier.Provincials possess in the highest degree the art of distilling gossip; the right moment for openly discussing this strange affair had not arrived; it was first necessary that all present should put themselves on record.So the whispers went round from ear to ear:—

zh: “你听说了吗？”
en: “You have heard?”

zh: “听说了。”
en: “Yes.”

zh: “是指迪布斯基耶吗？”
en: “Du Bousquier?”

zh: “还有那个漂亮的苏珊。”
en: “And that handsome Suzanne.”

zh: “科尔蒙小姐知道这件事吗？”
en: “Does Mademoiselle Cormon know of it?”

zh: “不知道。”
en: “No.”

zh: “啊，是吧！”
en: “Ha!”

zh: 这是传播丑闻的钢琴曲，一旦撤走第一道正菜后，这渐强的高潮部分就要爆发出来。突然，德瓦卢瓦骑士注意到了格朗松太太，她今天戴着她的绿色的帽子，插了一束报春花，并且满面红光。难道只是这场“音乐会”开始的喜悦让她如此开心？尽管这样的消息对于生活如此单调的人来说，相当于一个要开发的金矿，但是善于观察和多疑的骑士似乎发现了这个老太婆更深一层的感情，那就是要赢得自身利益的喜悦。他立刻转头去研究阿塔纳斯，发现他正处于那种深度沉思的沉默中。不一会儿，那年轻人看了一眼科尔蒙小姐，骑士立刻了解了一切。这闪电的一瞬间让他弄明白了过去发生的种种。
en: This was the PIANO of the scandal; the RINFORZANDO would break forth as soon as the first course had been removed.Suddenly Monsieur de Valois’s eyes lighted on Madame Granson, arrayed in her green hat with bunches of auriculas, and beaming with evident joy.Was it merely the joy of opening the concert?Though such a piece of news was like a gold mine to work in the monotonous lives of these personages, the observant and distrustful chevalier thought he recognized in the worthy woman a far more extended sentiment; namely, the joy caused by the triumph of self-interest.Instantly he turned to examine Athanase, and detected him in the significant silence of deep meditation.Presently, a look cast by the young man on Mademoiselle Cormon carried to the soul of the chevalier a sudden gleam.That momentary flash of lightning enabled him to read the past.

zh: “啊,该死的！”他心中暗想，“我岂不是要被将军了！”
en: “Ha! the devil!” he said to himself; “what a checkmate I’m exposed to!”

zh: 德瓦卢瓦现在走到科尔蒙小姐跟前，让她搀着他的手臂走进饭厅。这老姑娘对骑士非常尊敬。他的姓氏和在贵族中所占的威望，让他成为她的沙龙中最耀眼的装饰品。科尔蒙小姐在过去的十二年间一直都向往着能成为德瓦卢瓦夫人。这个姓氏就像一个树干，在她的头脑里发散出关于自己要嫁的人的地位、高尚的品德以及种种外部优点。虽然骑士是她的心、她的思想、她的雄心所选中的人，但是这个头发梳得光溜溜的老朽总是看上去像圣约翰，让她有些担忧。她认为他是一位绅士没错，但是她没法把他看成丈夫。骑士总是表现出对婚姻无所谓的态度，特别是他居住在女工充斥的房屋里还能保有高尚的品德，这两点都严重影响了科尔蒙小姐对他的看法，与骑士的预期相悖。这位对自己的养老金问题把握得很准的先生，在这件事上可是失算了。科尔蒙小姐没有意识到自己对骑士先生的想法，但是可以用这句话来解释她是怎么看待这位中规中矩的先生的：
en: Monsieur de Valois now approached Mademoiselle Cormon, and offered his arm.The old maid’s feeling to the chevalier was that of respectful consideration; and certainly his name, together with the position he occupied among the aristocratic constellations of the department made him the most brilliant ornament of her salon.In her inmost mind Mademoiselle Cormon had wished for the last dozen years to become Madame de Valois.That name was like the branch of a tree, to which the ideas which SWARMED in her mind about rank, nobility, and the external qualities of a husband had fastened.But, though the Chevalier de Valois was the man chosen by her heart, and mind, and ambition, that elderly ruin, combed and curled like a little Saint-John in a procession, alarmed Mademoiselle Cormon.She saw the gentleman in him, but she could not see a husband.The indifference which the chevalier affected as to marriage, above all, the apparent purity of his morals in a house which abounded in grisettes, did singular harm in her mind to Monsieur de Valois against his expectations.The worthy man, who showed such judgment in the matter of his annuity, was at fault here.Without being herself aware of it, the thoughts of Mademoiselle Cormon on the too virtuous chevalier might be translated thus:—

zh: “他要是能稍微放荡点就好了，真可惜！”
en: “What a pity that he isn’t a trifle dissipated!”

zh: 研究人类心理的人发现，虔诚的女教徒偏爱流氓之类的人；有人觉得很难理解，认为这是有悖基督教道德的。首先，要像木炭一样将恶习的浊水净化，对于一个品行端庄的妇女，你还能赋予她什么更圣洁的使命呢？一些擅于观察的人难道没有发现，这些高尚的女性所遵循的原则要求她们永远不能违背夫妻之间的忠诚，她们自然会向往一个实践经验比自己丰富的丈夫啊？这些社会的坏人往往是爱情方面的伟人。因此，可怜的老姑娘看见自己所选的花瓶碎成两半，悲叹不已。只有上帝才能将骑士和迪布斯基耶合二为一。
en: Observers of the human heart have remarked the leaning of pious women toward scamps; some have expressed surprise at this taste, considering it opposed to Christian virtue.But, in the first place, what nobler destiny can you offer to a virtuous woman than to purify, like charcoal, the muddy waters of vice?How is it some observers fail to see that these noble creatures, obliged by the sternness of their own principles never to infringe on conjugal fidelity, must naturally desire a husband of wider practical experience than their own?The scamps of social life are great men in love.Thus the poor woman groaned in spirit at finding her chosen vessel parted into two pieces.God alone could solder together a Chevalier de Valois and a du Bousquier.

zh: 要让诸位了解骑士和科尔蒙小姐将要交谈的话的重要意义，还必须交代两件激动了全城人心的事。人们对这两件事意见分歧很大，而迪布斯基耶也神秘地卷入了这些事。
en: In order to explain the importance of the few words which the chevalier and Mademoiselle Cormon are about to say to each other, it is necessary to reveal two serious matters which agitated the town, and about which opinions were divided; besides, du Bousquier was mysteriously connected with them.

zh: 一件是关于阿郎松的神父，他从前宣誓遵守《神父的公民组织法》，现在正通过大做好事来转变天主教徒对他的反感情绪。他是一个小小的谢弗吕，曾受到众人高度的尊敬，以至于他去世时，全城的人都为他哀悼。科尔蒙小姐和德斯蓬德神父属于极度正统的贵族小教会，它与罗马教堂的关系正如极端保王党忠心于路易十八一样。而且，神父尤其拒绝承认向宪法妥协的教会。这个神父已经得到阿郎松贵族教区圣莱奥纳尔教堂主持教师的好感，而科尔蒙家中却从未邀请过他。迪布斯基耶这个表面上支持保王党的人，实际上是个疯狂的自由党，他知道各反对派的依靠力量就是那些对现实不满的人（他们是最不受反对的），于是，他把这些对中产阶级有好感的人集中在这个神父周围。第一件事就是这样的，而第二件事是：
en: One concerns the rector of Alencon, who had formerly taken the constitutional oath, and who was now conquering the repugnance of the Catholics by a display of the highest virtues.He was Cheverus on a small scale, and became in time so fully appreciated that when he died the whole town mourned him.Mademoiselle Cormon and the Abbe de Sponde belonged to that “little Church,” sublime in its orthodoxy, which was to the court of Rome what the Ultras were to be to Louis XVIII. The abbe, more especially, refused to recognize a Church which had compromised with the constitutionals.The rector was therefore not received in the Cormon household, whose sympathies were all given to the curate of Saint-Leonard, the aristocratic parish of Alencon.Du Bousquier, that fanatic liberal now concealed under the skin of a royalist, knowing how necessary rallying points are to all discontents (which are really at the bottom of all oppositions), had drawn the sympathies of the middle classes around the rector.So much for the first case; the second was this:—

zh: 在迪布斯基耶的暗中鼓动下，阿郎松的人想要建一座剧院。支持迪布斯基耶的那些人并不了解他们的“穆罕默德”，但他们都认为要积极地支持这个计划。阿塔纳斯就是最狂热的戏院建造拥护者之一；最近，他在市长办公室里辩护，说年轻人都积极支持此事。
en: Under the secret inspiration of du Bousquier the idea of building a theatre had dawned on Alencon.The henchmen of the purveyor did not know their Mohammed; and they thought they were ardent in carrying out their own conception.Athanase Granson was one of the warmest partisans for the theatre; and of late he had urged at the mayor’s office a cause which all the other young clerks had eagerly adopted.

zh: 这时，骑士正让老姑娘搀着自己的胳膊散步。老姑娘接受了这番好意，同时投以欣喜的目光以表谢意，而骑士借机用眼神指了指阿塔纳斯。
en: The chevalier, as we have said, offered his arm to the old maid for a turn on the terrace.She accepted it, not without thanking him by a happy look for this attention, to which the chevalier replied by motioning toward Athanase with a meaning eye.

zh: “小姐，”他开口说道，“您对于社会体统如此重视，而且您与那位年轻人有着某种亲戚关系——”
en: “Mademoiselle,” he began, “you have so much sense and judgment in social proprieties, and also, you are connected with that young man by certain ties—”

zh: “只是远亲而已。”她打断他道。
en: “Distant ones,” she said, interrupting him.

zh: 骑士接着说：“您难道不应该利用您对他母亲和他本人的影响来阻止他误入歧途吗？你知道的，他不是很虔诚地信教，并且他还支持那位神父。这还不算什么，更严重的是，他现在会不会一头栽进反对派，而丝毫不了解这对他的前途会有多大的影响呢？他正在积极地谋划修建剧院。在这件事上，他是上了那个伪共和党人迪布斯基耶的当了——”
en: “Ought you not,” he continued, “to use the influence you have over his mother and over himself by saving him from perdition?He is not very religious, as you know; indeed he approves of the rector; but that is not all; there is something far more serious; isn’t he throwing himself headlong into an opposition without considering what influence his present conduct may exert upon his future?He is working for the construction of a theatre.In this affair he is simply the dupe of that disguised republican du Bousquier—”

zh: “天哪, 德瓦卢瓦先生，”她答道，“他母亲总是跟我说他很有头脑，可是他连两个词都说不出来，他在我面前总是沉默得像根柱子——”
en: “Good gracious! Monsieur de Valois,” she replied; “his mother is always telling me he has so much mind, and yet he can’t say two words; he stands planted before me as mum as a post—”

zh: “他根本什么都不想！” 抵押品总管高声喊道，“我无意听到了你说的话。向德瓦卢瓦先生致意了。”他补上一句，同时夸张地一鞠躬。
en: “Which doesn’t think at all!” cried the recorder of mortgages.“I caught your words on the fly.I present my compliments to Monsieur de Valois,” he added, bowing to that gentleman with much emphasis.

zh: 骑士拘谨地还了对方一个礼，然后带着科尔蒙小姐走向更远的几盆花，以向打断他们谈话的人表明他不希望被别人窃听。
en: The chevalier returned the salutation stiffly, and drew Mademoiselle Cormon toward some flower-pots at a little distance, in order to show the interrupter that he did not choose to be spied upon.

zh: 他压低声音在科尔蒙小姐的耳旁说道，“那些在帝国时期的垃圾学院里培养出来的年轻人能有什么思想呢？只有高尚的情操和高雅的习俗才能产生伟大的思想和真爱。谁看一眼都能知道那可怜的小伙子会成为一个傻瓜，也许就这么悲惨地死去。看他是多么苍白和憔悴啊！”
en: “How is it possible,” he continued, lowering his voice, and leaning towards Mademoiselle Cormon’s ear, “that a young man brought up in those detestable lyceums should have ideas?Only sound morals and noble habits will ever produce great ideas and a true love.It is easy to see by a mere look at him that the poor lad is likely to be imbecile, and come, perhaps, to some sad end.See how pale and haggard he is!”

zh: “他妈妈认为他工作太辛苦了，”老姑娘天真地答道，“他经常熬夜，干什么来着？哦，看书和写字！不知道是什么活非得让个年轻人在晚上写字？”
en: “His mother declares he works too hard,” replied the old maid, innocently.“He sits up late, and for what? reading books and writing!What business ought to require a young man to write at night?”

zh: “这会让他精疲力尽的。”骑士接着说道，极力将老姑娘的思想引到他的用意上来，让她对这位年轻的爱慕者产生厌恶感。“这些帝国学院培养的学生的道德品行真是糟糕。”
en: “It exhausts him,” replied the chevalier, trying to bring the old maid’s thoughts back to the ground where he hoped to inspire her with horror for her youthful lover.“The morals of those Imperial lyceums are really shocking.”

zh: “哦，是呀！”天真的小姐说道，“他们那时还让学生们顶着鼓游行呢。他们的老师都是没有宗教信仰的。并且还让那些可怜的孩子穿上制服，弄得像军队一样。不知道他们是怎么想的！”
en: “Oh, yes!” said the ingenuous creature.“They march the pupils about with drums at their head.The masters have no more religion than pagans.And they put the poor lads in uniform, as if they were troops.What ideas!”

zh: “看看培养出什么样的人了吧！”骑士意指阿塔纳斯，接着说道，“在我那个时代，年轻人可不会不好意思去看一位漂亮小姐的。而至于他，他每次看见你的时候都垂下眼皮。这个年轻人真让我担忧，因为我是真的很关心他。告诉他不要像现在这样为剧院的事忙乎了，不要和波拿巴分子搅和在一起阴谋策划。当所有这些年轻人不再这么暴动般要求修建剧院的时候——我是根据宪章的同义词说暴动的——政府自然就会建造剧院了。另外，告诉他母亲，要严加管教他。”
en: “And behold the product!” said the chevalier, motioning to Athanase.“In my day, young men were not so shy of looking at a pretty woman.As for him, he drops his eyes whenever he sees you.That young man frightens me because I am really interested in him.Tell him not to intrigue with the Bonapartists, as he is now doing about that theatre.When all these petty folks cease to ask for it insurrectionally,—which to my mind is the synonym of constitutionally,—the government will build it.Besides which, tell his mother to keep an eye on him.”

zh: “哦，我肯定他母亲会阻止他去见这些拿半薪的、可疑之人的。我会和他妈妈说的，”科尔蒙小姐说道，“要不他可能会丢了市长办公室的工作，那他们俩该靠什么过活呀？这真让我害怕。”
en: “Oh, I’m sure she will prevent him from seeing those half-pay, questionable people.I’ll talk to her,” said Mademoiselle Cormon, “for he might lose his place in the mayor’s office; and then what would he and his mother have to live on?It makes me shudder.”

zh: 正像德塔莱朗先生谈起自己的妻子时那样，骑士看着科尔蒙小姐也如是暗想道：
en: As Monsieur de Talleyrand said of his wife, so the chevalier said to himself, looking at Mademoiselle Cormon:—

zh: “再也找不到这么蠢的女人了!
en: “Find me another as stupid!

zh: 上帝呀! 没有智的德难道不是坏事吗？但是对于我这个年纪的人来说，她是多么可爱的妻子呀！她这么有原则！又是这么无知！”大家要知道他是一边取鼻烟，一边对着戈里扎公主暗自念叨着这段独白的。
en: Good powers! isn’t virtue which drives out intellect vice?But what an adorable wife for a man of my age!What principles! what ignorance!”Remember that this monologue, addressed to the Princess Goritza, was mentally uttered while he took a pinch of snuff.

zh: 格朗松太太已经猜到了骑士是在谈阿塔纳斯。科尔蒙小姐正摆出尊严十足的姿态向那位年轻人走去，格朗松太太急于想知道谈话的结果，于是便跟了上去。而这时雅克兰来宣布晚餐已准备好了。老姑娘用眼神召唤骑士过去。对女性极为殷勤的抵押品总保管，从骑士刚才的举止中看出了外省贵族与资产阶级之间的隔阂。看到科尔蒙小姐召唤的眼神，他设法抢在老骑士的前面。他靠近科尔蒙小姐，迅速地向她挽起手臂递过去，科尔蒙小姐只好接过来。于是骑士计上心来，快步向格朗松太太走去。
en: Madame Granson had divined that the chevalier was talking about Athanase.Eager to know the result of the conversation, she followed Mademoiselle Cormon, who was now approaching the young man with much dignity.But at this moment Jacquelin appeared to announce that mademoiselle was served.The old maid gave a glance of appeal to the chevalier; but the gallant recorder of mortgages, who was beginning to see in the manners of that gentleman the barrier which the provincial nobles were setting up about this time between themselves and the bourgeoisie, made the most of his chance to cut out Monsieur de Valois.He was close to Mademoiselle Cormon, and promptly offered his arm, which she found herself compelled to accept.The chevalier then darted, out of policy, upon Madame Granson.

zh: “亲爱的太太，”他对她说道，故意走在所有宾客后面，“科尔蒙小姐对您亲爱的儿子十分关切，但是我恐怕由于他自己的过错，这种关切会消散。他不信宗教又是自由党；而且为了剧院的事，他频繁与波拿巴分子来往；他支持那位拥护《教士的公民组织法》的神父。这种种行为都会让他丢掉市长办公室的职位。你知道政府现在是怎么样精心除掉这些异类派的。如果您那亲爱的阿塔纳斯一旦被辞退，他还能找到什么工作？我奉劝他可千万不要让政府对他有不好的看法呀。”
en: “Mademoiselle Cormon, my dear lady,” he said to her, walking slowly after all the other guests, “feels the liveliest interest in your dear Athanase; but I fear it will vanish through his own fault.He is irreligious and liberal; he is agitating this matter of the theatre; he frequents the Bonapartists; he takes the side of that rector.Such conduct may make him lose his place in the mayor’s office.You know with what care the government is beginning to weed out such opinions.If your dear Athanase loses his place, where can he find other employment?I advise him not to get himself in bad odor with the administration.”

zh: “骑士先生，”这位可怜的被吓坏了的母亲说道，“我真不知道该怎么感谢您！您说得对，我儿子被一帮坏人利用了，我得去开导他。”
en: “Monsieur le Chevalier,” said the poor frightened mother, “how grateful I am to you!You are right: my son is the tool of a bad set of people; I shall enlighten him.”

zh: 骑士早就看透了阿塔纳斯的本性，从他身上看出了那种共和主义信念的不驯因素。像他这样的年轻人，是愿意为了“自由”二字而牺牲一切的。“自由”这个词，定义不明确，也很少人理解，但是对于受命运鄙视的人来说，它就是反抗的旗帜；对于他们，反抗就是复仇。阿塔纳斯应该会坚持他的信仰，因为他的观点是与他艺术家的痛苦编织在一起的，也是与他对社会状况的辛酸观察交织在一起的。他不明白，三十六岁是一个人开始对人事、社会关系以及利益关系有所判断的人世阶段，他需要修正他原有的准备为之牺牲一切的观点，因为每一个真正才智过人的人都会做这样的改变。如果他仍然忠于阿郎松的左派，那他就等于自讨科尔蒙小姐的厌恶。骑士对于这一点的确看得很准。
en: The chevalier had long since fathomed the nature of Athanase, and recognized in it that unyielding element of republican convictions to which in his youth a young man is willing to sacrifice everything, carried away by the word “liberty,” so ill-defined and so little understood, but which to persons disdained by fate is a banner of revolt; and to such, revolt is vengeance.Athanase would certainly persist in that faith, for his opinions were woven in with his artistic sorrows, with his bitter contemplation of the social state.He was ignorant of the fact that at thirty-six years of age,—the period of life when a man has judged men and social interests and relations,—the opinions for which he was ready to sacrifice his future would be modified in him, as they are in all men of real superiority.To remain faithful to the Left side of Alencon was to gain the aversion of Mademoiselle Cormon.There, indeed, the chevalier saw true.

zh: 因此这个表面看似平静的社会，其实和任何外交圈一样动荡不安；在外交圈内，计谋、能力、激情围绕着一个王国最重要的问题。现在桌上已经摆好了第一道菜，客人们纷纷就座。在这里他们都是按照外省的吃饭方式，不会因为胃口大开而不好意思。在巴黎则不然，就连动嘴咀嚼似乎都受到禁止奢侈的法律限制，这些法律要求推翻解剖学的规律。在巴黎，人们都是用牙尖吃饭，并且要掩饰好胃口。而在外省，一切都很自然，可能也有点太过于集中在“吃”之上了，而这也是上帝规定万物得以生存的普遍而伟大的方式。
en: Thus we see that this society, so peaceful in appearance, was internally as agitated as any diplomatic circle, where craft, ability, and passions group themselves around the grave questions of an empire.The guests were now seated at the table laden with the first course, which they ate as provincials eat, without shame at possessing a good appetite, and not as in Paris, where it seems as if jaws gnashed under sumptuary laws, which made it their business to contradict the laws of anatomy.In Paris people eat with their teeth, and trifle with their pleasure; in the provinces things are done naturally, and interest is perhaps rather too much concentrated on the grand and universal means of existence to which God has condemned his creatures.

zh: 第一道菜快要吃完的时候，科尔蒙小姐说出了她最精彩的“演讲”，以至于之后人们谈论了足足两年，在阿郎松小资产阶级聚会上，只要提到她的婚姻，大家就会说起这件事。
en: It was at the end of the first course that Mademoiselle Cormon made the most celebrated of her “speeches”; it was talked about for fully two years, and is still told at the gatherings of the lesser bourgeoisie whenever the topic of her marriage comes up.

zh: 等上倒数第二道主菜的时候，谈话内容自然而然地又提到剧院的事和那位宣誓拥护《教士的公民组织法》的神父。在一八一六年保王主义处于首次狂热时，人们后来称之为当地的“耶稣会会士”的那些人，都想将弗朗索瓦神父逐出他的教区。德瓦卢瓦骑士怀疑迪布斯基耶给这个神父撑腰，并且怀疑他是剧院事件的幕后策划者。其实，精明的骑士凭着他惯有的精明，就算背着迪布斯基耶，也能给他加上很多罪名，而迪布斯基耶是个没有律师为之辩护的被告。阿塔纳斯是唯一比较直爽能够支持迪布斯基耶的人，但在阿郎松有权有势的人物面前，他又没有勇气发表意见，虽然他内心认为他们很愚蠢。现在只有外省的年轻人还对上了年纪的人保持谦恭的态度，既不敢指责他们，也不敢和他们唱反调。在享用味道极其鲜美的流着油的橄榄鸭时，大家都顾不上谈话了。虽然科尔蒙小姐也赶紧尝上几口鸭子，但是她还是想先替迪布斯基耶说些好话，因为大家都把他说成专门煽动阴谋诡计的恶人，说他什么坏事都做得出来。
en: The conversation, becoming lively as the penultimate entree was reached, had turned naturally on the affair of the theatre and the constitutionally sworn rector.In the first fervor of royalty, during the year 1816, those who later were called Jesuits were all for the expulsion of the Abbe Francois from his parish.Du Bousquier, suspected by Monsieur de Valois of sustaining the priest and being at the bottom of the theatre intrigues, and on whose back the adroit chevalier would in any case have put those sins with his customary cleverness, was in the dock with no lawyer to defend him.Athanase, the only guest loyal enough to stand by du Bousquier, had not the nerve to emit his ideas in the presence of those potentates of Alencon, whom in his heart he thought stupid.None but provincial youths now retain a respectful demeanor before men of a certain age, and dare neither to censure nor contradict them.The talk, diminished under the effect of certain delicious ducks dressed with olives, was falling flat.Mademoiselle Cormon, feeling the necessity of maintaining it against her own ducks, attempted to defend du Bousquier, who was being represented as a pernicious fomenter of intrigues, capable of any trickery.

zh: 她说道：“至于我，我倒认为迪布斯基耶先生只不过是搞些小孩子的名堂罢了。”
en: “As for me,” she said, “I thought that Monsieur du Bousquier cared chiefly for childish things.”

zh: 在当时的气氛中，这句话产生了极大的效果。科尔蒙小姐获得了辉煌的胜利，她让戈里扎公主掉了下来，鼻子撞到了桌子上。骑士怎么也料不到他的杜尔西内亚冒出来这么一句机智的话，他惊呆了，竟然一下子想不出赞扬的语句；他无声地鼓起掌来，就像人们在看歌剧时鼓掌那样，用他的手指尖做出鼓掌的样子。
en: Under existing circumstances the remark had enormous success.Mademoiselle Cormon obtained a great triumph; she brought the nose of the Princess Goritza flat on the table.The chevalier, who little expected such an apt remark from his Dulcinea, was so amazed that he could at first find no words to express his admiration; he applauded noiselessly, as they do at the Opera, tapping his fingers together to imitate applause.

zh: “她真是机灵得可爱呀，”他对格朗松太太说，"我就说她总有一天会摘下她的假面具的。”
en: “She is adorably witty,” he said to Madame Granson.“I always said that some day she would unmask her batteries.”

zh: “私下里她总是很可爱。”寡妇回答道。
en: “In private she is always charming,” replied the widow.

zh: “私下里，夫人，所有的女人都很机灵。”骑士接着说道。
en: “In private, madame, all women have wit,” returned the chevalier.

zh: 这场大笑终于平息下来，科尔蒙小姐问大家为什么这么笑。于是大家流言蜚语的拿手好戏开始了。有人说迪布斯基耶是个没有结过婚却有很多子女的纪戈涅爸爸，是个恶魔，过去十五年来是他维持着孤儿收容所。他的不道德生活终于揭露出来了！说他跟巴黎的那些钟情声色的家伙也相差无几，等等，等等。由德瓦卢瓦骑士这个声色乐队的最佳指挥带领，这一曲流言蜚语大汇集的康康序曲演奏得十分精彩。
en: The Homeric laugh thus raised having subsided, Mademoiselle Cormon asked the reason of her success.Then began the FORTE of the gossip.Du Bousquier was depicted as a species of celibate Pere Gigogne, a monster, who for the last fifteen years had kept the Foundling Hospital supplied.His immoral habits were at last revealed! These Parisian saturnalias were the result of them, etc., etc.Conducted by the Chevalier de Valois, a most able leader of an orchestra of this kind, the opening of the CANCAN was magnificent.

zh: “我真搞不懂，”他说，“一个迪布斯基耶这样的人怎么就不能娶一个叫苏珊小姐之类的人呢？她叫什么，你知道吗？叙泽特！虽然我在拉尔多太太家租房住，但我也只是知道这些小女孩长什么样而已。如果这个叙泽特是个身材高挑、活泼莽撞的姑娘，有着灰色的双眸、纤细的腰身和漂亮的小脚，我倒偶尔见过她。对于我来说，她的举止似乎很肆无忌惮，不过比迪布斯基耶的风度要好得多了。而且，这个姑娘很有贵族之美。从这点来看，嫁给迪布斯基耶，她还亏了呢，她可以有更好的选择。你们都知道，约瑟夫皇帝好奇地要到卢夫西恩去看杜巴里。他向她伸出手臂，要带着她散步。这个可怜的姑娘没想到能有这份荣幸，便犹豫着不敢挽皇帝的手臂。‘美人永远是皇后。’皇帝对她如是说。而你们知道，他还是个在奥地利出生的德国人呢，”骑士补上一句。“不过我可以说，德国，我们这儿都认为他们是乡巴佬，其实是一个有着非常高贵的骑士风度和对礼节十分讲究的国家，特别是靠近波兰和匈牙利的地方，在那里——”
en: “I really don’t know,” he said, “what should hinder a du Bousquier from marrying a Mademoiselle Suzanne What’s-her-name.What IS her name, do you know?Suzette!Though I have lodgings at Madame Lardot’s, I know her girls only by sight.If this Suzette is a tall, fine, saucy girl, with gray eyes, a slim waist, and a pretty foot, whom I have occasionally seen, and whose behavior always seemed to me extremely insolent, she is far superior in manners to du Bousquier.Besides, the girl has the nobility of beauty; from that point of view the marriage would be a poor one for her; she might do better.You know how the Emperor Joseph had the curiosity to see the du Barry at Luciennes.He offered her his arm to walk about, and the poor thing was so surprised at the honor that she hesitated to accept it. ‘Beauty is ever a queen,’ said the Emperor.And he, you know, was an Austrian-German,” added the chevalier.“But I can tell you that Germany, which is thought here very rustic, is a land of noble chivalry and fine manners, especially in Poland and Hungary, where—”

zh: 说到这骑士突然停下来，害怕别人会以为是在指他自己过去的艳福呢；他拿出鼻烟盒，将剩下的话留给那位三十六年多来一直对他微笑的公主了。
en: Here the chevalier stopped, fearing to slip into some allusion to his personal happiness; he took out his snuff-box, and confided the rest of his remarks to the princess, who had smiled upon him for thirty-six years and more.

zh: “这句话对路易十五来说，可真是太到位了！”迪龙瑟雷说道。
en: “That speech was rather a delicate one for Louis XV,” said du Ronceret.

zh: “但我认为是约瑟夫皇帝，而不是路易十五。”科尔蒙小姐以纠正的口吻说道。
en: “But it was, I think, the Emperor Joseph who made it, and not Louis XV,” remarked Mademoiselle Cormon, in a correcting tone.

zh: “小姐，”骑士注意到法院院长、公证人和抵押品总馆互换的狡黠的眼神，说道，“杜巴里夫人便是路易十五的苏珊，这是我们这些坏家伙都清楚的事，但是年轻姑娘并不适合知道。您不知道此事证明您是无瑕的白玉，历史上的腐败的事没有影响到您。”
en: “Mademoiselle,” said the chevalier, observing the malicious glance exchanged between the judge, the notary, and the recorder, “Madame du Barry was the Suzanne of Louis XV,—a circumstance well known to scamps like ourselves, but unsuitable for the knowledge of young ladies.Your ignorance proves you to be a flawless diamond; historical corruptions do not enter your mind.”

zh: 德斯蓬德神父亲切地看了看德瓦卢瓦骑士，点点头以示赞许。
en: The Abbe de Sponde looked graciously at the Chevalier de Valois, and nodded his head in sign of his laudatory approbation.

zh: “小姐难道不了解历史？”抵押品总保管问道。
en: “Doesn’t mademoiselle know history?” asked the recorder of mortgages.

zh: “你们把路易十五和苏珊混在一起，我怎么能了解你们的故事呢？”科尔蒙小姐天使般地回答道，很高兴看到橄榄鸭被吃光了，而且谈话也很热烈。在座的宾客听到她这句话，虽然嘴里满满的，但都忍不住哈哈大笑起来。
en: “If you mix up Louis XV and this girl Suzanne, how am I to know history?” replied Mademoiselle Cormon, angelically, glad to see that the dish of ducks was empty at last, and the conversation so ready to revive that all present laughed with their mouths full at her last remark.

zh: “可怜的小姑娘！”德斯蓬德神父说道，“慈善是一种神圣的爱，与不信教的人的爱情一样盲目。当不幸发生了，慈善就不应该再去考虑是什么原因造成的了。外甥女，你是妇女协会的主席，你们必须帮助那可怜的姑娘，她大概很难嫁人了。”
en: “Poor girl!” said the Abbe de Sponde.“When a great misfortune happens, charity, which is divine love, and as blind as pagan love, ought not to look into the causes of it.Niece, you are president of the Maternity Society; you must succor that poor girl, who will now find it difficult to marry.”

zh: “可怜的孩子！”科尔蒙小姐感慨到。
en: “Poor child!” ejaculated Mademoiselle Cormon.

zh: “你们认为迪布斯基耶会娶她吗？”法院院长问。
en: “Do you suppose du Bousquier would marry her?” asked the judge.

zh: “如果他是一位正直的人，就应该娶她，”格朗松太太说道，“但是，坦白说，我家的狗都比他品格正派些呢——”
en: “If he is an honorable man he ought to do so,” said Madame Granson; “but really, to tell the truth, my dog has better morals than he—”

zh: “不过阿佐尔确是一位大商人哦。”抵押品总保管以诙谐的语气说道。
en: “Azor is, however, a good purveyor,” said the recorder of mortgages, with the air of saying a witty thing.

zh: 到了吃甜点的时候，人们还在谈论迪布斯基耶。几杯酒下肚，大家说的各种挖苦话更加刻薄些了。在抵押品总保管的带动下，大家你一句我一句地调侃起来。于是，迪布斯基耶就成了一个神父，但却不是自白者；他没有神父；他如神父般；他不是教士的神父，也还不是被征召的神父——
en: At dessert du Bousquier was still the topic of conversation, having given rise to various little jokes which the wine rendered sparkling.Following the example of the recorder, each guest capped his neighbor’s joke with another: Du Bousquier was a father, but not a confessor; he was father less; he was father LY; he was not a reverend father; nor yet a conscript-father—

zh: “他也不能当养父。”德斯蓬德神父表情严肃地说道，止住了大家的笑声。
en: “Nor can he be a foster-father,” said the Abbe de Sponde, with a gravity which stopped the laughter.

zh: “也不是品德高尚的贵族老先生。”骑士接着说道。
en: “Nor a noble father,” added the chevalier.

zh: 教会和贵族虽然还保持着他们的尊严，但也都玩起这样的文字游戏了。
en: The Church and the nobility descended thus into the arena of puns, without, however, losing their dignity.

zh: “嘘！”抵押品总保管说道，“我听到迪布斯基耶的靴子响了。”
en: “Hush!” exclaimed the recorder of mortgages.“I hear the creaking of du Bousquier’s boots.”

zh: 事情往往是这样的，一个人总是不知道自己背后的流言蜚语。也许全城都在议论他，在诽谤他，或是公开指责他，但如果他没有朋友，就会一无所知。现在这个无辜的迪布斯基耶就是超级无知。没有人告诉他苏珊已经透露了那件事，因此，他表现得非常自满，还有点自命不凡的样子；这时，大伙正离开饭厅，回到客厅准备喝咖啡；另外一些准备晚上打牌的客人也来了。科尔蒙小姐因为觉得羞耻，不敢抬眼看这个引诱少女的可恶家伙。她抓住了阿塔纳斯，开始对他说了一番关于保王政治和宗教道德的莫名其妙的陈词滥调。这个可怜的诗人不像德瓦卢瓦骑士一样有个装饰着公主肖像的鼻烟盒，以便忍受这番蠢话。他只有呆呆地听着他所爱慕的人讲话，同时盯着她那硕大的胸部，在他眼前的那上身是这完美身躯体积庞大的标志。他的情欲让他陶醉于这老姑娘的讲话中，她尖锐的嗓音变成了温柔的絮语，她乏味的言谈变成了机智的话语。爱情是一个假币制造者，不断地将铜币换成金币，而有时也将真的金币换成铜币。
en: It usually happens that a man is ignorant of rumors that are afloat about him.A whole town may be talking of his affairs; may calumniate and decry him, but if he has no good friends, he will know nothing about it.Now the innocent du Bousquier was superb in his ignorance.No one had told him as yet of Suzanne’s revelations; he therefore appeared very jaunty and slightly conceited when the company, leaving the dining-room, returned to the salon for their coffee; several other guests had meantime assembled for the evening.Mademoiselle Cormon, from a sense of shamefacedness, dared not look at the terrible seducer.She seized upon Athanase, and began to lecture him with the queerest platitudes about royalist politics and religious morality.Not possessing, like the Chevalier de Valois, a snuff-box adorned with a princess, by the help of which he could stand this torrent of silliness, the poor poet listened to the words of her whom he loved with a stupid air, gazing, meanwhile, at her enormous bust, which held itself before him in that still repose which is the attribute of all great masses.His love produced in him a sort of intoxication which changed the shrill voice of the old maid into a soft murmur, and her flat remarks into witty speeches.Love is a maker of false coin, continually changing copper pennies into gold-pieces, and sometimes turning its real gold into copper.

zh: “好了，阿塔纳斯，你能答应我吗？”
en: “Well, Athanase, will you promise me?”

zh: 这最后一句话，像是会惊醒我们的声音一样，击在这个正陶醉其中的年轻人的耳膜上。
en: This final sentence struck the ear of the absorbed young man like one of those noises which wake us with a bound.

zh: “什么，小姐？”
en: “What, mademoiselle?”

zh: 科尔蒙小姐突然站起来，同时看了迪布斯基耶一眼。那一刻，他酷似共和国硬币上那位神话中的胖天神。她朝格朗松太太走过去，在她耳边说：
en: Mademoiselle Cormon rose hastily, and looked at du Bousquier, who at that moment resembled the stout god of Fable which the Republic stamped upon her coins.She walked up to Madame Granson, and said in her ear:—

zh: “我亲爱的朋友，你的儿子真是个傻瓜。那个学院糟蹋了他。”她补充道，同时想起德瓦卢瓦骑士反复强调过那种学校的教育非常糟糕。
en: “My dear friend, your son is an idiot.That lyceum has ruined him,” she added, remembering the insistence with which the chevalier had spoken of the evils of education in such schools.

zh: 这真是晴天霹雳呀！可怜的阿塔纳斯还不知道，他刚才完全有机会用他自己火焰的余烬点燃老姑娘心中堆积的毛刷。他刚才要是仔细听了她说什么，当时当地他就能让这老姑娘了解他的激情，因为当时科尔蒙小姐正处于情绪激动之中，一句话就足够了。可是他当时正处于年轻人对真爱的愚蠢的陶醉中，错过了良机，就像一个充满生命力的孩子有时会因为无知而害死了自己。
en: What a catastrophe!Unknown to himself, the luckless Athanase had had an occasion to fling an ember of his own fire upon the pile of brush gathered in the heart of the old maid.Had he listened to her, he might have made her, then and there, perceive his passion; for, in the agitated state of Mademoiselle Cormon’s mind, a single word would have sufficed.But that stupid absorption in his own sentiments, which characterizes young and true love, had ruined him, as a child full of life sometimes kills itself out of ignorance.

zh: “你刚才对科尔蒙小姐说了什么？”格朗松太太问她的儿子。
en: “What have you been saying to Mademoiselle Cormon?” demanded his mother.

zh: “没说什么。”
en: “Nothing.”

zh: “什么也没说，好吧，等下我会弄清楚。”她心中想道，把这件事推到明天再想，并且认为科尔蒙小姐刚才的话没什么大不了的。因为她认为经过那晚的讨论，迪布斯基耶在老姑娘心目中的形象已经完全毁了。
en: “Nothing; well, I can explain that,” she thought to herself, putting off till the next day all further reflection on the matter, and attaching but little importance to Mademoiselle Cormon’s words; for she fully believed that du Bousquier was forever lost in the old maid’s esteem after the revelation of that evening.

zh: 不久，客厅的四张牌桌就坐满了十六位玩家。四位在玩皮克牌——皮克牌是一项花销很大的游戏，玩家往往要搭上许多钱。舒瓦内尔先生、检察官和另两位女士到小客厅里去玩西洋双陆棋了。多枝烛台上的蜡烛都已点燃，于是科尔蒙小姐的女伴们在壁炉前、沙发上和牌桌旁纷纷就座。每对新到的夫妇都问她：
en: Soon the four tables were filled with their sixteen players.Four persons were playing piquet,—an expensive game, at which the most money was lost.Monsieur Choisnel, the procureur-du-roi, and two ladies went into the boudoir for a game at backgammon.The glass lustres were lighted; and then the flower of Mademoiselle Cormon’s company gathered before the fireplace, on sofas, and around the tables, and each couple said to her as they arrived,—

zh: “您明天就要去普雷博戴了吗？”
en: “So you are going to-morrow to Prebaudet?”

zh: “是呀，我得去了。”她答道。
en: “Yes, I really must,” she replied.

zh: 这种情况下，这房子的女主人就显得特别忙碌。格朗松太太是第一个发现这老姑娘的情绪有点反常的——科尔蒙小姐居然有心事！
en: On this occasion the mistress of the house appeared preoccupied.Madame Granson was the first to perceive the quite unnatural state of the old maid’s mind,—Mademoiselle Cormon was thinking!

zh: “你在想什么呢，表妹？”等科尔蒙小姐在小客厅坐下后，格朗松太太终于有机会问她了。
en: “What are you thinking of, cousin?” she said at last, finding her seated in the boudoir.

zh: “我在想那个可怜的小姑娘呢，”她答道，“作为妇女协会的主席，我要你替我拿五十法郎给她。”
en: “I am thinking,” she replied, “of that poor girl.As the president of the Maternity Society, I will give you fifty francs for her.”

zh: “五十法郎！”格朗松太太惊叹道，“你可从来没有捐过这么多钱呀！”
en: “Fifty francs!” cried Madame Granson.“But you have never given as much as that.”

zh: “可是，我的好表姐，有孩子不是很自然的嘛。”
en: “But, my dear cousin, it is so natural to have children.”

zh: 这位老姑娘发自内心的不道德的话让妇女协会的司库目瞪口呆了。显然迪布斯基耶在科尔蒙小姐心中的形象更加高大起来了。
en: That immoral speech coming from the heart of the old maid staggered the treasurer of the Maternity Society.Du Bousquier had evidently advanced in the estimation of Mademoiselle Cormon.

zh: “说实在的，”格朗松太太说，“迪布斯基耶不仅是个恶棍，还是个流氓。一个男人做了这样的错事，他就应该赔偿全部的损失。要负责照顾这个小姑娘的，应该是他而不是我们吧？说实话，在我看来这个姑娘也不够正经，在阿郎松，比迪布斯基耶这个愤世嫉俗的家伙好的男人大有人在。这个女孩一定很放荡，才会去找他。”
en: “Upon my word,” said Madame Granson, “du Bousquier is not only a monster, he is a villain.When a man has done a wrong like that, he ought to pay the indemnity.Isn’t it his place rather than ours to look after the girl?—who, to tell you the truth, seems to me rather questionable; there are plenty of better men in Alencon than that cynic du Bousquier.A girl must be depraved, indeed, to go after him.”

zh: “愤世嫉俗！亲爱的，你的儿子教了你一些完全不可理解的拉丁词。我当然不是要原谅迪布斯基耶先生。不过，请解释下，一个女人喜欢一个男人而不喜欢别的男人，怎么就说她是放荡的呢？”
en: “Cynic! Your son teaches you to talk Latin, my dear, which is wholly incomprehensible.Certainly I don’t wish to excuse Monsieur du Bousquier; but pray explain to me why a woman is depraved because she prefers one man to another.”

zh: “亲爱的表妹，如果你嫁给我的儿子阿塔纳斯，那才是最自然不过的啦。他年轻英俊，前途无量，他将成为阿郎松的骄傲；尽管每个人都会针对你说些坏话：那些毒舌头会说各种各样的话，嫉妒的女人会谴责你堕落——但那又有什么要紧呢？你会得到爱，真正的爱。如果你觉得阿塔纳斯是傻瓜，亲爱的，那是因为他的思想太丰富了，物极必反嘛。他过的是十五岁少女般的生活；他完全没有染上巴黎的生活恶习，绝对没有！哎，换个话题吧，我那可怜的丈夫常这么说，迪布斯基耶和苏珊的关系也是如此。你可能会遭人诽谤，不过，迪布斯基耶这件事上，大家说的都是真的。难道你不懂我的意思吗？”
en: “My dear cousin, suppose you married my son Athanase; nothing could be more natural.He is young and handsome, full of promise, and he will be the glory of Alencon; and yet everybody will exclaim against you: evil tongues will say all sorts of things; jealous women will accuse you of depravity,—but what will that matter?you will be loved, and loved truly.If Athanase seemed to you an idiot, my dear, it is that he has too many ideas; extremes meet.He lives the life of a girl of fifteen; he has never wallowed in the impurities of Paris, not he!Well, change the terms, as my poor husband used to say; it is the same thing with du Bousquier in connection with Suzanne.YOU would be calumniated; but in the case of du Bousquier, the charge would be true.Don’t you understand me?”

zh: “和你跟我讲希腊语一样不明白。”科尔蒙小姐眼睛睁得大大地说道，把自己的全部智慧都使出来了。
en: “No more than if you were talking Greek,” replied Mademoiselle Cormon, who opened her eyes wide, and strained all the forces of her intellect.

zh: “唉，表妹，如果我必须把话讲个明白，我就直说了，苏珊是不可能爱迪布斯基耶的。如果这件事上，没有一点儿真心——”
en: “Well, cousin, if I must dot all the i’s, it is impossible for Suzanne to love du Bousquier.And if the heart counts for nothing in this affair—”

zh: “但是，表姐，如果人们不用心爱，那该怎么爱呢？”
en: “But, cousin, what do people love with if not their hearts?”

zh: 格朗松太太听到这里，不禁产生和骑士先前同样的想法：“我这可怜的表妹真是太天真了，愚蠢得让人受不了！——亲爱的”，她接着大声说道，“我认为孩子不单是靠想出来的。”“怎么不是，亲爱的，圣母玛利亚她——”
en: Here Madame Granson said to herself, as the chevalier had previously thought: “My poor cousin is altogether too innocent; such stupidity passes all bounds! —Dear child,” she continued aloud, “it seems to me that children are not conceived by the spirit only.”“Why, yes, my dear; the Holy Virgin herself—”

zh: “但是，亲爱的，迪布斯基耶不是圣灵啊！”
en: “But, my love, du Bousquier isn’t the Holy Ghost!”

zh: “没错，”老姑娘说，”他是一个男人！这个男人的行为使他自己成了一个相当危险的人物，以至于他的朋友们都建议他得结婚。”“表妹，你自己就可以带来那样的结果呀。”
en: “True,” said the old maid; “he is a man! —a man whose personal appearance makes him dangerous enough for his friends to advise him to marry.”“You could yourself bring about that result, cousin.”

zh: “怎么做呢？”老姑娘带着基督徒慈悲为怀的心情说道。
en: “How so?” said the old maid, with the meekness of Christian charity.

zh: “你可以不接待他，除非他结婚才行。在这种情况下，你应该凭着美德和宗教信仰来清楚地表现出作为表率的谴责。”
en: “By not receiving him in your house until he marries.You owe it to good morals and to religion to manifest under such circumstances an exemplary displeasure.”

zh: “等我从普雷博戴回来，我们再谈吧，亲爱的格朗松太太。我还要咨询我舅舅和库蒂里耶神父的意见呢。”科尔蒙小姐说完便回到客厅，那里正是最热闹的时候。
en: “On my return from Prebaudet we will talk further of this, my dear Madame Granson.I will consult my uncle and the Abbe Couturier,” said Mademoiselle Cormon, returning to the salon, where the animation was now at its height.

zh: 灯火辉煌，女人们穿得花枝招展，聚会的人语气庄重而且高贵，这一切都使科尔蒙小姐对她的这个小圈子骄傲不已。对许多人来说，在巴黎的最高级聚会里，也看不到比这更豪华的场面了吧。
en: The lights, the group of women in their best clothes, the solemn tone, the dignified air of the assembly, made Mademoiselle Cormon not a little proud of her company.To many persons nothing better could be seen in Paris in the highest society.

zh: 这时，迪布斯基耶正和德瓦卢瓦骑士以及两位老妇人——迪库得赖夫人和迪龙瑟雷夫人——玩着惠斯特。他已成了大家好奇地默默观察的对象。有几位少妇走过来，借口看牌，实际上是在仔细地偷偷打量他，尽管她们做得不明显，但就这么定定地看着他，让迪布斯基耶这老光棍还以为他的穿着打扮有什么问题呢。
en: At this moment du Bousquier, who was playing whist with the chevalier and two old ladies,—Madame du Coudrai and Madame du Ronceret,—was the object of deep but silent curiosity.A few young women arrived, who, under pretext of watching the game, gazed fixedly at him in so singular a manner, though slyly, that the old bachelor began to think that there must be some deficiency in his toilet.

zh: “是不是我的假发戴歪了？”他暗想，感到很不自在，这是最让老光棍们担心的事了。
en: “Can my false front be crooked?” he asked himself, seized by one of those anxieties which beset old bachelors.

zh: 在第七局结束他输了的时候，他利用这个机会起身离开牌桌。
en: He took advantage of a lost trick, which ended a seventh rubber, to rise and leave the table.

zh: “我今天一碰牌就输，”他说，“显然运气很不好呀。”
en: “I can’t touch a card without losing,” he said.“I am decidedly too unlucky.”

zh: “但是你在别的事上很走运呀。”骑士狡猾地瞟了他一眼。
en: “But you are lucky in other ways,” said the chevalier, giving him a sly look.

zh: 这句话在客厅里不胫而走，大家都学着骑士的绝妙腔调，使得骑士相当于当地的塔莱朗亲王了。
en: That speech naturally made the rounds of the salon, where every one exclaimed on the exquisite taste of the chevalier, the Prince de Talleyrand of the province.

zh: “再也没有人有德瓦卢瓦骑士这样的机智了。”
en: “There’s no one like Monsieur de Valois for such wit.”

zh: 迪布斯基耶走到那《逃兵》画上的椭圆镜子前照了照，没发现他的外表有什么异样。
en: Du Bousquier went to look at himself in a little oblong mirror, placed above the “Deserter,” but he saw nothing strange in his appearance.

zh: 同样的告别语，用了各种语调重复了无数遍后，客人们在将近十点钟的时候沿着长长的前厅纷纷离去。科尔蒙小姐将几位贵客送到台阶上告别。人们三五成群地离开了，有的沿着布列塔尼大路朝着城堡方向走去，有的朝萨尔特河的住宅区走去。于是，在阿郎松这条街上、在这个时间重复了二十年的对话，又开始了。还是一如既往的：
en: After innumerable repetitions of the same text, varied in all keys, the departure of the company took place about ten o’clock, through the long antechamber, Mademoiselle Cormon conducting certain of her favorite guests to the portico.There the groups parted; some followed the Bretagne road towards the chateau; the others went in the direction of the river Sarthe.Then began the usual conversation, which for twenty years had echoed at that hour through this particular street of Alencon.It was invariably:—

zh: “科尔蒙小姐今晚看上去真好。”
en: “Mademoiselle Cormon looked very well to-night.”

zh: “科尔蒙小姐？不会吧，我觉得她今晚很反常。”“那个可怜的神父身体越来越不行了！他一直在睡觉，你注意到了吗？他连他拿的什么牌都不知道；他真是很心不在焉呀。”
en: “Mademoiselle Cormon? why, I thought her rather strange.”“How that poor abbe fails!Did you notice that he slept?He does not know what cards he holds; he is getting very absent-minded.”

zh: “他恐怕活不长了哦。”
en: “We shall soon have the grief of losing him.”

zh: “今晚天气真好！明天天气肯定不错。”
en: “What a fine night!It will be a fine day to-morrow.”

zh: “这种天气很适合苹果树开花呀。”
en: “Good weather for the apple-blossoms.”

zh: “你赢了我们，但是你和德瓦卢瓦先生玩的时候，你可赢不了。”
en: “You beat us; but when you play with Monsieur de Valois you never do otherwise.”

zh: “他赢了多少？”
en: “How much did he win?”

zh: “嗯，今天晚上，大概三、四法郎吧。他从来不会输的。”
en: “Well, to-night, three or four francs; he never loses.”

zh: “的确，难道你不知道一年有三百六十五天吗？这么算下来，他都能赢一座农场啦。”
en: “True; and don’t you know there are three hundred and sixty-five days a year?At that price his gains are the value of a farm.”

zh: “哎呀！我们今晚输得真惨！”“先生，夫人，你们就到家了，多好呀！我们还要穿过半个城呢！”
en: “Ah! what hands we had to-night!”“Here you are at home, monsieur and madame, how lucky you are, while we have half the town to cross!”

zh: “我可不同情你们；你们完全可以买一辆马车，免掉步行之劳呀。”
en: “I don’t pity you; you could afford a carriage, and dispense with the fatigue of going on foot.”

zh: “哎呀，先生！我们有一个女儿要出嫁，这就耗掉了一个轮子，还有一个儿子在巴黎要我们供给，这就耗掉了另一个车轮了。”“你们还是要培养他当法官吗？”
en: “Ah, monsieur! We have a daughter to marry, which takes off one wheel, and the support of our son in Paris carries off another.”“You persist in making a magistrate of him?”

zh: “年轻人还能学什么呢？而且，给国王效劳总没有什么可耻的。”
en: “What else can be done with a young man?Besides, there’s no shame in serving the king.”

zh: 有时大家会谈起苹果酒和亚麻，总是那些话，每年不同的时节在回家的路上谈的都是那个时节的内容。任何一个曾住在这条街上并善于观察人类风俗的人，只要他用心听听谈话的内容，就能知道现在是几月了。
en: Sometimes a discussion on ciders and flax, always couched in the same terms, and returning at the same time of year, was continued on the homeward way.If any observer of human customs had lived in this street, he would have known the months and seasons by simply overhearing the conversations.

zh: 这时谈话的内容特别有趣；迪布斯基耶正独自走在人群的前面，哼着著名的“多情善感的女郎啊！你可听见小鸟在歌唱”的曲子，根本没想过合不合适。有些人认为，迪布斯基耶是个很能干的人，只是大家对他有误解。自从一个新的王政机构批准给他一个职位后，迪龙瑟雷院长就一直支持他。而其他的人则认为这个商人很危险，说他道德败坏，什么事都干得出来。在外省和在巴黎一样，惹人注目的人与艾迪生那则美妙寓言中的雕像一样：两个骑士从不同的方向看到这座雕像，便互相争论起来，一个说雕像是白的，一个说雕像是黑的，并因此动武。当他们都下马后才发现，这雕像一边是白的，一边是黑的。而到的第三个骑士说这雕像是红的。
en: On this occasion it was exclusively jocose; for du Bousquier, who chanced to march alone in front of the groups, was humming the well-known air,—little thinking of its appropriateness,—“Tender woman! hear the warble of the birds,” etc.To some, du Bousquier was a strong man and a misjudged man.Ever since he had been confirmed in his present office by a royal decree, Monsieur du Ronceret had been in favor of du Bousquier.To others the purveyor seemed dangerous,—a man of bad habits, capable of anything.In the provinces, as in Paris, men before the public eye are like that statue in the fine allegorical tale of Addison, for which two knights on arriving near it fought; for one saw it white, the other saw it black.Then, when they were both off their horses, they saw it was white one side and black the other.A third knight coming along declared it red.

zh: 那晚骑士回家时，想了很多：
en: When the chevalier went home that night, he made many reflections, as follows:—

zh: “现在是时候让大家开始谣传我要和科尔蒙小姐结婚了。这个消息得从德埃斯格里翁家的客厅传出去，然后传到赛镇的主教家里，通过代理主教们再传到圣莱奥纳尔教堂神父那里；神父一定会告诉库蒂里耶神父，这样的话，科尔蒙小姐就会受到一系列的影响。德埃斯格里尼翁老侯爵就会请德斯蓬德神父吃饭，以制止各种对科尔蒙小姐不利的流言（如果我决定拒绝她）或是对我不利的流言（如果她拒绝我的话）。神父很容易被打动，而科尔蒙小姐也不会反对阿芒德小姐登门拜访，这位小姐将告诉她这桩婚事是多么了不起，前程多么光明。斯蓬德神父的财产肯定有三十万法郎；她自己的积蓄应该也有二十多万法郎，并且她还有公馆、普雷博戴的地产以及一万五千法郎的固定收入。只要向我的朋友德方丹伯爵说上一句话，我就能当上阿郎松下一任的市长和议员。然后，一旦坐上右翼的板凳，我就能进入贵族院，高喊‘闭幕！’或者‘开始议题！’。”
en: “It is high time now to spread a rumor of my marriage with Mademoiselle Cormon.It will leak out from the d’Esgrignon salon, and go straight to the bishop at Seez, and so get round through the grand vicars to the curate of Saint-Leonard’s, who will be certain to tell it to the Abbe Couturier; and Mademoiselle Cormon will get the shot in her upper works.The old Marquis d’Esgrignon shall invite the Abbe de Sponde to dinner, so as to stop all gossip about Mademoiselle Cormon if I decide against her, or about me if she refuses me.The abbe shall be well cajoled; and Mademoiselle Cormon will certainly not hold out against a visit from Mademoiselle Armande, who will show her the grandeur and future chances of such an alliance.The abbe’s property is undoubtedly as much as three hundred thousand; her own savings must amount to more than two hundred thousand; she has her house and Prebaudet and fifteen thousand francs a year.A word to my friend the Comte de Fontaine, and I should be mayor of Alencon to-morrow, and deputy.Then, once seated on the Right benches, we shall reach the peerage, shouting, ‘Cloture!’‘Ordre!’”

zh: 格朗松太太一到家，便跟儿子激烈地争论了一番。她的儿子不能明白他的政见和爱情有什么关系。这还是头一回打破这贫寒家庭和睦气氛的争吵。
en: As soon as she reached home Madame Granson had a lively argument with her son, who could not be made to see the connection which existed between his love and his political opinions.It was the first quarrel that had ever troubled that poor household.

zh: 第六章 最终的失望及其最初的影响
en: CHAPTER VI FINAL DISAPPOINTMENT AND ITS FIRST RESULT

zh: 第二天，科尔蒙小姐和若赛特坐上马车出发了。在包裹堆成的海洋上，她的身影就像一座金字塔。马车沿圣布莱兹街北行，到普雷博戴去。在普雷博戴发生了一件出人意料的事，加速了她的婚事。这件事，无论是格朗松太太、迪布斯基耶、德瓦卢瓦先生，还是科尔蒙小姐本人都无法预料。机遇是最伟大的艺术家。
en: The next day, Mademoiselle Cormon, packed into the old carriole with Josette, and looking like a pyramid on a vast sea of parcels, drove up the rue Saint-Blaise on her way to Prebaudet, where she was overtaken by an event which hurried on her marriage,—an event entirely unlooked for by either Madame Granson, du Bousquier, Monsieur de Valois, or Mademoiselle Cormon himself.Chance is the greatest of all artificers.

zh: 到达普雷博戴的第二天，早上八点左右，科尔蒙小姐正一边吃着早饭，一边天真地忙着听取看守人和园丁的各种报告，这时雅克兰突然跑进饭厅。
en: The day after her arrival at Prebaudet, she was innocently employed, about eight o’clock in the morning, in listening, as she breakfasted, to the various reports of her keeper and her gardener, when Jacquelin made a violent irruption into the dining-room.

zh: “小姐，”他上气不接下气地喊道，“您舅父给您派了特急信使，是格罗莫尔老太太的儿子，带了一封信来。这小伙子天没亮就出发了，他刚到这儿，他简直像珀涅罗珀那样跑过来的！给他一杯酒喝吧？”
en: “Mademoiselle,” he cried, out of breath, “Monsieur l’abbe sends you an express, the son of Mere Grosmort, with a letter.The lad left Alencon before daylight, and he has just arrived; he ran like Penelope!Can’t I give him a glass of wine?”

zh: “会是什么事呢，若赛特？不会是我舅舅——”
en: “What can have happened, Josette?Do you think my uncle can be—”

zh: “如果是，那他就写不了信了。”若赛特猜到了女主人担心的事情，因而说道。
en: “He couldn’t write if he were,” said Josette, guessing her mistress’s fears.

zh: “快！快！”科尔蒙小姐看了头几行内容后便大喊起来。“叫雅克兰把珀涅罗珀套上！若赛特，快收拾下，半小时之内打包好。我们要赶紧回城——”
en: "Quick! quick!” cried Mademoiselle Cormon, as soon as she had read the first lines.“Tell Jacquelin to harness Penelope—Get ready, Josette; pack up everything in half an hour.We must go back to town—”

zh: “雅克兰！”若赛特看着女主人的表情也着急地大喊道。
en: “Jacquelin!” called Josette, excited by the sentiment she saw on her mistress’s face.

zh: 雅克兰听到若赛特喊后，走进来说道：
en: Jacquelin, informed by Josette, came in to say,—

zh: “可是，小姐，珀涅罗珀在吃燕麦呢。”
en: “But, mademoiselle, Penelope is eating her oats.”

zh: “那又有什么关系？我要马上走。”
en: “What does that signify?I must start at once.”

zh: “可是，小姐，马上就要下雨了。”
en: “But, mademoiselle, it is going to rain.”

zh: “那我们就淋雨吧。”
en: “Then we shall get wet.”

zh: “家里着火了！”若赛特嘀咕着说，很郁闷女主人看完信后一言不发，却又反复地读。
en: “The house is on fire!” muttered Josette, piqued at the silence her mistress kept as to the contents of the letter, which she read and reread.

zh: “至少喝完咖啡吧，小姐；别那么着急，瞧您满脸通红的。”
en: “Finish your coffee, at any rate, mademoiselle; don’t excite your blood; just see how red you are.”

zh: “我脸红了吗，若赛特？”她说着便去照镜子。镜子上的水银正往下掉，照出来她的样子怪怪的。
en: “Am I red, Josette?” she said, going to a mirror, from which the quicksilver was peeling, and which presented her features to her upside down.

zh: “天哪！”科尔蒙小姐心想，“我要是变丑了怎么办！来，若赛特，亲爱的，快帮我穿上衣服；我要在雅克兰把珀涅罗珀套好之前准备好。如果你来不及收拾好包裹，那就先留在这儿吧，我可不愿浪费一分钟的时间。”
en: “Good heavens!” thought Mademoiselle Cormon, “suppose I should look ugly!Come, Josette; come, my dear, dress me at once; I want to be ready before Jacquelin has harnessed Penelope.If you can’t pack my things in time, I will leave them here rather than lose a single minute.”

zh: 如果你能完全理解科尔蒙小姐想要结婚的欲望已经到了偏执狂的地步，你就能体会她的心情了。她的好舅舅通知她说，他最要好的一个朋友有个孙子，叫德特雷维尔，以前去当兵为俄国服务，现在想退伍后回到阿郎松居住。鉴于他祖父德特雷维尔男爵与神父之间的友情，希望神父能予以接待。这位老神父很紧张，要求外甥女立即返回，帮助他接待这位客人，以尽地主之谊。他收到的那封信已经迟了，德特雷维尔先生很可能当晚就会到达。
en: If you have thoroughly comprehended the positive monomania to which the desire of marriage had brought Mademoiselle Cormon, you will share her emotion.The worthy uncle announced in this sudden missive that Monsieur de Troisville, of the Russian army during the Emigration, grandson of one of his best friends, was desirous of retiring to Alencon, and asked his, the abbe’s hospitality, on the ground of his friendship for his grandfather, the Vicomte de Troisville.The old abbe, alarmed at the responsibility, entreated his niece to return instantly and help him to receive this guest, and do the honors of the house; for the viscount’s letter had been delayed, and he might descend upon his shoulders that very night.

zh: 看完这封信后，科尔蒙小姐怎么还顾得上普雷博戴呢？看守人和园丁都亲眼看到科尔蒙小姐激动的样子，便站在一边等待她的吩咐。但是就在科尔蒙小姐要离开的时候，他们拦住她询问她的指示。这位在普雷博戴事事都要亲自过问的专横的老姑娘，居然第一次对他们说“你们看着办吧”，让他们目瞪口呆。要知道，这老姑娘平时对她果园的管理，细致到有多少个水果都要数得一清二楚，还要做上记号，以便按照每种水果的数目和情况来安排消费事宜！
en: After reading this missive could there be a question of the demands of Prebaudet?The keeper and the gardener, witnesses to Mademoiselle Cormon’s excitement, stood aside and awaited her orders.But when, as she was about to leave the room, they stopped her to ask for instructions, for the first time in her life the despotic old maid, who saw to everything at Prebaudet with her own eyes, said, to their stupefaction, “Do what you like.”This from a mistress who carried her administration to the point of counting her fruits, and marking them so as to order their consumption according to the number and condition of each!

zh: “我是在做梦吧，”若赛特看见她的女主人像是上帝给装上了翅膀的大象一般飞快地跑下楼梯时，不禁想到。
en: “I believe I’m dreaming,” thought Josette, as she saw her mistress flying down the staircase like an elephant to which God has given wings.

zh: 此刻，尽管下着大雨，科尔蒙小姐已经离开了普雷博戴，让她的下人自由处理各种事物。雅克兰可不敢擅自做主，驱使性情平和的珀涅罗珀比平时加快速度。这珀涅罗珀，生来就像她名字所代表的那位美丽王后一样，好像总是往前走几步，又往后退几步似的。科尔蒙小姐可受不了这速度了，用刺耳的声音命令雅克兰驾马快跑，必要的话，抽上几鞭子，这可吓到了这可怜的牲畜。科尔蒙小姐生怕没有时间安排好家中的一切来接待德特雷维尔先生。她算计着，舅舅朋友的孙子，大概就四十岁吧，是军人的话肯定还是单身。于是她决定，靠着舅舅的帮助，绝对不让德特雷维尔怎么走进家门，还怎么离开。科尔蒙小姐已经在想她的嫁妆和她的婚礼了。虽然珀涅罗珀在拼命奔跑，可是科尔蒙小姐还是不停地对雅克兰说，这马没有往前走。她在马车里坐立不安，顾不上回答若赛特的问话，自顾自地说着话，像是在考虑重大计划的人一样。
en: Presently, in spite of a driving rain, Mademoiselle Cormon drove away from Prebaudet, leaving her factotums with the reins on their necks.Jacquelin dared not take upon himself to hasten the usual little trot of the peaceable Penelope, who, like the beautiful queen whose name she bore, had an appearance of making as many steps backward as she made forward.Impatient with the pace, mademoiselle ordered Jacquelin in a sharp voice to drive at a gallop, with the whip, if necessary, to the great astonishment of the poor beast, so afraid was she of not having time to arrange the house suitably to receive Monsieur de Troisville.She calculated that the grandson of her uncle’s friend was probably about forty years of age; a soldier just from service was undoubtedly a bachelor; and she resolved, her uncle aiding, not to let Monsieur de Troisville quit their house in the condition he entered it.Though Penelope galloped, Mademoiselle Cormon, absorbed in thoughts of her trousseau and the wedding-day, declared again and again that Jacquelin made no way at all.She twisted about in the carriole without replying to Josette’s questions, and talked to herself like a person who is mentally revolving important designs.

zh: 马车终于到了阿郎松的主干道上。从莫尔塔涅方向进城，这条街叫圣布莱兹街，到了摩尔旅馆附近的街叫赛镇门大街，而通向布列塔尼大马路上的这条街是羊圈街。科尔蒙小姐离开时惊动了整个阿郎松城，而现在可以想见，她刚在普雷博戴安下身的第二天就冒着大雨返回，在阿郎松又会激起怎样的喧嚣。大雨打在她的脸上，她也根本不在乎。每个人都注意到了珀涅罗珀的疾驰，雅克兰诡诈的笑，大清早的时间，乱七八糟的包裹，以及科尔蒙小姐迫不及待的神情。
en: The carriole at last arrived in the main street of Alencon, called the rue Saint-Blaise at the end toward Montagne, but near the hotel du More it takes the name of the rue de la Porte-de-Seez, and becomes the rue du Bercail as it enters the road to Brittany.If the departure of Mademoiselle Cormon made a great noise in Alencon, it is easy to imagine the uproar caused by her sudden return on the following day, in a pouring rain which beat her face without her apparently minding it.Penelope at a full gallop was observed by every one, and Jacquelin’s grin, the early hour, the parcels stuffed into the carriole topsy-turvy, and the evident impatience of Mademoiselle Cormon were all noted.

zh: 特雷维尔家的房产位于阿郎松和莫尔塔涅之间。若赛特对这个家族的各个支系都很了解。在进入阿郎松城的时候，小姐透露的一句话让若赛特恍然大悟。于是主仆二人进行了讨论，确认要来的这个德特雷维尔大概是四十到四十二岁的单身贵族，家境不富也不穷。科尔蒙小姐现在似乎已看到自己成了德特雷维尔子爵夫人。
