en: The property of the house of Troisville lay between Alencon and Mortagne.Josette knew the various branches of the family.A word dropped by mademoiselle as they entered Alencon had put Josette on the scent of the affair; and a discussion having started between them, it was settled that the expected de Troisville must be between forty and forty-two years of age, a bachelor, and neither rich nor poor.Mademoiselle Cormon beheld herself speedily Vicomtesse de Troisville.

zh: “我舅舅居然什么也不告诉我！什么也不考虑！什么也不打听！这就是我舅舅。要不是他的鼻子长在他的脸上，他大概连自己的鼻子都会忘了吧。”
en: “And to think that my uncle told me nothing! Thinks of nothing! Inquires nothing!That’s my uncle all over.He’d forget his own nose if it wasn’t fastened to his face.”

zh: 你注意到没有，在这种情形下，老姑娘像理查三世一样变得聪明、凶狠、大胆、轻诺寡信；或者也可以说，她像酒醉的教士一样，什么都不顾了。
en: Have you never remarked that, under circumstances such as these, old maids become, like Richard III, keen-witted, fierce, bold, promissory,—if one may so use the word,—and, like inebriate clerks, no longer in awe of anything?

zh: 很快，科尔蒙小姐突然回来这件事及相应的情形就从圣布莱兹街的街首一直传到赛镇门，传遍了整个阿郎松城，全程的公共活动和家庭活动都受到了影响。厨师、商贩和行人都纷纷挨家挨户传播着这条新闻，接着又传到了更高一级的地区。不久，“科尔蒙小姐回来了！”这句话就像炸弹一样轰动了各家各户。此刻，雅克兰正从马车前头他坐的木凳上下来（那木凳刨得非常光亮，恐怕连木匠都不知道是怎么弄成的）。他亲自打开绿色的大门。这门上部为圆形，举丧时一般闭着，因为科尔蒙小姐离开期间都没有举行过聚会。都是那些常客轮流在家设宴款待德斯蓬德神父。德瓦卢瓦先生还邀请神父到德埃斯格里尼翁侯爵家参加晚宴，算是还了人情。雅克兰打开大门后，亲切地呼唤珀涅罗珀进来，刚才他把珀泥罗珀停在马路中间。那牲口已经熟悉这程序了，于是自己动身进了大门，在院子里转圈，很小心地避免碰坏园中的花花草草。然后雅克兰拿起缰绳，把车赶到台阶前。
en: Immediately the town of Alencon, speedily informed from the farther end of the rue de Saint-Blaise to the gate of Seez of this precipitate return, accompanied by singular circumstances, was perturbed throughout its viscera, both public and domestic.Cooks, shopkeepers, street passengers, told the news from door to door; thence it rose to the upper regions.Soon the words “Mademoiselle Cormon has returned!” burst like a bombshell into all households.At that moment Jacquelin was descending from his wooden seat (polished by a process unknown to cabinet-makers), on which he perched in front of the carriole.He opened the great green gate, round at the top, and closed in sign of mourning; for during Mademoiselle Cormon’s absence the evening assemblies did not take place.The faithful invited the Abbe de Sponde to their several houses; and Monsieur de Valois paid his debt by inviting him to dine at the Marquis d’Esgrignon’s.Jacquelin, having opened the gate, called familiarly to Penelope, whom he had left in the middle of the street.That animal, accustomed to this proceeding, turned in of herself, and circled round the courtyard in a manner to avoid injuring the flower-bed.Jacquelin then took her bridle, and led the carriage to the portico.

zh: “玛丽埃特！”科尔蒙小姐喊道。
en: “Mariette!” cried Mademoiselle Cormon.

zh: “小姐！”玛丽埃特正在关门，回道。
en: “Mademoiselle!” exclaimed Mariette, who was occupied in closing the gate.

zh: “那位先生还没到吧？”
en: “Has the gentleman arrived?”

zh: “没呢，小姐。”
en: “No, mademoiselle.”

zh: “我舅舅在哪儿？”
en: “Where’s my uncle?”

zh: “他上教堂去了，小姐。”
en: “He is at church, mademoiselle.”

zh: 雅克兰和若赛特这时站在第一层台阶上，伸出手，扶着车，好让女主人出来。女主人一边抓着车门帘，一边踩着车辕。然后，她撑着他们的手臂下了车。在车上的脚蹬是两个铁环，用一个由笨重的大螺钉构成的糟糕机关固定在车辕上。但是这两年来，由于她的体重，她再也不敢冒险踩那个脚蹬子了。
en: Jacquelin and Josette were by this time on the first step of the portico, holding out their hands to manoeuvre the exit of their mistress from the carriole as she pulled herself up by the sides of the vehicle and clung to the curtains.Mademoiselle then threw herself into their arms; because for the last two years she dared not risk her weight on the iron step, affixed to the frame of the carriage by a horrible mechanism of clumsy bolts.

zh: 科尔蒙小姐站在台阶上后，满意地看了看她的庭院。
en: When Mademoiselle Cormon reached the level of the portico she looked about her courtyard with an air of satisfaction.

zh: “快来，快来，玛丽埃特，别管那大门了，我要你帮忙。”
en: “Come, come, Mariette, leave that gate alone; I want you.”

zh: “家里要出大事了。”玛丽埃特经过马车时，雅克兰悄悄对她说道。
en: “There’s something in the wind,” whispered Jacquelin, as Mariette passed the carriole.

zh: “玛丽埃特，家里有什么吃的？”科尔蒙小姐像是累坏了一样一屁股坐在前厅的长凳上，问道。
en: “Mariette, what provisions have you in the house?” asked Mademoiselle Cormon, sitting down on the bench in the long antechamber like a person overcome with fatigue.

zh: “我还没做什么呢，”玛丽埃特两手叉腰地说道，“小姐您知道的，您不在的时候，神父先生总是在外面吃饭。我昨天才把他从阿芒德小姐家接回来。”
en: “I haven’t anything,” replied Mariette, with her hands on her hips.“Mademoiselle knows very well that during her absence Monsieur l’abbe dines out every day.Yesterday I went to fetch him from Mademoiselle Armande’s.”

zh: “他现在在哪儿？”
en: “Where is he now?”

zh: “神父先生吗？哎，在教堂呢，他要三点钟才会回来。”
en: “Monsieur l’abbe?Why, at church; he won’t be in before three o’clock.”

zh: “他什么也不管！他应该叫你去市场的。玛丽埃特，快去吧。当然不要乱花钱，但也不要省着，去买些好吃的、精致的菜回来。去公共马车站那儿问问，看能不能弄到点肉糜，我还想要点儿亮河里的虾。现在几点了？”
en: "He thinks of nothing! He ought to have told you to go to market.Mariette, go at once; and without wasting money, don’t spare it; get all there is that is good and delicate.Go to the diligence office and see if you can send for pates; and I want shrimps from the Brillante.What o’clock is it?”

zh: “差一刻九点。”
en: “A quarter to nine.”

zh: “天哪，玛丽埃特，快别再唠唠叨叨呢。我舅舅说的那人说不定马上就到了。家里什么也没有，到时我们怎么给他做早饭呀？”
en: "Good heavens! Mariette, don’t stop to chatter.The person my uncle expects may arrive at any moment.If we had to give him breakfast, where should we be with nothing in the house?”

zh: 玛丽埃特朝浑身是汗的珀涅罗珀转过身去，看着雅克兰，似乎在说：“小姐这次总算要逮着一个丈夫了。”
en: Mariette turned back to Penelope in a lather, and looked at Jacquelin as if she would say, “Mademoiselle has put her hand on a husband THIS time.”

zh: “现在，若赛特，”老姑娘接着说，“我们一起看看安排德特雷维尔先生在哪儿睡觉吧。”
en: “Now, Josette,” continued the old maid, “let us see where we had better put Monsieur de Troisville to sleep.”

zh: 老姑娘说这句话的时候真是感觉幸福呀——“安排德特雷维尔先生睡觉。”这句话里包含了多少想法呀!老姑娘沐浴在希望之中。
en: With what joy she said the words, “Put Monsieur de Troisville” (pronounced Treville) “to sleep.”How many ideas in those few words!The old maid was bathed in hope.

zh: “您想安排他睡在那个绿色的房间吗？”
en: “Will you put him in the green chamber?”

zh: “主教的房间吗？不，那间离我的卧室太近了，”科尔蒙小姐说，“对主教阁下倒是很合适，他是一位圣人。”
en: “The bishop’s room?No; that’s too near mine,” said Mademoiselle Cormon.“All very well for monseigneur; he’s a saintly man.”

zh: “那让他住在您舅舅的房间吧。”
en: “Give him your uncle’s room.”

zh: “唉，里面太空了，没有什么家具，不大像样。”
en: “Oh, that’s so bare; it is actually indecent.”

zh: “那么，小姐，让人在您的小客厅里摆一张床吧？也不麻烦，而且那里还有火炉。莫罗的店里肯定能找到一张与那间屋子的帷幔相称的床。”
en: “Well, then, mademoiselle, why not arrange a bed in your boudoir?It is easily done; and there’s a fire-place.Moreau can certainly find in his warerooms a bed to match the hangings.”

zh: “很好，若赛特。你快到莫罗那儿去，跟他商量一下要做什么，需要什么你买就行。如果德特雷维尔先生到之前，莫罗能把床装好，或者他们同时到，但是莫罗可以不让德特雷维尔先生察觉而把床装好，我是愿意的。但如果莫罗不能保证，我就让德特雷维尔先生住在那间绿色的卧室里，虽然会离我的房间很近。”
en: “You are right, Josette.Go yourself to Moreau; consult with him what to do; I authorize you to get what is wanted.If the bed could be put up to-night without Monsieur de Troisville observing it (in case Monsieur de Troisville arrives while Moreau is here), I should like it.If Moreau won’t engage to do this, then I must put Monsieur de Troisville in the green room, although Monsieur de Troisville would be so very near to me.”

zh: 若赛特刚走没几步就又被女主人叫住了。
en: Josette was departing when her mistress recalled her.

zh: “等一下！把这件事向雅克兰解释清楚，”她紧张地大喊道，“让他到莫罗店里去，我还要换衣服呢！要是让德特雷维尔先生瞧见我这副模样就糟了！况且舅舅还没回来！
en: “Stop! Explain the matter to Jacquelin,” she cried, in a loud nervous tone.“Tell HIM to go to Moreau; I must be dressed!Fancy if Monsieur de Troisville surprised me as I am now! And my uncle not here to receive him!

zh: 啊呀，舅舅，舅舅！快来，若赛特，赶紧帮我换衣服吧。”
en: Oh, uncle, uncle!Come, Josette; come and dress me at once.”

zh: “但是珀涅罗珀怎么办？”若赛特不假思索地问道。
en: “But Penelope?” said Josette, imprudently.

zh: “总是珀涅罗珀！珀涅罗珀这个，珀涅罗珀那个！珀涅罗珀是家中的女主人吗？”
en: “Always Penelope!Penelope this, Penelope that!Is Penelope the mistress of this house?”

zh: “但她全身是汗呢，而且她还没有时间吃燕麦。”
en: “But she is all of a lather, and she hasn’t had time to eat her oats.”

zh: “那就让它饿死好了！”科尔蒙小姐大叫道，心想，“只要我能嫁人就行。”
en: “Then let her starve!” cried Mademoiselle Cormon; “provided I marry,” she thought to herself.

zh: 这句话对若赛特来说，无异于说杀人，顿时她目瞪口呆地站在那里，一动也不动。直到女主人向她打了一个手势，她才缓过神来，赶紧冲下台阶。
en: Hearing these words, which seemed to her like homicide, Josette stood still for a moment, speechless.Then, at a gesture from her mistress, she ran headlong down the steps of the portico.

zh: “小姐着魔了，雅克兰。”这是若赛特缓过神说的第一句话。
en: “The devil is in her, Jacquelin,” were the first words she uttered.

zh: 于是，这一天，所有一切都相互配合，产生出伟大的戏剧效果，决定了科尔蒙小姐未来的生活。伴随着科尔蒙小姐返回的有五件严重情况：一是倾盆大雨；二是珀涅罗珀飞奔回来，浑身是汗，精疲力竭；三是一大早的时刻；四是没有收拾好的包裹；五是那老小姐异常激动的表情。全城都因此而陷入一片混乱之中了。再看到玛丽埃特闯进市场，见什么好买什么；加上雅克兰来到距离教堂两步远的赛镇门大街，到阿郎松城里主要的软垫家具店里要买一张床的时候，大家都觉得事态严重了。大家都在到处谈论和琢磨这些事，它们已经占据了每个人的脑海，甚至包括阿芒德小姐，当时她正和德瓦卢瓦先生在一起。前后也就两天的时间，阿郎松城受到如此重大事件的连续冲击，以至于有几位善良的女士说世界末日就要到了。然而，这条消息最后都归为一个问题——“科尔蒙家到底发生什么事了？”
en: Thus all things conspired on this fateful day to produce the great scenic effect which decided the future life of Mademoiselle Cormon.The town was already topsy-turvy in mind, as a consequence of the five extraordinary circumstances which accompanied Mademoiselle Cormon’s return; to wit, the pouring rain; Penelope at a gallop, in a lather, and blown; the early hour; the parcels half-packed; and the singular air of the excited old maid.But when Mariette made an invasion of the market, and bought all the best things; when Jacquelin went to the principal upholsterer in Alencon, two doors from the church, in search of a bed,—there was matter for the gravest conjectures.These extraordinary events were discussed on all sides; they occupied the minds of every one, even Mademoiselle Armande herself, with whom was Monsieur de Valois.Within two days the town of Alencon had been agitated by such startling events that certain good women were heard to remark that the world was coming to an end.This last news, however, resolved itself into a single question, “What is happening at the Cormons?”

zh: 德斯蓬德神父走出圣莱奥纳尔教堂时，本打算和库蒂里耶神父一起去散步，这时有人很机智地打探消息，于是他以惯常的友好态度告诉对方，他正等待着德特雷维尔子爵驾到。这位子爵曾在流放期间为俄国服务，现在要回阿郎松定居。于是从下午两点到五点，全城都在以嘴唇散布电报。所有的居民都知道科尔蒙小姐通过书信终于找到一个丈夫，并且她就要嫁给德特雷维尔子爵了。有人说：“莫罗已经卖给他们一张床呢。”在那片地方，传言说那张床有六尺宽；在羊圈街，格朗松太太家，说那张床是四尺宽；迪布斯基耶正在迪隆斯雷家吃饭，在那里，有人说，只不过是张简单的沙发床而已。小布尔乔亚们说那床花了有一千一百法郎。但是大家普遍都在想，现在高兴未免为时过早吧。另几处地方，有人说玛丽埃特把市场上的东西抢购一空，以至于鲤鱼的价格都上涨了。在圣布莱兹街尾，大家说珀涅罗珀已经累死了。在税务局长家里，虽然大家不相信珀涅罗珀死了，但是在这一地区已经证实说这牲口在一拐进科尔蒙公馆庭院时就咽气了，因为科尔蒙小姐飞一般地想见她的丈夫，一直叫它狂奔快跑。赛镇大街拐角上的鞍具商，壮着胆子来打听是不是科尔蒙小姐的马车出问题了，以了解珀涅罗珀是不是真的死了。从圣布莱兹街头到羊圈街尾，大家终于得知，幸亏有雅克兰的精心护理，珀涅罗珀这个无辜受女主人迫害的牲口还活着，不过看上去是有点问题。
en: The Abbe de Sponde, adroitly questioned when he left Saint-Leonard’s to take his daily walk with the Abbe Couturier, replied with his usual kindliness that he expected the Vicomte de Troisville, a nobleman in the service of Russia during the Emigration, who was returning to Alencon to settle there.From two to five o’clock a species of labial telegraphy went on throughout the town; and all the inhabitants learned that Mademoiselle Cormon had at last found a husband by letter, and was about to marry the Vicomte de Troisville.Some said, “Moreau has sold them a bed.”The bed was six feet wide in that quarter; it was four feet wide at Madame Granson’s, in the rue du Bercail; but it was reduced to a simple couch at Monsieur du Ronceret’s, where du Bousquier was dining.The lesser bourgeoisie declared that the cost was eleven hundred francs.But generally it was thought that, as to this, rumor was counting the chickens before they were hatched.In other quarters it was said that Mariette had made such a raid on the market that the price of carp had risen.At the end of the rue Saint-Blaise, Penelope had dropped dead.This decease was doubted in the house of the receiver-general; but at the Prefecture it was authenticated that the poor beast had expired as she turned into the courtyard of the hotel Cormon, with such velocity had the old maid flown to meet her husband.The harness-maker, who lived at the corner of the rue de Seez, was bold enough to call at the house and ask if anything had happened to Mademoiselle Cormon’s carriage, in order to discover whether Penelope was really dead.From the end of the rue Saint-Blaise to the end of the rue du Bercail, it was then made known that, thanks to Jacquelin’s devotion, Penelope, that silent victim of her mistress’s impetuosity, still lived, though she seemed to be suffering.

zh: 整个布列塔尼大道上，大家都说，德特雷维尔子爵是家中幼子，一文不名，因为佩尔舍的财产都归他哥哥德特雷维尔侯爵所有。德特雷维尔侯爵是法国贵族院议员，有孩子。因此这桩婚事真是便宜了那个流亡国外的可怜人。而布列塔尼大道上的贵族都赞成这桩婚事，说科尔蒙小姐的财产实在不能派上再好的用场了。但是在市民阶层，大家说德特雷维尔子爵是曾与法国作战的俄国将军，他这次归来带了大笔在圣彼得堡宫廷中赚来的财富；大家还说他是自由党痛恨的外国人；有人说，是德斯蓬德神父暗中撮合了这件婚事。凡是有权去拜访科尔蒙小姐的人，都决定今晚去看她。
en: Along the road to Brittany the Vicomte de Troisville was stated to be a younger son without a penny, for the estates in Perche belonged to the Marquis de Troisville, peer of France, who had children; the marriage would be, therefore, an enormous piece of luck for a poor emigre.The aristocracy along that road approved of the marriage; Mademoiselle Cormon could not do better with her money.But among the Bourgeoisie, the Vicomte de Troisville was a Russian general who had fought against France, and was now returning with a great fortune made at the court of Saint-Petersburg; he was a FOREIGNER; one of those ALLIES so hated by the liberals; the Abbe de Sponde had slyly negotiated this marriage.All the persons who had a right to call upon Mademoiselle Cormon determined to do so that very evening.

zh: 这震动全城的事情，让人几乎忘了苏珊的事。科尔蒙小姐的激动也不亚于其他人，她充满了全新的情感。她望着她的大客厅、饭厅和小客厅，突然一种恐惧感涌上心头。一种类似魔鬼的东西在嘲笑她这些过时的奢侈品。这些她从小欣赏的漂亮什物突然让她觉得是不是过于陈旧和可笑了。简而言之，她感受到了几乎所有作家都经历过的那种恐惧，每当非常严格或是感觉麻木的批评家读自己的新作品时，即使他们以为自己的作品很完美了，但还是忐忑不安。原本是全新的情景，现在觉得很老套；原本是表述很漂亮、精雕细琢的词句，现在觉得无力而偏颇了；比喻和形象都变得具有嘲讽意味而且互相矛盾；文中的错误变得十分显眼。同样，这可怜的老姑娘很害怕德特雷维尔先生见了这间主教客厅，嘴唇上会掠过轻蔑的一笑；她害怕他会冷冷地看着这古老的饭厅；总之，她害怕那镜框会让那肖像画变得老气。要是这些古董使她也显得苍老了怎么办？这个问题让她浑身起鸡皮疙瘩。这时候，如果有魔棒可以将她的房屋瞬间装修一新，就算要花去她的一半积蓄她也愿意。哪个将军在临上战场时，不曾发抖过呢？这个可怜的姑娘现在就是处在她的奥斯特利兹战役和滑铁卢战役中。
en: During this transurban excitement, which made that of Suzanne almost a forgotten affair, Mademoiselle was not less agitated; she was filled with a variety of novel emotions.Looking about her salon, dining-room, and boudoir, cruel apprehensions took possession of her.A species of demon showed her with a sneer her old-fashioned luxury.The handsome things she had admired from her youth up she suddenly suspected of age and absurdity.In short, she felt that fear which takes possession of nearly all authors when they read over a work they have hitherto thought proof against every exacting or blase critic: new situations seem timeworn; the best-turned and most highly polished phrases limp and squint; metaphors and images grin or contradict each other; whatsoever is false strikes the eye.In like manner this poor woman trembled lest she should see on the lips of Monsieur de Troisville a smile of contempt for this episcopal salon; she dreaded the cold look he might cast over that ancient dining-room; in short, she feared the frame might injure and age the portrait.Suppose these antiquities should cast a reflected light of old age upon herself?This question made her flesh creep.She would gladly, at that moment, spend half her savings on refitting her house if some fairy wand could do it in a moment.Where is the general who has not trembled on the eve of a battle?The poor woman was now between her Austerlitz and her Waterloo.

zh: “德特雷维尔子爵夫人，”她自言自语道，“多高贵的名字呀！至少我们的财产落入好人家了。”
en: “Madame la Vicomtesse de Troisville,” she said to herself; “a noble name!Our property will go to a good family, at any rate.”

zh: 她完全处在心烦意乱中，每一束最细微的神经和深埋在她的肥肉中的神经末梢都在颤抖。这新的希望加快了她的血液循环。她觉得，如果有必要的话，她自己还有足够的精力和德特雷维尔先生谈话。
en: She fell a prey to an irritation which made every fibre of her nerves quiver to all their papillae, long sunk in flesh.Her blood, lashed by this new hope, was in motion.She felt the strength to converse, if necessary, with Monsieur de Troisville.

zh: 至于若赛特、雅克兰、玛丽埃特、莫罗和他的助手在怎样紧张地张罗着，就不用赘述了。他们就和蚂蚁运卵一样紧张。平时仔细打理和收拾过的东西，全都重新洗过，刷过，熨过，擦过。盛大节日使用的瓷器，又摆出来重见天日了；绣着A、B、C的缎纹餐巾，平时包裹三层，还用排排别针护着，现在也从柜子深处给请出来了。最后，科尔蒙小姐在她希望的祭坛上奉献出三瓶昂伏夫人的名酒，这可是热带地区最著名的酿酒商，对嗜酒者来说这是十分亲切的名字。多亏小姐手下的副官们竭诚效力，科尔蒙小姐才得以很快为这场战斗做好准备。各种武器——家具装备，厨房炮兵，储备粮，总之，战争需要的各种军需品以及后备队——都已全线备齐。雅克兰、玛丽埃特和若赛特收到命令，都要穿上礼服。花园也已耙平整了。老姑娘就遗憾不懂鸟语，不能和栖息在树上的夜莺商量，让它们到时献上最美妙的歌声。
en: It is useless to relate the activity with which Josette, Jacquelin, Mariette, Moreau, and his agents went about their functions.It was like the busyness of ants about their eggs.All that daily care had already rendered neat and clean was again gone over and brushed and rubbed and scrubbed.The china of ceremony saw the light; the damask linen marked “A, B, C” was drawn from depths where it lay under a triple guard of wrappings, still further defended by formidable lines of pins.Above all, Mademoiselle Cormon sacrificed on the altar of her hopes three bottles of the famous liqueurs of Madame Amphoux, the most illustrious of all the distillers of the tropics,—a name very dear to gourmets.Thanks to the devotion of her lieutenants, mademoiselle was soon ready for the conflict.The different weapons—furniture, cookery, provisions, in short, all the various munitions of war, together with a body of reserve forces—were ready along the whole line.Jacquelin, Mariette, and Josette received orders to appear in full dress.The garden was raked.The old maid regretted that she couldn’t come to an understanding with the nightingales nesting in the trees, in order to obtain their finest trilling.

zh: 四点钟左右，德斯蓬德神父刚回到家，而小姐已开始怀疑她这最精美的晚餐和最精美的餐具都白白准备了。就在这时，终于从瓦诺布勒传来了马车夫甩鞭子的噼啪声。
en: At last, about four o’clock, at the very moment when the Abbe de Sponde returned home, and just as mademoiselle began to think she had set the table with the best plate and linen and prepared the choicest dishes to no purpose, the click-clack of a postilion was heard in the Val-Noble.

zh: “是他！”小姐心想，那每一鞭都抽在她的心上。
en: “‘Tis he!” she said to herself, the snap of the whip echoing in her heart.

zh: 果然，一辆从驿站雇的带蓬双轮轻便马车到了，车上只坐了一位先生。虽然各种流言蜚语都宣告了这辆车的到来，但当马车沿圣布莱兹街下到林阴大道上时，还是轰动了全城，以至于几个顽童和大人跟着车前进，聚在科尔蒙公馆大门附近，看着马车进入公馆。雅克兰从小姐的婚事中看到了自己的婚期，他也听到圣布莱兹街上的鞭声，把庭院的两扇大门大大敞开。那马车夫是他的朋友，只见他很得意地一个漂亮的拐弯，将马车拐进大门，停在台阶的前面。神父上前迎接他的客人，车上的东西转眼间就被卸完了，仿佛路上的强盗干得一般；马车停进车棚，大门关闭，就这么一会儿功夫，德特雷维尔先生到来的所有痕迹都消失了。任何两种化学物质相混合的速度，也比不上科尔蒙家将德特雷维尔子爵吸收进门的速度了。
en: True enough; heralded by all this gossip, a post-chaise, in which was a single gentleman, made so great a sensation coming down the rue Saint-Blaise and turning into the rue du Cours that several little gamains and some grown persons followed it, and stood in groups about the gate of the hotel Cormon to see it enter.Jacquelin, who foresaw his own marriage in that of his mistress, had also heard the click-clack in the rue Saint-Blaise, and had opened wide the gates into the courtyard.The postilion, a friend of his, took pride in making a fine turn-in, and drew up sharply before the portico.The abbe came forward to greet his guest, whose carriage was emptied with a speed that highwaymen might put into the operation; the chaise itself was rolled into the coach-house, the gates closed, and in a few moments all signs of Monsieur de Troisville’s arrival had disappeared.Never did two chemicals blend into each other with greater rapidity than the hotel Cormon displayed in absorbing the Vicomte de Troisville.

zh: 科尔蒙小姐的心脏跳得像个被牧童抓住的蜥蜴一样，但是她颇有英雄气概地坐在炉火旁边的安乐椅上。若赛特打开客厅的门，德特雷维尔子爵走在德斯蓬德神父的前面，出现在老姑娘的眼前。
en: Mademoiselle, whose heart was beating like a lizard caught by a herdsman, sat heroically still on her sofa, beside the fire in the salon.Josette opened the door; and the Vicomte de Troisville, followed by the Abbe de Sponde, presented himself to the eyes of the spinster.

zh: “外甥女，这是德特雷维尔子爵先生，我中学时代的老同学的孙子；德特雷维尔先生，这是我的外甥女科尔蒙小姐。“
en: “Niece, this is Monsieur le Vicomte de Troisville, the grandson of one of my old schoolmates; Monsieur de Troisville, my niece, Mademoiselle Cormon.”

zh: “哇，真是好舅舅，他互相介绍得真好呀！”罗丝—玛丽—维克图瓦心想。
en: “Ah! That good uncle; how well he does it!” thought Rose-Marie-Victoire.

zh: 要一句话描绘出德特雷维尔子爵的话，可以说，他是贵族化了的迪布斯基耶。这两人的全部区别，就在于庸俗和高雅之分。如果他们俩站在一起，恐怕就是最狂乱的自由党也无法否认贵族的优越。子爵的力量就在于他具备高雅的全部特点，他的举止保持着高度的贵族尊严。他有一双蓝眼睛，深色头发，橄榄色的皮肤，看上去四十六岁左右。你会认为他就是一位在俄国的冰雪中保存完好的西班牙美男子。他的举止、他的风度，都说明他是一位见识过整个欧洲的外交家。他的穿着正是一位很体面的旅者的装束。他看上去很疲倦，于是神父建议带他到为他准备的房间休息一下。当外甥女打开已经改装成卧室的小客厅的房门时，神父都惊呆了。
en: The Vicomte de Troisville was, to paint him in two words, du Bousquier ennobled.Between the two men there was precisely the difference which separates the vulgar style from the noble style.If they had both been present, the most fanatic liberal would not have denied the existence of aristocracy.The viscount’s strength had all the distinction of elegance; his figure had preserved its magnificent dignity.He had blue eyes, black hair, an olive skin, and looked to be about forty-six years of age.You might have thought him a handsome Spaniard preserved in the ice of Russia.His manner, carriage, and attitude, all denoted a diplomat who had seen Europe.His dress was that of a well-bred traveller.As he seemed fatigued, the abbe offered to show him to his room, and was much amazed when his niece threw open the door of the boudoir, transformed into a bedroom.

zh: 科尔蒙小姐和她的舅父于是走开，让这位尊贵的客人在雅克兰的帮助下去收拾自己的物品。雅克兰将他的行李一一送过来，而德斯蓬德神父和外甥女则沿着亮河去散步，等待他们的客人梳洗完毕。碰巧今天德斯蓬德神父比平时更加心不在焉，科尔蒙小姐这时也心事重重。他们俩都默默地走着。这老姑娘从未见过比这位严肃又恬静的子爵更具有诱惑力的男人。她大概会像德国人那样想：“这正是我想要的！”但是她感到从头到脚都被慑服了，而只能说：“我的爱情来了！”然后，她飞奔到玛丽埃特那询问，能不能让晚餐推后一点，但又不影响饭菜的味道。
en: Mademoiselle Cormon and her uncle then left the noble stranger to attend to his own affairs, aided by Jacquelin, who brought up his luggage, and went themselves to walk beside the river until their guest had made his toilet.Although the Abbe de Sponde chanced to be even more absent-minded than usual, Mademoiselle Cormon was not less preoccupied.They both walked on in silence.The old maid had never before met any man as seductive as this Olympean viscount.She might have said to herself, as the Germans do, “This is my ideal!” instead of which she felt herself bound from head to foot, and could only say, “Here’s my affair!”Then she flew to Mariette to know if the dinner could be put back a while without loss of excellence.

zh: “舅舅，这位德特雷维尔先生非常和蔼可亲呀。”她回来后说道。
en: “Uncle, your Monsieur de Troisville is very amiable,” she said, on returning.

zh: “可是，外甥女，他还没说过一句话呢。”
en: “Why, niece, he hasn’t as yet said a word.”

zh: “但是可以从他的行为、举止和外貌上看出来呀。他是单身吗？”
en: “But you can see it in his ways, his manners, his face.Is he a bachelor?”

zh: “我还真不知道，”神父回答道，心里正想着最近他和库蒂里耶神父关于上帝的仁慈问题的争论，“德特雷维尔先生给我写信说他想在这里买套房子。如果他结婚了，应该不会一个人前来吧。”神父毫不在意地加上一句，压根没想到他的外甥女在想着嫁人呢。
en: “I’m sure I don’t know,” replied the abbe, who was thinking of a discussion on mercy, lately begun between the Abbe Couturier and himself.“Monsieur de Troisville wrote me that he wanted to buy a house here.If he was married, he wouldn’t come alone on such an errand,” added the abbe, carelessly, not conceiving the idea that his niece could be thinking of marriage.

zh: “他很有钱吗？”
en: “Is he rich?”

zh: “他是幼支的幼子，”神父回答道，“他的祖父曾统帅海军舰队，但是这个年轻人他父亲的婚姻却很不好。”
en: “He is a younger son of the younger branch,” replied her uncle.“His grandfather commanded a squadron, but the father of this young man made a bad marriage.”

zh: “年轻人！”老姑娘重复道，“可是，舅舅，我觉得他至少四十五岁了！”她有强烈的欲望要让他们两人的年纪相当才行。
en: “Young man!” exclaimed the old maid.“It seems to me, uncle, that he must be at least forty-five.”She felt the strongest desire to put their years on a par.

zh: “是的，”神父说，“但是对于一个已经七十岁的可怜的神父看来，罗丝，一个四十岁的人还很年轻呢。”
en: “Yes,” said the abbe; “but to a poor priest of seventy, Rose, a man of forty seems a youth.”

zh: 此刻阿郎松全城都已经知道，德特雷维尔子爵先生已经到达科尔蒙小姐家。这位旅行家不久便前来和家中主人会齐，开始欣赏亮河的景色、花园和房屋。
en: All Alencon knew by this time that Monsieur de Troisville had arrived at the Cormons.The traveller soon rejoined his hosts, and began to admire the Brillante, the garden, and the house.

zh: “神父先生，”他说，“我全部的雄心就是要找一处像这栋房屋一样的住宅。”老姑娘听了这句话，以为是向她求爱了，于是垂下眼帘。“小姐在这里生活，一定很开心吧。”子爵又说道。
en: “Monsieur l’abbe,” he said, “my whole ambition is to have a house like this.”The old maid fancied a declaration lurked in that speech, and she lowered her eyes.“You must enjoy it very much, mademoiselle,” added the viscount.

zh: “我怎么能不开心呢？这所住宅从一五七四年就属于我们家。那年，我们的一位祖先，阿郎松公爵的总管得到了这块地，并建造了这所房屋。”科尔蒙小姐说。“这房屋是用支柱架空的。”她补充道。
en: “How could it be otherwise?It has been in our family since 1574, the period at which one of our ancestors, steward to the Duc d’Alencon, acquired the land and built the house,” replied Mademoiselle Cormon.“It is built on piles,” she added.

zh: 雅克兰宣布晚饭准备好了。德特雷维尔先生将手臂伸给兴高采烈的老姑娘，老姑娘尽量不紧靠在那手臂上，依然像往常一样担心会造成自己主动追求的感觉。
en: Jacquelin announced dinner.Monsieur de Troisville offered his arm to the happy woman, who endeavored not to lean too heavily upon it; she feared, as usual, to seem to make advances.

zh: “这里的一切都很和谐。”子爵在餐桌前就座时说道。
en: “Everything is so harmonious here,” said the viscount, as he seated himself at table.

zh: “是呀，我们的树林里都是小鸟，给我们免费演奏音乐；没有人会去惊扰它们；夜莺们每晚都歌唱。”科尔蒙小姐说。
en: “Yes, our trees are full of birds, which give us concerts for nothing; no one ever frightens them; and the nightingales sing at night,” said Mademoiselle Cormon.

zh: “我是说室内的布置呢。”子爵说，他根本没有费心去观察科尔蒙小姐，也因此没有发现她的愚昧。“所有的一切都很相称，色彩的搭配、家具以及总的格调。”
en: “I was speaking of the interior of the house,” remarked the viscount, who did not trouble himself to observe Mademoiselle Cormon, and therefore did not perceive the dulness of her mind.“Everything is so in keeping,—the tones of color, the furniture, the general character.”

zh: “但是我们可花了不少钱呢，税额太高了。”这了不起的老姑娘回答道。
en: “But it costs a great deal; taxes are enormous,” responded the excellent woman.

zh: “啊？这个地方税额很高吗？”子爵说，一心想着自己的事。
en: “Ah! Taxes are high, are they?” said the viscount, preoccupied with his own ideas.

zh: “我不知道，”神父回答,“都是我的外甥女管理我们的产业。”
en: “I don’t know,” replied the abbe.“My niece manages the property of each of us.”

zh: “对于有钱人来说，交税不算什么啦。”科尔蒙小姐说，不想让对方认为她很吝啬，“至于家具，我一直保持原样，不做变动。除非我结婚，那就另当别论了，这里的一切都得符合男主人的口味。”
en: “Taxes are not of much importance to the rich,” said Mademoiselle Cormon, not wishing to be thought miserly.“As for the furniture, I shall leave it as it is, and change nothing,—unless I marry; and then, of course, everything here must suit the husband.”

zh: “您的原则很明确呀，小姐，”子爵微笑着说，“您一定会让男人幸福的。”
en: “You have noble principles, mademoiselle,” said the viscount, smiling.“You will make one happy man.”

zh: “从没有人对我说过这么动听的话。”老姑娘心想。
en: “No one ever made to me such a pretty speech,” thought the old maid.

zh: 子爵称赞科尔蒙小姐招待周到，家里的摆设也让人赏心悦目，说自己原以为外省很落后，现在发现外省像英国人说的一样——“非常舒适”。
en: The viscount complimented Mademoiselle Cormon on the excellence of her service and the admirable arrangements of the house, remarking that he had supposed the provinces behind the age in that respect; but, on the contrary, he found them, as the English say, “very comfortable.”

zh: “这个英语词什么意思呀？”她心想，“哦，骑士在的话就能告诉我了，可他在哪儿呢？‘Comfortable’——听上去好像不止一个词啊。算了，勇敢些！”她暗想道。“我可不能回答外语，但是，”她高声接下去，就像任何人在重要场合都会变得能说会道一样，她也感觉话匣子打开了，说道，“先生，我们这里有最优秀的社交团体。全城的人都在我家聚会，您今晚就能了解到了。我们的一些朋友们知道我回来了，您来了，他们肯定会来看我的。他们当中有德瓦卢瓦骑士，他是过去的宫廷贵人，有着无穷的机智和高品位；还有德埃斯格里尼翁侯爵和他的妹妹阿芒德小姐（她不安地咬了下自己的舌头），她是一个很特别的高贵的姑娘。”她补充道，“她甘愿终身不嫁，以便将她所有的财产留给她的哥哥和她的侄子。”
en: “What can that word mean?” she thought.“Oh, where is the chevalier to explain it to me?‘Comfortable,’—there seem to be several words in it.Well, courage!” she said to herself.“I can’t be expected to answer a foreign language—But,” she continued aloud, feeling her tongue untied by the eloquence which nearly all human creatures find in momentous circumstances, “we have a very brilliant society here, monsieur.It assembles at my house, and you shall judge of it this evening, for some of my faithful friends have no doubt heard of my return and your arrival.Among them is the Chevalier de Valois, a seigneur of the old court, a man of infinite wit and taste; then there is Monsieur le Marquis d’Esgrignon and Mademoiselle Armande, his sister” (she bit her tongue with vexation),—“a woman remarkable in her way,” she added.“She resolved to remain unmarried in order to leave all her fortune to her brother and nephew.”

zh: “啊！”子爵说道，“是呀，德埃斯格里尼翁家，我记得他们。”
en: “Ah!” exclaimed the viscount.“Yes, the d’Esgrignons,—I remember them.”

zh: “阿郎松是个很快活的地方，”老姑娘一发不可收拾地接着说道，“在这儿有很多消遣，税务局长会举办舞会，省长非常和蔼可亲，主教大人还会时不时地光临寒舍——”
en: “Alencon is very gay,” continued the old maid, now fairly launched.“There’s much amusement: the receiver-general gives balls; the prefect is an amiable man; and Monseigneur the bishop sometimes honors us with a visit—”

zh: “啊，这样看来，”子爵微笑地说道，“我选择回到这里，落叶归根是很明智的啦。”
en: “Well, then,” said the viscount, smiling, “I have done wisely to come back, like the hare, to die in my form.”

zh: “是的，”她说道，“我也是，要一直呆在这里，不然就会死掉。”
en: “Yes,” she said.“I, too, attach myself or I die.”

zh: 子爵笑了笑。
en: The viscount smiled.

zh: “啊！”老姑娘心想，“一切都很顺利，他能理解我。”
en: “Ah!” thought the old maid, “all is well; he understands me.”

zh: 接下去，谈话转入一般的话题。受到一股神秘的、莫名的、叫不上名字的强大力量的影响，科尔蒙小姐拼命搜索脑中德瓦卢瓦骑士的各种句式，好让自己显得可爱。这就像在一场决斗中，似乎魔鬼亲自给你调好了手枪一样。从来就没有这么准地瞄准过对手。子爵出身高贵，因此不会说些赞美话来表示晚餐的鲜美，但是他的沉默就等于一种赞扬。雅克兰给他斟上一杯又一杯的美酒，他感觉像旧友重逢，不亦乐乎；因为真正的鉴赏家不会鼓掌，而是静静地品味享受。他询问了地皮、房产和庄园的价格；他让科尔蒙小姐详细地描述了亮河与萨尔特河汇合处的情形。对于城市建在距离河流这样远的地方，他感到很奇怪，似乎他很关心当地的地形。
en: The conversation continued on generalities.By one of those mysterious unknown and undefinable faculties, Mademoiselle Cormon found in her brain, under the pressure of her desire to be agreeable, all the phrases and opinions of the Chevalier de Valois.It was like a duel in which the devil himself pointed the pistol.Never was any adversary better aimed at.The viscount was far too well-bred to speak of the excellence of the dinner; but his silence was praise.As he drank the delicious wines which Jacquelin served to him profusely, he seemed to feel he was with friends, and to meet them with pleasure; for the true connoisseur does not applaud, he enjoys.He inquired the price of land, of houses, of estates; he made Mademoiselle Cormon describe at length the confluence of the Sarthe and the Brillante; he expressed surprise that the town was placed so far from the river, and seemed to be much interested in the topography of the place.

zh: 沉默的神父任由他的外甥女主导谈话，并且科尔蒙小姐也认为她已经占据了德特雷维尔先生的心，因为对方频频向她亲切地微笑。他在晚餐过程中作出的保证，比她最殷勤的追求者十天内作出的保证还多得多。因此，各位可以想见这位先生受到的无微不至的关怀，就像是一位心爱的夫君回到了家中，给家中带来了欢乐。科尔蒙小姐留心估计子爵什么时候要面包；她观察他每一个眼神；当他扭头的时候，她便巧妙地给他盛上看上去他喜欢的菜。如果他是个贪吃的人，她早就把他撑死了。但是，她倒是很好地表现了一个丈夫所欣赏的女人该有的本领。她没有做贬低自己的蠢事，相反，她大胆地张开了所有的船帆，挂上所有旗号，摆出阿郎松女王的架势，吹嘘自己的果酱做得有多好。事实上，她是靠大谈自己来捞取恭维。她发现自己很讨子爵的喜欢，热切的希望使她完全改变了模样，让她几乎成了一个女人。
en: The silent abbe left his niece to throw the dice of conversation; and she truly felt that she pleased Monsieur de Troisville, who smiled at her gracefully, and committed himself during this dinner far more than her most eager suitors had ever done in ten days.Imagine, therefore, the little attentions with which he was petted; you might have thought him a cherished lover, whose return brought joy to the household.Mademoiselle foresaw the moment when the viscount wanted bread; she watched his every look; when he turned his head she adroitly put upon his plate a portion of some dish he seemed to like; had he been a gourmand, she would almost have killed him; but what a delightful specimen of the attentions she would show to a husband!She did not commit the folly of depreciating herself; on the contrary, she set every sail bravely, ran up all her flags, assumed the bearing of the queen of Alencon, and boasted of her excellent preserves.In fact, she fished for compliments in speaking of herself, for she saw that she pleased the viscount; the truth being that her eager desire had so transformed her that she became almost a woman.

zh: 上甜点的时候，她满心欢喜地听到前厅和客厅的声响，说明她的那些常客已经来了。她让她舅舅和德特雷维尔先生注意到常客们的殷勤来访，因为这是人们爱戴她的一个证明。而实际上，大家是因为受这袭扰全城的强烈好奇心驱使而来的。科尔蒙小姐迫不及待地要满载荣誉地出现在人们面前，于是吩咐雅克兰去到客厅里给客人上咖啡和烈酒。在客厅里，仆人可以在社交界的精华面前，炫耀一下萨克森咖啡具的气派，这套咖啡具一年只从柜子里取出来使用两次。人们都注意到这情形，已经站在那里开始小声议论了。
en: At dessert she heard, not without emotions of delight, certain sounds in the antechamber and salon which denoted the arrival of her usual guests.She called the attention of her uncle and Monsieur de Troisville to this prompt attendance as a proof of the affection that was felt for her; whereas it was really the result of the poignant curiosity which had seized upon the town.Impatient to show herself in all her glory, Mademoiselle Cormon told Jacquelin to serve coffee and liqueurs in the salon, where he presently set out, in view of the whole company, a magnificent liqueur-stand of Dresden china which saw the light only twice a year.This circumstance was taken note of by the company, standing ready to gossip over the merest trifle:—

zh: “有什么了不起！”迪布斯基耶喃喃自语道，“事实上，他们一年四大节日才会上昂伏夫人的烈性酒！”
en: “The deuce!” muttered du Bousquier.“Actually Madame Amphoux’s liqueurs, which they only serve at the four church festivals!”

zh: “这件婚事肯定是一年前通过书信安排好的，”法院院长迪龙瑟雷先生说，“邮政局长告诉我这一年多来经常收到盖有敖德萨邮戳的信。”
en: “Undoubtedly the marriage was arranged a year ago by letter,” said the chief-justice du Ronceret.“The postmaster tells me his office has received letters postmarked Odessa for more than a year.”

zh: 格朗松太太浑身都震颤了。德瓦卢瓦骑士虽然吃了相当于四个人的饭，但这会儿连左半边脸都发白了。感到自己内心的秘密就要泄露出去，他仓促地说道：
en: Madame Granson trembled.The Chevalier de Valois, though he had dined with the appetite of four men, turned pale even to the left section of his face.Feeling that he was about to betray himself, he said hastily,—

zh: “您不觉得今天特别冷吗？我都快要冻僵了。”
en: “Don’t you think it is very cold to-day?I am almost frozen.”

zh: “也许是因为在俄国附近的缘故吧。”迪布斯基耶说。
en: “The neighborhood of Russia, perhaps,” said du Bousquier.

zh: 骑士看了他一眼，似乎在说：“说得太妙了！”
en: The chevalier looked at him as if to say, “Well played!”

zh: 科尔蒙小姐出现了，她是那么精神焕发，那么得意，让大家都觉得她变漂亮了。这不同寻常的神采不仅是由于感情的影响。自早晨起，她浑身的血液就在她体内沸腾，对于某种重大危机的预感一直在刺激着她的神经。得同时出现所有这些情况，她才会变得如此判若两人。她怀着无比幸福的心情郑重其事地将子爵介绍给骑士，再将骑士介绍给子爵，并将全体阿郎松人都介绍给德特雷维尔先生，并将德特雷维尔先生介绍给全体阿郎松人！
en: Mademoiselle Cormon appeared so radiant, so triumphant, that the company thought her handsome.This extraordinary brilliancy was not the effect of sentiment only.Since early morning her blood had been whirling tempestuously within her, and her nerves were agitated by the presentiment of some great crisis.It required all these circumstances combined to make her so unlike herself.With what joy did she now make her solemn presentation of the viscount to the chevalier, the chevalier to the viscount, and all Alencon to Monsieur de Troisville, and Monsieur de Troisville to all Alencon!

zh: 出于完全可以理解的偶然，子爵和骑士这两个具有贵族本性的人，相见后一拍即合，他们互相认出了同类。于是，两人便站在壁炉前畅聊起来。他们四周围了一圈人，虽然他们说话的声音很低，但是大家都在屏住气息听他们谈话。为了很好地展现出这个场面的效果，有必要以剧本的形式描述一下。科尔蒙小姐当时正背对着壁炉，忙着为他所谓的求婚者上咖啡。
en: By an accident wholly explainable, the viscount and chevalier, aristocrats by nature, came instantly into unison; they recognized each other at once as men belonging to the same sphere.Accordingly, they began to converse together, standing before the fireplace.A circle formed around them; and their conversation, though uttered in a low voice, was listened to in religious silence.To give the effect of this scene it is necessary to dramatize it, and to picture Mademoiselle Cormon occupied in pouring out the coffee of her imaginary suitor, with her back to the fireplace.

zh: 德瓦卢瓦先生：“听说子爵先生是来此地定居的，是吗？”
en: Monsieur de Valois.“Monsieur le vicomte has come, I am told, to settle in Alencon?”

zh: 德特雷维尔先生：“是的，先生，我正在找房子。（科尔蒙小姐端着咖啡杯转过身来。）得要找间大房子才行，（科尔蒙小姐向他递过杯子）这样才能安置我的家属。”（老姑娘顿时两眼发花。）
en: Monsieur de Troisville.“Yes, monsieur, I am looking for a house.”(Mademoiselle Cormon, cup in hand, turns round.) “It must be a large house” (Mademoiselle Cormon offers him the cup) “to lodge my whole family.”(The eyes of the old maid are troubled.)

zh: 德瓦卢瓦先生：“您已经成婚了？”
en: Monsieur de Valois.“Are you married?”

zh: 德特雷维尔先生：“是呀，已经结婚十六年了，内人是赛布洛夫公主的女儿。”
en: Monsieur de Troisville.“Yes, for the last sixteen years, to a daughter of the Princess Scherbellof.”

zh: 科尔蒙小姐顿时昏倒了；迪布斯基耶见她站不稳，立即上前将她抱住；有人将门打开，好让他将这个庞然大物抱出去。这个脾气暴躁的共和党使出浑身的劲来，在若赛特的指引下，将老姑娘抱到她的卧室里，放到她的床上。若赛特带了剪刀来，将束得紧紧的紧身衣剪开。迪布斯基耶往科尔蒙小姐脸上和身上洒水。紧身衣解开后，小姐身上的肉就像卢瓦尔河发大水一样摊开来。可怜的姑娘睁开眼睛，看见迪布斯基耶，女性的羞耻之心使她看到男人后立即发出一声叫喊。迪布斯基耶赶紧退出卧室，留下六位女士照顾她，为首的是格朗松太太，她兴高采烈地照顾这位病人。
en: Mademoiselle Cormon fainted; du Bousquier, who saw her stagger, sprang forward and received her in his arms; some one opened the door and allowed him to pass out with his enormous burden.The fiery republican, instructed by Josette, found strength to carry the old maid to her bedroom, where he laid her out on the bed.Josette, armed with scissors, cut the corset, which was terribly tight.Du Bousquier flung water on Mademoiselle Cormon’s face and bosom, which, released from the corset, overflowed like the Loire in flood.The poor woman opened her eyes, saw du Bousquier, and gave a cry of modesty at the sight of him.Du Bousquier retired at once, leaving six women, at the head of whom was Madame Granson, radiant with joy, to take care of the invalid.

zh: 德瓦卢瓦先生一直在干什么呢？他仍旧忠于自己的原则，掩护撤退。
en: What had the Chevalier de Valois been about all this time?Faithful to his system, he had covered the retreat.

zh: “可怜的科尔蒙小姐，”他对德特雷维尔先生说道，一边看向在场的人，他那贵族般沉着的目光，让在场的人都止住了自己的笑声，“血热折磨得她够呛。到普雷博戴她的田庄去之前，她不肯让人给放放血。看吧，这下好了！”
en: “That poor Mademoiselle Cormon,” he said to Monsieur de Troisville, gazing at the assembly, whose laughter was repressed by his cool aristocratic glances, “her blood is horribly out of order; she wouldn’t be bled before going to Prebaudet (her estate),—and see the result!”

zh: “她早上淋雨回来的，”德斯蓬德神父说，“可能是着凉了。不要紧的，她只是老病犯了。”
en: “She came back this morning in the rain,” said the Abbe de Sponde, “and she may have taken cold.It won’t be anything; it is only a little upset she is subject to.”

zh: “她昨天才告诉我这三个月来都没有发过病了，还说担心会再犯呢。”骑士说道。
en: “She told me yesterday she had not had one for three months, adding that she was afraid it would play her a trick at last,” said the chevalier.

zh: “哈！原来你已经成婚了？”雅克兰看着德特雷维尔先生静静地小口呷着咖啡，自言自语道。
en: “Ha! So you are married?” said Jacquelin to himself as he looked at Monsieur de Troisville, who was quietly sipping his coffee.

zh: 这个忠诚的奴仆也分担了女主人的沮丧心情，猜到了她的心思，他立即将昂伏夫人的烈性酒端走了，那是用来款待单身汉的，而不是款待一个俄国女人的丈夫的。
en: The faithful servant espoused his mistress’s disappointment; he divined it, and he promptly carried away the liqueurs of Madame Amphoux, which were offered to a bachelor, and not to the husband of a Russian woman.

zh: 大家都注意到了这些细节，都成了他们的笑料。德斯蓬德神父本来知道德特雷维尔先生此行的目的，但是由于他一贯的心不在焉，竟然丝毫没有向他的外甥女提起。他怎么也想不到他的外甥女会对德特雷维尔先生产生兴趣。而子爵也一心想着自己此行的目的，并且，像许多丈夫一样，不着急提起自己的妻室，况且他也没有机会说自己已经结婚了。此外，他可能很自然地认为科尔蒙小姐已经知道了。
en: All these details were noticed and laughed at.The Abbe de Sponde knew the object of Monsieur de Troisville’s journey; but, absent-minded as usual, he forgot it, not supposing that his niece could have the slightest interest in Monsieur de Troisville’s marriage.As for the viscount, preoccupied with the object of his journey, and, like many husbands, not eager to talk about his wife, he had had no occasion to say he was married; besides, he would naturally suppose that Mademoiselle Cormon knew it.

zh: 迪布斯基耶一露面，大家便刨根究底地向他询问情况。楼上六位女士中的一位不久便下楼来，宣布科尔蒙小姐已经好转多了，而且还请来了医生。她还需要卧床休息，并且急需放血。客厅现在宾客已满。科尔蒙小姐不在场，女士们得以大谈特谈刚才那一幕，将这悲喜剧的一幕加以铺陈、评论、美化、修饰、添油加醋地大肆渲染了一番。到了第二天，整个阿郎松城一定会对这一幕念念不忘。
en: Du Bousquier reappeared, and was questioned furiously.One of the six women came down soon after, and announced that Mademoiselle Cormon was much better, and that the doctor had come.She intended to stay in bed, as it was necessary to bleed her.The salon was now full.Mademoiselle Cormon’s absence allowed the ladies present to discuss the tragi-comic scene—embellished, extended, historified, embroidered, wreathed, colored, and adorned—which had just taken place, and which, on the morrow, was destined to occupy all Alencon.

zh: “迪布斯基耶先生真是好呀！他抱着您的时候有多稳呀！”若赛特对女主人说,“他见您病了，脸都白了；他还爱着您呢。”
en: “That good Monsieur du Bousquier!How well he carried you!” said Josette to her mistress.“He was really pale at the sight of you; he loves you still.”

zh: 这句话便是这隆重而又可怕的晚宴的结束语了。
en: That speech served as closure to this solemn and terrible evening.

zh: 第二天上午，这出喜剧的细枝末节都在阿郎松的家家户户传遍了。说句让这个城市丢人的话吧，这些细节引起了难以停息的笑声。第二天，科尔蒙小姐放血后，身体大有好转，她让那个并非故意愚弄她的人挎着胳膊去吃早饭。即使对那些最胆大包天的嘲笑者来说，如果他们看到她这个时候表现出来的高贵尊严和激励着她的了不起的基督教逆来顺受的精神，一定会觉得她令人崇敬。拿她开心的冷酷的人们！看看她对子爵说了什么吧：
en: Throughout the morning of the next day every circumstance of the late comedy was known in the household of Alencon, and—let us say it to the shame of that town,—they caused inextinguishable laughter.But on that day Mademoiselle Cormon (much benefited by the bleeding) would have seemed sublime even to the boldest scoffers, had they witnessed the noble dignity, the splendid Christian resignation which influenced her as she gave her arm to her involuntary deceiver to go into breakfast.Cruel jesters!Why could you not have seen her as she said to the viscount,—

zh: “德特雷维尔夫人在这里很难找到适合她的房子的；先生，在您还没有安排好住宅以前，请您赏光，就先暂住在我家里吧。”
en: “Madame de Troisville will have difficulty in finding a suitable house; do me the favor, monsieur, of accepting the use of mine during the time you are in search of yours.”

zh: “可是，小姐，我有两个女儿和两个儿子，那样的话就太麻烦你们了。”
en: “But, mademoiselle, I have two sons and two daughters; we should greatly inconvenience you.”

zh: “请您不要拒绝我吧。”她诚恳地说道。
en: “Pray do not refuse me,” she said earnestly.

zh: “我给您回信的时候，也告诉您先住在我家了，”神父说道，“但是您没有收到我的回信。”
en: “I made you the same offer in the answer I wrote to your letter,” said the abbe; “but you did not receive it.”

zh: “怎么，舅舅！那您知道——”
en: “What, uncle! Then you knew—”

zh: 可怜的老姑娘及时打住。若赛特叹了一口气。子爵和神父都没有察觉到有什么不对。早饭后，德斯蓬德神父按照他们前一晚商量好的计划，带着子爵去看阿郎松有什么房子可以买的，或者看什么地方可以盖房子。
en: The poor woman stopped.Josette sighed.Neither the viscount nor the abbe observed anything amiss.After breakfast the Abbe de Sponde carried off his guest, as agreed upon the previous evening, to show him the various houses in Alencon which could be bought, and the lots of lands on which he might build.

zh: 只留下科尔蒙小姐独自一人在客厅里，她满脸痛苦地对若赛特说：“我的孩子，现在我已经成了全城的笑柄了。”
en: Left alone in the salon, Mademoiselle Cormon said to Josette, with a deeply distressed air, “My child, I am now the talk of the whole town.”

zh: “这样的话，小姐，你该嫁人啦。”
en: “Well, then, mademoiselle, you should marry.”

zh: “但是我还没有准备好选谁呀。”
en: “But I am not prepared to make a choice.”

zh: “哎呀，我要是您的话，就嫁给迪布斯基耶先生。”
en: “Bah! If I were in your place, I should take Monsieur du Bousquier.”

zh: “若赛特，德瓦卢瓦先生说了他可是铁杆的共和党呀。”
en: “Josette, Monsieur de Valois says he is so republican.”

zh: “您的那些先生，都是胡说八道呢。他们还说他敲共和党的钱呢，他要是那样做的话，那他应该一点儿也不喜欢共和党吧。”若赛特说着走开了。
en: “They don’t know what they say, your gentlemen: sometimes they declare that he robbed the republic; he couldn’t love it if he did that,” said Josette, departing.

zh: “没想到这姑娘还挺有头脑的呀。”科尔蒙小姐想道，独自一人在那里发呆，脑中一片茫然。
en: “That girl has an amazing amount of sense,” thought Mademoiselle Cormon, who remained alone, a prey to her perplexities.

zh: 她很清楚，迅速结婚是唯一堵住全城人的嘴的办法。这最后的受挫，如此明显的丢人，倒是起了一个作用，促使她做个决定。没有头脑的人总是不知好坏地沿着他们选择的路一直跑下去。
en: She saw plainly that a prompt marriage was the only way to silence the town.This last checkmate, so evidently mortifying, was of a nature to drive her into some extreme action; for persons deficient in mind find difficulty in getting out of any path, either good or evil, into which they have entered.

zh: 两个老光棍都清楚地了解老姑娘即将面临的处境，于是都决定上午就来问候她的身体健康情况，并且趁机以单身汉的姿态“向前挺进”。德瓦卢瓦先生认为这样的情况，需要更仔细地梳洗打扮才行。于是他洗了一个澡，收拾得异乎寻常的整齐。赛查丽娜是第一次也是最后一次见到他很巧妙地略施脂粉。而迪布斯基耶这个大老粗般的共和党，在坚强意志的激励下，对衣着打扮毫不在意，最先来到。
en: Each of the two old bachelors had fully understood the situation in which Mademoiselle Cormon was about to find herself; consequently, each resolved to call in the course of that morning to ask after her health, and take occasion, in bachelor language, to “press his point.”Monsieur de Valois considered that such an occasion demanded a painstaking toilet; he therefore took a bath and groomed himself with extraordinary care.For the first and last time Cesarine observed him putting on with incredible art a suspicion of rouge.Du Bousquier, on the other hand, that coarse republican, spurred by a brisk will, paid no attention to his dress, and arrived the first.

zh: 这样的小事不仅能决定帝国的命运，也能决定人的命运。凯勒曼的骑兵来到马郎戈，勃吕歇到达滑铁卢，路易十四对欧也纳亲王的蔑视，德南的神父，所有这些造成成败的重大原因，历史上都有记载。但是没有人会将他们生活中的小事记录下来。因此，看看发生了什么吧：德朗热公爵夫人（见《十三人故事》）因为缺乏十分钟的耐心而当了修女，包比诺法官推迟到第二天去询问德埃斯巴侯爵（见《禁治产》），夏尔·葛朗台归来从波尔多上岸，却不从南特回来。这些事情都被人们称之为偶然或是命中注定。仔细往脸上施了一点点脂粉，却让德瓦卢瓦骑士的希望完全破灭；还能有什么方式让这位绅士垮台的吗？他从前靠着美惠三女神活着，那他也注定要死在三女神手里。在骑士最后一次审视他的衣着打扮的时候，粗里粗气的迪布斯基耶已经走进了愁眉苦脸的老姑娘的客厅里。老姑娘刚才还想着骑士挺好的，而看到迪布斯基耶第一个走进客厅，就立刻倾向于这个共和党人了。
en: Such little things decide the fortunes of men, as they do of empires.Kellerman’s charge at Marengo, Blucher’s arrival at Waterloo, Louis XIV’s disdain for Prince Eugene, the rector of Denain,—all these great causes of fortune or catastrophe history has recorded; but no one ever profits by them to avoid the small neglects of their own life.Consequently, observe what happens: the Duchesse de Langeais (see “History of the Thirteen”) makes herself a nun for the lack of ten minutes’ patience; Judge Popinot (see “Commission in Lunacy”) puts off till the morrow the duty of examining the Marquis d’Espard; Charles Grandet (see “Eugenie Grandet”) goes to Paris from Bordeaux instead of returning by Nantes; and such events are called chance or fatality!A touch of rouge carefully applied destroyed the hopes of the Chevalier de Valois; could that nobleman perish in any other way?He had lived by the Graces, and he was doomed to die by their hand.While the chevalier was giving this last touch to his toilet the rough du Bousquier was entering the salon of the desolate old maid.This entrance produced a thought in Mademoiselle Cormon’s mind which was favorable to the republican, although in all other respects the Chevalier de Valois held the advantages.

zh: “他就是上帝的旨意！”她看着迪布斯基耶走进来，心想。
en: “God wills it!” she said piously, on seeing du Bousquier.

zh: “小姐，请您不要介意我这么着急前来。我信不过我那个傻瓜勒内来打听您的消息，于是亲自前来了。”
en: “Mademoiselle, you will not, I trust, think my eagerness importunate.I could not trust to my stupid Rene to bring news of your condition, and therefore I have come myself.”

zh: “我已经完全好了，”她激动地回答道，“我要谢谢您，迪布斯基耶先生，”她停顿了下，接着用意味深长的声音说道，“昨天真是麻烦您了，让您辛苦地——”
en: “I am perfectly recovered,” she replied, in a tone of emotion.“I thank you, Monsieur du Bousquier,” she added, after a slight pause, and in a significant tone of voice, “for the trouble you have taken, and for that which I gave you yesterday—”

zh: 她记起了自己曾躺在迪布斯基耶的怀抱里，又一次让她觉得这是天意。这还是第一次让男人看见她的腰带、束带被剪断，女性的珍宝全部抛洒在珠宝匣外面。
en: She remembered having been in his arms, and that again seemed to her an order from heaven.She had been seen for the first time by a man with her laces cut, her treasures violently bursting from their casket.

zh: “我无比荣幸能抱着您，感觉您很轻呀。”
en: “I carried you with such joy that you seemed to me light.”

zh: 这时，科尔蒙小姐用她从未看过世界上任何一个男人的目光看了迪布斯基耶一眼。因此这位前商人受到了鼓励，也向这个老姑娘回了个媚眼，打动了老姑娘的心。
en: Here Mademoiselle Cormon looked at du Bousquier as she had never yet looked at any man in the world.Thus encouraged, the purveyor cast upon the old maid a glance which reached her heart.

zh: “我真希望，”他说，“那个时刻能让您永远属于我。（老姑娘开心地听着）当您晕倒在床上的时候，真是动人呀。我这辈子还没有见过比您更漂亮的女人呢——当然我是见过许多漂亮女人的。丰满的女人有一个长处，就是看着特别美；她们只要一显露自己的身体，她们就赢了。”
en: “I would,” he said, “that that moment had given me the right to keep you as mine forever” (she listened with a delighted air); “as you lay fainting upon that bed, you were enchanting.I have never in my life seen a more beautiful person,—and I have seen many handsome women.Plump ladies have this advantage: they are superb to look upon; they have only to show themselves and they triumph.”

zh: “您这是取笑我吧，”老姑娘说道，“昨天的事，全城的人都在乱说吧，这很不好呀。”
en: “I fear you are making fun of me,” said the old maid, “and that is not kind when all the town will probably misinterpret what happened to me yesterday.”

zh: “有如我的名字迪布斯基耶一样，小姐，我对您的感情始终如一。您第一次拒绝我，并没有让我灰心。”
en: “As true as my name is du Bousquier, mademoiselle, I have never changed in my feelings toward you; and your first refusal has not discouraged me.”

zh: 老姑娘的眼帘低垂着。这对迪布斯基耶来说，可是难熬的一刻呀。然后，科尔蒙小姐打定主意了。她抬起眼来，热泪盈眶，温柔地看了迪布斯基耶一眼。
en: The old maid’s eyes were lowered.There was a moment of cruel silence for du Bousquier, and then Mademoiselle Cormon decided on her course.She raised her eyelids; tears flowed from her eyes, and she gave du Bousquier a tender glance.

zh: “真是这样的话，先生，”她颤抖地说，“只要您答应我过基督徒的生活，不会反对我的宗教习惯，不干涉我选择自己的神师，我便答应您的求婚。”她说完，将手伸给他。
en: “If that is so, monsieur,” she said, in a trembling voice, “promise me to live in a Christian manner, and not oppose my religious customs, but to leave me the right to select my confessors, and I will grant you my hand”; as she said the words, she held it out to him.

zh: 迪布斯基耶紧紧握住这金钱万贯的胖手，庄重地吻了一下。
en: Du Bousquier seized the good fat hand so full of money, and kissed it solemnly.

zh: “可是，”她让他亲吻自己的手，接着说道，“我还有一个要求。”
en: “But,” she said, allowing him to kiss it, “one thing more I must require of you.”

zh: “只要我能办到，就一定满足。”商人回道。
en: “If it is a possible thing, it is granted,” replied the purveyor.

zh: “唉！”老姑娘接着说，“看在我的份上，我必须要求您承担一项罪过。我觉得这个罪过不小，因为说谎是七条大罪之一。但是，你以后可以忏悔的，对吧？我们以后可以通过苦行来赎罪的（两人深情地互望了一眼）。并且，这个谎也许可以被教会列为善意的谎言——”
en: “Alas!” returned the old maid.“For my sake, I must ask you to take upon yourself a sin which I feel to be enormous,—for to lie is one of the capital sins.But you will confess it, will you not?We will do penance for it together” (they looked at each other tenderly).“Besides, it may be one of those lies which the Church permits as necessary—”

zh: “莫非她和苏珊说的一样？”迪布斯基耶暗想，“这叫什么运气呀!”“小姐，您是指什么呢？”他高声说道。
en: “Can she be as Suzanne says she is?” thought du Bousquier.“What luck!Well, mademoiselle, what is it?” he said aloud.

zh: “就是您得自己承认——”
en: “That you will take upon yourself to—”

zh: “什么事？”
en: “What?”

zh: “您要说，这桩婚事我们已经在六个月前谈妥了。”
en: “To say that this marriage has been agreed upon between us for the last six months.”

zh: “可爱的女人，”商人用极其忠诚的语气说道，“只有对一个爱恋了十年之久的女子，男人才愿意做出这样的牺牲。”
en: “Charming woman,” said the purveyor, in the tone of a man willing to devote himself, “such sacrifices can be made only for a creature adored these ten years.”

zh: “即使我对您那么狠心？”她问。
en: “In spite of my harshness?” she said.

zh: “是的，即使您对我那样狠心。”
en: “Yes, in spite of your harshness.”

zh: “迪布斯基耶先生，我以前错看您了。”
en: “Monsieur du Bousquier, I have misjudged you.”

zh: 她再次向他伸出那只通红的胖手，迪布斯基耶再一次吻了那只手。
en: Again she held out the fat red hand, which du Bousquier kissed again.

zh: 这时门开了，这对未婚夫妻抬头看看是谁来了。他们看到的是打扮得十分风雅，却姗姗来迟了的德瓦卢瓦骑士。
en: At this moment the door opened; the betrothed pair, looking round to see who entered, beheld the delightful, but tardy Chevalier de Valois.

zh: “啊！”他进来时说，“我很高兴您就要起身了，美丽的女王。”
en: “Ah!” he said, on entering, “I see you are about to be up, fair queen.”

zh: 她对骑士微笑，感到胸口一阵发紧。德瓦卢瓦骑士显得那么年轻、诱人，他的神情就像是洛赞进宫去看大公主一般。
en: She smiled at the chevalier, feeling a weight upon her heart.Monsieur de Valois, remarkably young and seductive, had the air of a Lauzunre—entering the apartments of the Grande Mademoiselle in the Palais—Royal.

zh: “嗨，亲爱的迪布斯基耶，”骑士认为自己稳操胜券，用冷嘲热讽的语气说道，“德特雷维尔先生和德斯蓬德神父正在打量您的房子呢，他们俩就像土地测量员一样。”
en: “Hey! dear du Bousquier,” said he, in a jaunty tone, so sure was he of success, “Monsieur de Troisville and the Abbe de Sponde are examining your house like appraisers.”

zh: “确实！”迪布斯基耶说道，“如果德特雷维尔子爵想要，我四万法郎就卖给他了。现在那所房子对我已经毫无意义了。如果小姐允许我说的话——别人很快就能知道了——小姐，我能说吗？——好！那么，我亲爱的骑士，请您作为第一个得知我们好消息的人吧（科尔蒙小姐垂下眼帘）。科尔蒙小姐早已垂青于我，而这件事我保密了好几个月。过几天我们就要结婚了；婚约已经拟好，明天我们就要签约了。所以，您自然明白，我在天鹅街的房屋对我已经毫无用处了。我一直在私下找寻买主，德斯蓬德神父知道的，所以就把德特雷维尔领到我家去看房呢。”
en: “Faith!” said du Bousquier, “if the Vicomte de Troisville wants it, it it is his for forty thousand francs.It is useless to me now.If mademoiselle will permit—it must soon be known—Mademoiselle, may I tell it?—Yes!Well, then, be the first, MY DEAR CHEVALIER, to hear” (Mademoiselle Cormon dropped her eyes) “of the honor that mademoiselle has done me, the secret of which I have kept for some months.We shall be married in a few days; the contract is already drawn, and we shall sign it to-morrow.You see, therefore, that my house in the rue du Cygne is useless to me.I have been privately looking for a purchaser for some time; and the Abbe de Sponde, who knew that fact, has naturally taken Monsieur de Troisville to see the house.”

zh: 这个弥天大谎，说得那么活灵活现，连骑士都被骗住了。那个“我亲爱的骑士”的称呼，正像彼得大帝在波尔塔瓦向查理十二报复从前败在他手下的全部仇恨一样。
en: This falsehood bore such an appearance of truth that the chevalier was taken in by it.That “my dear chevalier” was like the revenge taken by Peter the Great on Charles XII at Pultawa for all his past defeats.

zh: 迪布斯基耶从前默默忍受了千百支利箭，这下他用这句话痛快地报仇雪恨了。在他得意的时候，他做了一个年轻人的手势，将手插进了假顶发，这样一下子就把假顶发给弄下来了。
en: Du Bousquier revenged himself deliciously for the thousand little shafts he had long borne in silence; but in his triumph he made a lively youthful gesture by running his hands through his hair, and in so doing he—knocked aside his false front.

zh: “我恭喜你们二位，”骑士以和悦的声音说道，“并且希望二位能拥有童话故事里那样的结局——他们从此非常幸福，并且生了许多孩子！”说到这儿，他拿了一撮鼻烟。“但是，先生，”他讥讽地加上一句，“您忘了，您戴的是假顶发。”
en: “I congratulate you both,” said the chevalier, with an agreeable air; “and I wish that the marriage may end like a fairy tale: THEY WERE HAPPY EVER AFTER, AND HAD—MANY—CHILDREN!”So saying, he took a pinch of snuff.“But, monsieur,” he added satirically, “you forget—that you are wearing a false front.”

zh: 迪布斯基耶涨得满脸通红。他的假顶发已经离他的脑壳有十几英寸远了。科尔蒙小姐抬起眼睛，看到了那光秃的头顶，羞得垂下了眼皮。迪布斯基耶狠狠地瞪了骑士一眼，那目光比癞蛤蟆盯着自己的猎物还更加狠毒。
en: Du Bousquier blushed.The false front was hanging half a dozen inches from his skull.Mademoiselle Cormon raised her eyes, saw that skull in all its nudity, and lowered them, abashed.Du Bousquier cast upon the chevalier the most venomous look that toad ever darted on its prey.

zh: “鄙视我的贵族走狗，”他心想，“我终有一天会把你们粉碎的。”
en: “Dogs of aristocrats who despise me,” thought he, “I’ll crush you some day.”

zh: 骑士以为自己又恢复了优势。但是科尔蒙小姐不是那样的女人，她不懂得骑士的祝愿和假顶发之间有什么关联。而且，就算她能明白，她的话已出口，她的手也不再属于他了。德瓦卢瓦骑士立即明白一切都完了。这个天真的老姑娘，看到眼前两人都默默不语，于是认为她应该有责任让他们开心一下。
en: The chevalier thought he had recovered his advantage.But Mademoiselle Cormon was not a woman to understand the connection which the chevalier intimated between his congratulatory wish and the false front.Besides, even if she had comprehended it, her word was passed, her hand given.Monsieur de Valois saw at once that all was lost.The innocent woman, with the two now silent men before her, wished, true to her sense of duty, to amuse them.

zh: “要不一起玩皮克牌吧？”她天真而毫无恶意地说道。
en: “Why not play a game of piquet together?” she said artlessly, without the slightest malice.

zh: 迪布斯基耶微微一笑，然后作为家中未来的主人，走去搬牌桌了。德瓦卢瓦骑士，也许是昏了头，也许是想留下来以便研究他灾难的原因并设法补救，总之，他就像人们牵到屠宰场去的绵羊一样，任人摆布。他受到了一个男人所能受的最沉重的打击，任何一位绅士都至少会被打击得丧失理智的。
en: Du Bousquier smiled, and went, as the future master of the house, to fetch the piquet table.Whether the Chevalier de Valois lost his head, or whether he wanted to stay and study the causes of his disaster and remedy it, certain it is that he allowed himself to be led like a lamb to the slaughter.He had received the most violent knock-down blow that ever struck a man; any nobleman would have lost his senses for less.

zh: 不一会儿，德斯蓬德神父和德特雷维尔子爵回来了。科尔蒙小姐立即起身，跑到前厅去，将她的舅舅拉到一旁，好告诉他她的决定。得知德特雷维尔先生很中意天鹅街的房子时，她便请自己的未婚夫来帮忙，告诉对方她舅父本来就知道这房子是要出售的。她不敢让神父去撒这个谎，因为他总是心不在焉的。总之，这谎编织的比美德还成功。到了晚上，全城都得知了这个重大消息。这四天以来，这城市的人忙碌得就像在一八一四年和一八一五年那些不幸的日子中一样。有些人讥讽嘲笑，有些人相信这桩婚事。有些人谴责这桩婚事，有些人看好这桩婚事。阿郎松的中产阶级为此兴高采烈，认为这是一种胜利。第二天，在朋友们面前，德瓦卢瓦骑士说了一句很刻薄的话：
en: The Abbe de Sponde and the Vicomte de Troisville soon returned.Mademoiselle Cormon instantly rose, hurried into the antechamber, and took her uncle apart to tell him her resolution.Learning that the house in the rue du Cygne exactly suited the viscount, she begged her future husband to do her the kindness to tell him that her uncle knew it was for sale.She dared not confide that lie to the abbe, fearing his absent-mindedness.The lie, however, prospered better than if it had been a virtuous action.In the course of that evening all Alencon heard the news.For the last four days the town had had as much to think of as during the fatal days of 1814 and 1815.Some laughed; others admitted the marriage.These blamed it; those approved it.The middle classes of Alencon rejoiced; they regarded it as a victory.The next day, among friends, the Chevalier de Valois said a cruel thing:—

zh: “科尔蒙家怎么兴起的，也怎么衰落。从总管到商人，不过一步之遥而已。”
en: “The Cormons end as they began; there’s only a hand’s breadth between a steward and a purveyor.”

zh: 第七章 其他影响
en: CHAPTER VII OTHER RESULTS

zh: 科尔蒙小选中了丈夫的事，深深地刺伤了阿塔纳斯·格朗松的心，但他丝毫没有流露出他内心的狂风暴雨。他得知这婚事的消息时，正在法院院长迪龙瑟雷家里，他的母亲在那里玩波士顿牌。格朗松太太从一面镜子里观察她的儿子，发现他脸色苍白；不过他从早上就那样了，因为他已经隐约听到了这件婚事的传言。
en: The news of Mademoiselle Cormon’s choice stabbed poor Athanase Granson to the heart; but he showed no outward sign of the terrible agitation within him.When he first heard of the marriage he was at the house of the chief-justice, du Ronceret, where his mother was playing boston.Madame Granson looked at her son in a mirror, and thought him pale; but he had been so all day, for a vague rumor of the matter had already reached him.

zh: 科尔蒙小姐原本是阿塔纳斯赌上自己一生的一张牌，而灾难将要发生的冰冷预感已经牢牢地将他罩住。当心灵和想象将不幸放大，使之成了肩上或思想上难以承担的重负时，当怀抱已久的希望（这个希望如果实现，就连吞噬心肝的贪婪秃鹫也会满足）破灭时，当一个人虽然有力量，却对自己失去了信心，虽然有坚强的意志，但是对前途已经失去了信心的时候，这个人就要垮了。阿塔纳斯就是帝国教育的产物。这个皇帝信仰的宗教，从皇帝的宝座上一直渗透到军队最底层的队伍中和学校里的板凳上。阿塔纳斯一直瞪着迪龙瑟雷夫人的牌，那种痴呆的样子，很容易让人以为他满不在乎，甚至连格朗松太太自己也认为估计错了儿子的感情。阿塔纳斯表面上的不在乎倒可以解释为她的儿子拒绝为了这件婚事牺牲自己“自由派”的见解。“自由派”这个词是由亚历山大大帝创造出来的，我认为它起源于斯塔尔夫人，又通过邦雅曼·贡斯当传开的。
en: Mademoiselle Cormon was the card on which Athanase had staked his life; and the cold presentiment of a catastrophe was already upon him.When the soul and the imagination have magnified a misfortune and made it too heavy for the shoulders and the brain to bear; when a hope long cherished, the realization of which would pacify the vulture feeding on the heart, is balked, and the man has faith neither in himself, despite his powers, nor in the future, despite of the Divine power,—then that man is lost.Athanase was a fruit of the Imperial system of education.Fatality, the Emperor’s religion, had filtered down from the throne to the lowest ranks of the army and the benches of the lyceums.Athanase sat still, with his eyes fixed on Madame du Ronceret’s cards, in a stupor that might so well pass for indifference that Madame Granson herself was deceived about his feelings.This apparent unconcern explained her son’s refusal to make a sacrifice for this marriage of his LIBERAL opinions,—the term “liberal” having lately been created for the Emperor Alexander by, I think, Madame de Stael, through the lips of Benjamin Constant.

zh: 自从这个不幸的晚上开始，这个年轻人总是到萨尔特河河边风景最优美的地方散步。这是萨尔特河的一处河岸，阿郎松的画家经常到这里取景作画。那里有风车，河水在草地中愉快地穿行。萨尔特河岸边生长着排列优美而茂盛的树木。虽然这里的地形很平坦，但仍然具有法国独具一格的特色。在法国，你的眼睛从来不会因东方光线强烈而疲劳，也不会为持续不断的浓雾而忧郁。这里是很荒僻的。在外省，没有人在意优美的景物，也许是大家都习以为常了，也许是他们的灵魂中都缺乏诗意。在外省，如果从某条林阴道，某个地方或某个散步场所可以看到优美的景色，那里一定是没有人去的地方。阿塔纳斯很喜欢这荒僻的地方，汩汩流水使之生机盎然，春日的阳光刚一绽出微笑，草地便复苏发绿。那些看到他坐在白杨树下的人，以及注意过他那茫然眼神的人，都会和格朗松太太说：
en: After that fatal evening the young man took to rambling among the picturesque regions of the Sarthe, the banks of which are much frequented by sketchers who come to Alencon for points of view.Windmills are there, and the river is gay in the meadows.The shores of the Sarthe are bordered with beautiful trees, well grouped.Though the landscape is flat, it is not without those modest graces which distinguish France, where the eye is never wearied by the brilliancy of Oriental skies, nor saddened by constant fog.The place is solitary.In the provinces no one pays much attention to a fine view, either because provincials are blases on the beauty around them, or because they have no poesy in their souls.If there exists in the provinces a mall, a promenade, a vantage-ground from which a fine view can be obtained, that is the point to which no one goes.Athanase was fond of this solitude, enlivened by the sparkling water, where the fields were the first to green under the earliest smiling of the springtide sun.Those persons who saw him sitting beneath a poplar, and who noticed the vacant eye which he turned to them, would say to Madame Granson:—

zh: “您儿子有点儿不对劲呀。”
en: “Something is the matter with your son.”

zh: “我知道他在干什么。”这位母亲会得意地回答道，言下之意是她的儿子正在酝酿一部伟大作品呢。
en: “I know what it is,” the mother would reply; hinting that he was meditating over some great work.

zh: 阿塔纳斯不再参与政治，也不再有什么政见了。但是有几次他却显得很开心，因为和一些认为可以将全世界都辱骂一顿的人在一起，为讥讽别人而快活。这位年轻人，游离于各种思想和外省的各种享乐之外，很少有人会在意他，他压根不是个令人好奇的对象。如果有人会和他的母亲谈起他，完全是因为他母亲的缘故，而不是对他感兴趣。阿郎松没有一个人来同情他，没有一个女人、一个朋友来为他擦干眼泪，他的眼泪都洒入了萨尔特河。如果俊俏的苏珊从这里经过，他们的相逢会诞生多少新的不幸呀！他们是完全可能相爱的。事实上，苏珊确实到过这里。苏珊的野心是因为曾经听了一段不同寻常的艳史，让她孩童般的头脑着迷了。这段艳史是发生在摩尔旅店。一位美得像天使一般的巴黎女郎，接受了警察局的任务，去迷惑德蒙托郎侯爵，要让他爱上她（见《舒昂党人》）。就在他从莫尔塔涅远征归来的时候，这个女郎在摩尔旅店与他相遇，并且诱惑了他，让他爱上了自己，然后出卖了他。这神奇的力量，美貌对于男性产生的这种魅力，玛丽·德韦纳伊与德蒙托郎侯爵的整个故事都让苏珊着迷。从她懂事起，她就渴望长大，好玩弄男性。在她匆忙离开之后的几个月，她和一位艺术家穿过她的家乡一起到布列塔尼去。她想看看富热尔，因为德蒙托郎侯爵的艳遇就是在富热尔结束的。她还想走遍这个可悲可泣的战场，这场悲剧直到现在还很少为人所知，却充满了她那幼稚的头脑。另外，她还希望能体面地穿过阿郎松城而没有人能认出她来。她打算让她的母亲避开不幸，并且感情微妙地想给可怜的阿塔纳斯一笔钱。这笔钱在我们这个时代，对于一个天才来说，相当于中世纪时蕊贝卡给艾凡赫弄到的战马和盔甲。
en: Athanase no longer took part in politics: he ceased to have opinions; but he appeared at times quite gay,—gay with the satire of those who think to insult a whole world with their own individual scorn.This young man, outside of all the ideas and all the pleasures of the provinces, interested few persons; he was not even an object of curiosity.If persons spoke of him to his mother, it was for her sake, not his.There was not a single soul in Alencon that sympathized with his; not a woman, not a friend came near to dry his tears; they dropped into the Sarthe.If the gorgeous Suzanne had happened that way, how many young miseries might have been born of the meeting! For the two would surely have loved each other.She did come, however.Suzanne’s ambition was early excited by the tale of a strange adventure which had happened at the tavern of the More,—a tale which had taken possession of her childish brain.A Parisian woman, beautiful as the angels, was sent by Fouche to entangle the Marquis de Montauran, otherwise called “The Gars,” in a love-affair (see “The Chouans”).She met him at the tavern of the More on his return from an expedition to Mortagne; she cajoled him, made him love her, and then betrayed him.That fantastic power—the power of beauty over mankind; in fact, the whole story of Marie de Verneuil and the Gars—dazzled Suzanne; she longed to grow up in order to play upon men.Some months after her hasty departure she passed through her native town with an artist on his way to Brittany.She wanted to see Fougeres, where the adventure of the Marquis de Montauran culminated, and to stand upon the scene of that picturesque war, the tragedies of which, still so little known, had filled her childish mind.Besides this, she had a fancy to pass through Alencon so elegantly equipped that no one could recognize her; to put her mother above the reach of necessity, and also to send to poor Athanase, in a delicate manner, a sum of money,—which in our age is to genius what in the middle ages was the charger and the coat of mail that Rebecca conveyed to Ivanhoe.

zh: 科尔蒙小姐的婚姻造成的莫名其妙的风云变幻持续了一个月。人们分成两派，一派不相信这桩婚姻，总是在一起否认这婚事；另一派则总是肯定这桩婚事。过了两周，怀疑派遭到了惨败：迪布斯基耶的房子卖给了德特雷维尔先生。这位先生只想在阿郎松有一所简朴的房子，因为日后赛布洛夫公主去世了，他还想搬到巴黎去住。他打算一边恢复自己的土地旧观，一面心平气和地等着他的遗产。看来是不会有错了。然而，怀疑派仍然不甘心。他们声称，不管迪布斯基耶是否要结婚，他都是做了一桩好买卖。他的房子最初只花了两万七千法郎。怀疑派这样不容质疑的见解，把相信派给震住了。怀疑派还说，舒瓦内尔，也就是科尔蒙小姐的公证人，确实还没有听到婚约的事。但是相信派仍然坚信不疑，到了第十二天，他们取得了胜利：自由党的公证人勒普雷索瓦先生到了科尔蒙小姐家中，并且签了婚约。
en: One month passed away in the strangest uncertainties respecting the marriage of Mademoiselle Cormon.A party of unbelievers denied the marriage altogether; the believers, on the other hand, affirmed it.At the end of two weeks, the faction of unbelief received a vigorous blow in the sale of du Bousquier’s house to the Marquis de Troisville, who only wanted a simple establishment in Alencon, intending to go to Paris after the death of the Princess Scherbellof; he proposed to await that inheritance in retirement, and then to reconstitute his estates.This seemed positive.The unbelievers, however, were not crushed.They declared that du Bousquier, married or not, had made an excellent sale, for the house had only cost him twenty-seven thousand francs.The believers were depressed by this practical observation of the incredulous.Choisnel, Mademoiselle Cormon’s notary, asserted the latter, had heard nothing about the marriage contract; but the believers, still firm in their faith, carried off, on the twentieth day, a signal victory: Monsieur Lepressoir, the notary of the liberals, went to Mademoiselle Cormon’s house, and the contract was signed.

zh: 这是科尔蒙小姐为丈夫做出的头一件牺牲的事，以后还会有很多要她牺牲的事。迪布斯基耶恨透了舒瓦内尔。他认为阿芒德小姐第一次拒绝他，就是受舒瓦内尔的影响；而他认为，阿芒德小姐拒绝了他的求婚又导致了科尔蒙小姐第一次对他求婚的拒绝。婚事因为这一情况拖了下来。老姑娘还收到了几封匿名信。她吃惊地了解到，苏珊和她一样还是处女，因为那个戴假顶发、引诱少女的坏蛋迪布斯基耶和这类风流韵事从来沾不上边。科尔蒙小姐很讨厌这种匿名信，但是她还是本着阐明妇女协会的宗旨，给苏珊写了信。毫无疑问苏珊也得知了迪布斯基耶要结婚的事，在回信中承认了自己玩的花招，给协会寄回了一千法郎，同时在信中对迪布斯基耶大肆诋毁。科尔蒙小姐召集妇女协会成员，举办了一次特别会议，决定以后协会不再救济将要发生的不幸，但是只救济那些已经发生的不幸。
en: This was the first of the numerous sacrifices which Mademoiselle Cormon was destined to make to her husband.Du Bousquier bore the deepest hatred to Choisnel; to him he owed the refusal of the hand of Mademoiselle Armande,—a refusal which, as he believed, had influenced that of Mademoiselle Cormon.This circumstance alone made the marriage drag along.Mademoiselle received several anonymous letters.She learned, to her great astonishment, that Suzanne was as truly a virgin as herself so far as du Bousquier was concerned, for that seducer with the false toupet could never be the hero of any such adventure.Mademoiselle Cormon disdained anonymous letters; but she wrote to Suzanne herself, on the ground of enlightening the Maternity Society.Suzanne, who had no doubt heard of du Bousquier’s proposed marriage, acknowledged her trick, sent a thousand francs to the society, and did all the harm she could to the old purveyor.Mademoiselle Cormon convoked the Maternity Society, which held a special meeting at which it was voted that the association would not in future assist any misfortunes about to happen, but solely those that had happened.

zh: 这些事件又成为了全城风言风语的中心话题，但是在教堂和市政府门前还是贴出了结婚预告。阿塔纳斯为他们安排了这些事宜。为了安全和礼节，未婚妻到普雷博戴去住了；而迪布斯基耶每天早上带着十分难看但很奢华的花束，早出晚归，回城吃晚饭。
en: In spite of all these various events which kept the town in the choicest gossip, the banns were published in the churches and at the mayor’s office.Athanase prepared the deeds.As a matter of propriety and public decency, the bride retired to Prebaudet, where du Bousquier, bearing sumptuous and horrible bouquets, betook himself every morning, returning home for dinner.

zh: 最后，在六月的一个多雨而阴沉的上午，当着全城人的面，科尔蒙小姐和迪布斯基耶先生的婚礼于中午时分在阿郎松教区举行了。这对新人从家到市政府，从市政府到教堂，坐的是一辆豪华的敞篷四轮马车。这辆马车是迪布斯基耶悄悄从巴黎弄来的。那辆旧马车被丢弃了，对于全城的人来说无异于一大灾难。赛镇门的鞍具商大嚷大叫，因为他每年修理那马车可以赚到五十法郎，这下是没有了。阿郎松的人满怀恐惧地看到，奢侈品可能因此而进入这个城市。每个人都担心物价会上涨，房租会提高，巴黎的家具会入侵这里的市场。有人好奇心特别强，愿意给雅克兰十个苏，好让他们就近仔细瞧瞧这辆可能会引起当地经济危机的敞篷四轮马车。从诺曼底买来的两匹马也够骇人的了。
en: At last, on a dull and rainy morning in June, the marriage of Mademoiselle Cormon and the Sieur du Bousquier took place at noon in the parish church of Alencon, in sight of the whole town.The bridal pair went from their own house to the mayor’s office, and from the mayor’s office to the church in an open caleche, a magnificent vehicle for Alencon, which du Bousquier had sent for secretly to Paris.The loss of the old carriole was a species of calamity in the eyes of the community.The harness-maker of the Porte de Seez bemoaned it, for he lost the fifty francs a year which it cost in repairs.Alencon saw with alarm the possibility of luxury being thus introduced into the town.Every one feared a rise in the price of rents and provisions, and a coming invasion of Parisian furniture.Some persons were sufficiently pricked by curiosity to give ten sous to Jacquelin to allow them a close inspection of the vehicle which threatened to upset the whole economy of the region.A pair of horses, bought in Normandie, were also most alarming.

zh: “我们要是也买这样的马，”迪龙瑟雷商号的人说，“再也别想把它们卖出去了。”
en: “If we bought our own horses,” said the Ronceret circle, “we couldn’t sell them to those who come to buy.”

zh: 虽然这种看法很愚昧，但是从防止当地囤积外来金钱这个意义上看，还是很有远见的。在外省看来，各地的财富不是表现在金钱的积极周转上，而是看有多少固定不动的积蓄。在这里应该要提一下，珀涅罗珀在小姐结婚六周前得了胸膜炎，怎么也治不好，死了。
en: Stupid as it was, this reasoning seemed sound; for surely such a course would prevent the region from grasping the money of foreigners.In the eyes of the provinces wealth consisted less in the rapid turning over of money than in sterile accumulation.It may be mentioned here that Penelope succumbed to a pleurisy which she acquired about six weeks before the marriage; nothing could save her.

zh: 格朗松太太、玛丽埃特、迪库徳赖夫人、迪龙瑟雷夫人以及全城的人都注意到，迪布斯基耶夫人走进教堂时，先迈的是左脚！“左”这个字眼当时具有政治意义，因此更让人觉得是个凶兆。另外，负责念誓词的教士很偶然地一翻开书便翻到了哀悼经的地方。因此这桩婚事从头到尾就这样一直伴随着种种注定倒霉、令人惊心动魄的情况，没有一个人说是吉兆。事实上，情况越来越糟糕。根本没有举行婚礼，因为新婚夫妇立即前往普雷博戴去了。大家都说，巴黎的风俗要压倒外省历史悠久的习俗了。
en: Madame Granson, Mariette, Madame du Coudrai, Madame du Ronceret, and through them the whole town, remarked that Madame du Bousquier entered the church WITH HER LEFT FOOT,—an omen all the more dreadful because the term Left was beginning to acquire a political meaning.The priest whose duty it was to read the opening formula opened his book by chance at the De Profundis.Thus the marriage was accompanied by circumstances so fateful, so alarming, so annihilating that no one dared to augur well of it.Matters, in fact, went from bad to worse.There was no wedding party; the married pair departed immediately for Prebaudet.Parisian customs, said the community, were about to triumph over time-honored provincial ways.

zh: 玛丽埃特和雅克兰现在终于成婚了，他们的婚礼倒举行得很愉快。阿郎松也就他们俩会驳斥那些关于他们女主人婚姻的不吉利的预言了。
en: The marriage of Jacquelin and Josette now took place: it was gay; and they were the only two persons in Alencon who refuted the sinister prophecies relating to the marriage of their mistress.

zh: 迪布斯基耶打算把他卖房子的钱来修葺科尔蒙公馆，并且将这栋房子现代化。他决定在普雷博戴过上半年，把德斯蓬德舅舅也带去了。这消息惊恐了整座城的人，每个人都感觉到，迪布斯基耶就要把这个城市带到追求舒适的邪路上去。一天早上，阿郎松人看见这新郎坐着一辆轻便双轮马车从普雷博戴来到瓦诺布勒监督施工，车上又套了一匹新买的马，他旁边坐的是穿着仆人号衣的勒内。这更增加了城里人的恐惧情绪。他管理财产的第一举动，便是将他妻子的全部积蓄以公债形式存入国库，当时的报价是67.5法郎。一年之内他不停地做交易，后来他的个人财富达到了几乎和他妻子的财富相当的程度。
en: Du Bousquier determined to use the proceeds of the sale of his late residence in restoring and modernizing the hotel Cormon.He decided to remain through two seasons at Prebaudet, and took the Abbe de Sponde with them.This news spread terror through the town, where every individual felt that du Bousquier was about to drag the community into the fatal path of “comfort.”This fear increased when the inhabitants of Alencon saw the bridegroom driving in from Prebaudet one morning to inspect his works, in a fine tilbury drawn by a new horse, having Rene at his side in livery.The first act of his administration had been to place his wife’s savings on the Grand-Livre, which was then quoted at 67 fr. 50 cent.In the space of one year, during which he played constantly for a rise, he made himself a personal fortune almost as considerable as that of his wife.

zh: 可是，有件与这婚事相关联的祸事，让这桩婚事显得更加不吉利了，把之前那些凶兆和扰乱人心的革新举动都比下去了。
en: But all these foreboding prophecies, these perturbing innovations, were superseded and surpassed by an event connected with this marriage which gave a still more fatal aspect to it.

zh: 在他们举行婚礼的当天晚上，阿塔纳斯和他妈妈吃过晚饭，仆人像往常一样在上餐后甜点时用细树枝生了一点火，他们就坐在火炉旁。
en: On the very evening of the ceremony, Athanase and his mother were sitting, after their dinner, over a little fire of fagots, which the servant lighted usually at dessert.

zh: “好吧，既然现在没有科尔蒙小姐了，我们今晚去迪龙瑟雷院长家去吧，”格朗松太太说，
en: “Well, we will go this evening to the du Roncerets’, inasmuch as we have lost Mademoiselle Cormon,” said Madame Granson.

zh: “天哪！我永远不会习惯管她叫迪布斯基耶夫人的。这个称呼真让我觉得别扭。”阿塔纳斯神情抑郁地望了母亲一眼，他再也笑不出来了。他产生了一个天真的念头，这个念头能抚慰他的创伤，却医治不了他的痛苦。他倒不排斥这个念头。
en: “Heavens! How shall I ever accustom myself to call her Madame du Bousquier! That name burns my lips.”Athanase looked at his mother with a constrained and melancholy air; he could not smile; but he seemed to wish to welcome that naive sentiment which soothed his wound, though it could not cure his anguish.

zh: “妈妈，”他像孩子一样温柔地喊道，他已经多年不用这个称呼了，“我亲爱的妈妈，我们先不要出门吧；在火炉前坐着多舒服呀。”
en: “Mamma,” he said, in the voice of his childhood, so tender was it, and using the name he had abandoned for several years,—“my dear mamma, do not let us go out just yet; it is so pleasant here before the fire.”

zh: 这位母亲听见了，却没有理解这是一个忍受着致命痛苦的人发出的最后祈求。
en: The mother heard, without comprehending, that supreme prayer of a mortal sorrow.

zh: “好吧，我们再呆会儿吧，孩子，”她说，“比起玩波士顿还可能输钱，我当然更愿意和你聊天，听听你的计划。”
en: “Yes, let us stay, my child,” she said.“I like much better to talk with you and listen to your projects than to play at boston and lose my money.”

zh: “你今晚真漂亮，我喜欢看着你。而且，我现在很多想法都和这可怜的小客厅融合在一起了。我们在这儿受了太多苦了。”
en: “You are so handsome to-night I love to look at you.Besides, I am in a current of ideas which harmonize with this poor little salon where we have suffered so much.”

zh: “而且我们今后还要受苦，我可怜的阿塔纳斯，一直要等到你的作品获得成功。我倒没有关系，穷惯了；可是你，我的宝贝！眼看着你的青春年华逝去，毫无快乐！我可怜的孩子生活里只有艰辛的工作！一个母亲一想到这些就很难过呀，这些事晚上折磨我，早上又把我惊醒。哦，上帝呀！我做错了什么？因为什么罪过你要这样惩罚我呀？”她离开自己的沙发，搬了一张小椅子，坐在阿塔纳斯身边，好把她的头依偎在她孩子的胸前。真正的母爱总是有让人动情之处。阿塔纳斯亲吻了母亲的眼睛，亲吻了母亲花白的头发，亲吻了母亲的前额，怀着一份神圣的意愿，要在凡是嘴唇能接触的地方，都留下自己的感情。
en: “And where we shall still suffer, my poor Athanase, until your works succeed.For myself, I am trained to poverty; but you, my treasure! To see your youth go by without a joy! Nothing but toil for my poor boy in life!That thought is like an illness to a mother; it tortures me at night; it wakes me in the morning.O God! What have I done? For what crime dost thou punish me for thus?”She left her sofa, took a little chair, and sat close to Athanase, so as to lay her head on the bosom of her child.There is always the grace of love in true motherhood.Athanase kissed her on the eyes, on her gray hair, on her forehead, with the sacred desire of laying his soul wherever he applied his lips.

zh: “我永远不会成功的。”他说道，极力地要瞒住母亲他脑中正在做出的一个致命决定。
en: “I shall never succeed,” he said, trying to deceive his mother as to the fatal resolution he was revolving in his mind.

zh: “哎呀！不要灰心啊。正如你经常说的，思想可以成就一切。只要十大瓶墨水，十令纸，加上顽强的意志，路德把整个欧洲都颠覆了。好了，你会出名的；你用同样的手段来行善，而他却用来作恶。你不是这样说过的吗？你看我一直都认真听你说的话，我比你想得还更理解你呢。因为我觉得我还在腹中怀着你，你的任何想法都会对我产生影响，就像曾经你轻轻一动，都会在我腹中引起反应一样。”
en: “Pooh! Don’t get discouraged.As you often say, thought can do all things.With ten bottles of ink, ten reams of paper, and his powerful will, Luther upset all Europe.Well, you’ll make yourself famous; you will do good things by the same means which he used to do evil things.Haven’t you said so yourself?For my part, I listen to you; I understand you a great deal more than you think I do,—for I still bear you in my bosom, and your every thought still stirs me as your slightest motion did in other days.”

zh: “我在这儿永远不会成功的，妈妈；我不想让你看到我的挣扎，我的不幸，我的痛苦。啊，母亲，您让我离开阿郎松吧！我想到远离您的地方去受苦。”
en: “I shall never succeed here, mamma; and I don’t want you to witness the sight of my struggles, my misery, my anguish.Oh, mother, let me leave Alencon!I want to suffer away from you.”

zh: “我愿意呆在你的身边，”母亲骄傲地说，“没有母亲陪着你受苦怎么行呢！必要的话，你可怜的母亲可以当你的女仆；你要求的话，你可怜的母亲会躲起来而不会伤害你；你的母亲永远不会让你感到羞愧。不，不，阿塔纳斯，我们一定不能分离。”
en: “And I wish to be at your side,” replied his mother, proudly.“Suffer without your mother!—that poor mother who would be your servant if necessary; who will efface herself rather than injure you; your mother, who will never shame you.No, no, Athanase; we must not part.”

zh: 阿塔纳斯以一个垂死之人拥抱生命的热情拥抱了他的母亲。
en: Athanase clung to his mother with the ardor of a dying man who clings to life.

zh: “尽管如此，我还是想要走。否则，你就会失去我；这双重的痛苦，你的痛苦和我的痛苦，会折磨死我的。你总希望我活着的吧？”
en: “But I wish it, nevertheless.If not, you will lose me; this double grief, yours and mine, is killing me.You would rather I lived than died?”

zh: 格朗松太太神色惊慌地看着儿子。
en: Madame Granson looked at her son with a haggard eye.

zh: “这就是你心里一直在想的吗？”她说，“看来别人说的是对的。你真的要走吗？”
en: “So this is what you have been brooding?” she said.“They told me right.Do you really mean to go?”

zh: “是的。”
en: “Yes.”

zh: “你不会不和我说明白、不和我打招呼就走吧。你也必须要带上衣服和钱才能走呀。我还有几个金路易缝在我的衬裙里，我把它们给你。”
en: “You will not go without telling me; without warning me?You must have an outfit and money.I have some louis sewn into my petticoat; I shall give them to you.”

zh: 阿塔纳斯哭了。
en: Athanase wept.

zh: “这就是我要对你说的话，”他说，“我现在送你到法院院长家去吧。走吧。”
en: “That’s all I wanted to tell you,” he said.“Now I’ll take you to the du Roncerets’.Come.”

zh: 母子二人出门了。阿塔纳斯送母亲到了那户人家的门口，她打算在那里打发晚上的时间。他紧紧靠在墙上，久久望着百叶窗缝里透出来的灯光。一会儿，他听到他妈妈说“他拥有极其独立”，他感到一阵莫名的狂喜。
en: The mother and the son went out.Athanase left his mother at the door of the house where she intended to pass the evening.He looked long at the light which came through the shutters; he clung closely to the wall, and a frenzied joy came over him when he presently heard his mother say, “He has great independence of heart.”

zh: “可怜的母亲！我骗了她。”他走到萨尔特河边时，大喊道。
en: “Poor mother!I have deceived her,” he cried, as he made his way to the Sarthe.

zh: 他走到了那棵美丽的白杨树下，在过去的四十天里，他在这里思考了多少问题呀！他还搬来了两块大石头，以便坐在上面。他欣赏了明媚的月光映照下的自然美景；他再次重温了他所渴望的全部的辉煌未来；他走过为他的名字所轰动的城市；他听到人们热烈的掌声；他呼吸着自己名望的气息；他热爱自己梦寐以求的一生；他兴高采烈地向辉煌的胜利奔去；他为自己树立了雕像；他忆起了自己全部的幻想，好在最后一次奥林匹斯诸神宴会上向它们告别。这种魔法曾一度是可能的，但是现在永远失效了。在这最后的时刻，他紧紧抱住那棵美丽的大树，他一直把它当作朋友一样来迷恋。然后他把两块石头分别装进大衣的口袋里，并且扣好胸口的衣扣。他故意出门不戴帽子。现在他走向他早已选定的深水处，坚定地走进水中，尽量不弄出声响，而事实上几乎没有什么声响。
en: He reached the noble poplar beneath which he had meditated so much for the last forty days, and where he had placed two heavy stones on which he now sat down.He contemplated that beautiful nature lighted by the moon; he reviewed once more the glorious future he had longed for; he passed through towns that were stirred by his name; he heard the applauding crowds; he breathed the incense of his fame; he adored that life long dreamed of; radiant, he sprang to radiant triumphs; he raised his stature; he evoked his illusions to bid them farewell in a last Olympic feast.The magic had been potent for a moment; but now it vanished forever.In that awful hour he clung to the beautiful tree to which, as to a friend, he had attached himself; then he put the two stones into the pockets of his overcoat, which he buttoned across his breast.He had come intentionally without a hat.He now went to the deep pool he had long selected, and glided into it resolutely, trying to make as little noise as possible, and, in fact, making scarcely any.

zh: 九点半左右，格朗松太太回到家，仆人没有提到阿塔纳斯，不过交给她一封信。她打开信，看到上面写着短短几句话：
en: When, at half-past nine o’clock, Madame Granson returned home, her servant said nothing of Athanase, but gave her a letter.She opened it and read these few words,—

zh: “亲爱的母亲，我走了，不要责怪我吧。”
en: “My good mother, I have departed; don’t be angry with me.”

zh: “他怎么能这样对我！”她想道，“他的衣服！还有钱呢！
en: “A pretty trick he has played me!” she thought.“And his linen! and the money!

zh: 好吧，他会给我写信的，到时我再去找他。这些可怜的孩子，总以为自己会比他们的爸妈聪明。”
en: Well, he will write to me, and then I’ll follow him.These poor children think they are so much cleverer than their fathers and mothers.”

zh: 于是她安心地去睡觉了。
en: And she went to bed in peace.

zh: 次日早上，萨尔特河如渔夫们预料的一样涨水了。涨水时会把鳗鱼从河的泥沟里给卷了出来。一个渔夫撒网，碰巧撒在可怜的阿塔纳斯跳进去的地方。阿塔纳斯还以为别人永远找不到他呢。清晨六点钟，渔夫用网将这年轻人的尸体拖了回来。这位可怜的母亲的两三位好友小心谨慎地采取各种方法，以便让她有点思想准备来面对这可怕的遗体。可以想见，这一自杀事件在阿郎松引起了极大的反响。这可怜的年轻人前一晚还没有一个保护人，但在他死后的第二天，千百个声音在大喊说：“我本来可以帮帮他的。”白送人情的假慈悲，可以很容易又方便地装出来!
en: During the preceding morning the Sarthe had risen to a height foreseen by the fisherman.These sudden rises of muddy water brought eels from their various runlets.It so happened that a fisherman had spread his net at the very place where poor Athanase had flung himself, believing that no one would ever find him.About six o’clock in the morning the man drew in his net, and with it the young body.The few friends of the poor mother took every precaution in preparing her to receive the dreadful remains.The news of this suicide made, as may well be supposed, a great excitement in Alencon.The poor young man of genius had no protector the night before, but on the morrow of his death a thousand voices cried aloud, “I would have helped him.”It is so easy and convenient to be charitable gratis!

zh: 德瓦卢瓦骑士解释了这一自杀事件。他怀着报复的想法，揭示了阿塔纳斯对科尔蒙小姐怀着多么天真、诚挚而又美好的爱情。格朗松太太受到骑士的提醒，记起了千百件小事，证明骑士说的都是真的。于是这成了很凄婉感人的故事，很多女人都为之洒泪。格朗松太太的悲痛并不外露，而是集中在自己心里，很少有人能够理解。丧子的母亲有两种悲痛方式。通常，世人完全明白她们损失的是什么：她们的儿子平时受人器重，受人赏识，年轻或者俊朗，有着前途无量的未来，会成为大富翁，也有可能成名。他的去世让人普遍感到惋惜，世人会分担这悲哀，在扩大哀痛的同时也减轻了母亲的哀痛。但还有一种情况，只有母亲才真正了解自己的孩子，只有母亲才看到过儿子的微笑，只有母亲才知道这个夭折的生命中蕴藏着什么珍宝。这种痛苦常把它的悲伤隐藏起来，但是悲伤的黑色却使其他的丧事都黯然失色。这种哀痛很难用语言形容，所幸遭受此种痛苦的女性很少。
