en: The suicide was explained by the Chevalier de Valois.He revealed, in a spirit of revenge, the artless, sincere, and genuine love of Athanase for Mademoiselle Cormon.Madame Granson, enlightened by the chevalier, remembered a thousand little circumstances which confirmed the chevalier’s statement.The story then became touching, and many women wept over it.Madame Granson’s grief was silent, concentrated, and little understood.There are two forms of mourning for mothers.Often the world can enter fully into the nature of their loss: their son, admired, appreciated, young, perhaps handsome, with a noble path before him, leading to fortune, possibly to fame, excites universal regret; society joins in the grief, and alleviates while it magnifies it.But there is another sorrow of mothers who alone know what their child was really; who alone have received his smiles and observed the treasures of a life too soon cut short.That sorrow hides its woe, the blackness of which surpasses all other mourning; it cannot be described; happily there are but few women whose heart-strings are thus severed.

zh: 迪布斯基耶夫人回城以前，就有一位好友，迪龙瑟雷法院院长的太太到普雷博戴去，将这具尸体扔到她欢乐的玫瑰花上，告诉她她曾经忽视了的爱情，并且温柔地在她新婚蜜月的蜂蜜上撒上了千百滴苦艾酒。迪布斯基耶夫人回到阿郎松后，在瓦诺布勒街拐角上碰见了格朗松太太。那位母亲哀莫大于心死的目光刺在了这可怜的女人的心上。那目光凝聚了千种诅咒、万种斥责，那目光向她预言了不幸，并且召唤着不幸降临到她身上，把迪布斯基耶夫人吓坏了。
en: Before Madame du Bousquier returned to town, Madame du Ronceret, one of her good friends, had driven out to Prebaudet to fling this corpse upon the roses of her joy, to show her the love she had ignored, and sweetly shed a thousand drops of wormwood into the honey of her bridal month.As Madame du Bousquier drove back to Alencon, she chanced to meet Madame Granson at the corner of the rue Val-Noble.The glance of the mother, dying of her grief, struck to the heart of the poor woman.A thousand maledictions, a thousand flaming reproaches, were in that look: Madame du Bousquier was horror-struck; that glance predicted and called down evil upon her head.

zh: 格朗松太太是最反对这座城市里的神父的人之一，她一直支持圣莱奥纳尔教堂的牧师。灾难降临后的第二天晚上，当她想到自己一派一向宣扬的不可改变的天主教教义时，就开始浑身发抖。她心中想着救世主的母亲，亲手将儿子的尸体用裹尸布裹好，然后怀着忐忑不安的沉重心情走到她一直憎恨的那位神父家里去。她看见这位清贫的教士正在外屋里忙着储存大麻和亚麻，准备交给城里所有贫苦的女人们，将麻纺成线，以免她们没有活干。这种慈善的举动拯救了许多无法沿街乞讨的贫苦之人。神父见到格朗松太太，急忙放下活，领着格朗松太太到饭厅里坐下。这位不幸的母亲看到神父的晚餐，知道他也过着和自己一样节俭的生活。
en: The evening after the catastrophe, Madame Granson, one of the persons most opposed to the rector of the town, and who had hitherto supported the minister of Saint-Leonard, began to tremble as she thought of the inflexible Catholic doctrines professed by her own party.After placing her son’s body in its shroud with her own hands, thinking of the mother of the Saviour, she went, with a soul convulsed by anguish, to the house of the hated rector.There she found the modest priest in an outer room, engaged in putting away the flax and yarns with which he supplied poor women, in order that they might never be wholly out of work,—a form of charity which saved many who were incapable of begging from actual penury.The rector left his yarns and hastened to take Madame Granson into his dining-room, where the wretched mother noticed, as she looked at his supper, the frugal method of his own living.

zh: “教士先生，”她说，“我来这儿是要恳求您——”她泣不成声，说不下去了。
en: “Monsieur l’abbe,” she said, “I have come to implore you—” She burst into tears, unable to continue.

zh: “我知道您来是为了什么事，”教士回答道，“太太，我相信您和您的亲戚迪布斯基耶夫人，可以使赛镇主教在这个问题上不予以追究。对，我一定为您可怜的孩子祈祷；是的，我会为他作弥撒。但是我们一定要避免任何的闲言闲语，不给机会让城里的恶人聚到教堂里来。只有我一个人，不要别的教士，在晚上——”
en: “I know what brings you,” replied the saintly man.“I must trust to you, madame, and to your relation, Madame du Bousquier, to pacify Monseigneur the Bishop at Seez.Yes, I will pray for your unhappy child; yes, I will say the masses.But we must avoid all scandal, and give no opportunity for evil-judging persons to assemble in the church.I alone, without other clergy, at night—”

zh: “好，好，由您安排，只要能让他踏上圣土就好。”可怜的母亲拉着教士的手亲吻着说道。
en: “Yes, yes, as you think best; if only he may lie in consecrated ground,” said the poor mother, taking the priest’s hand and kissing it.

zh: 在午夜时分，阿塔纳斯生前最喜欢的四位年轻人悄悄地抬着棺材来到郊区。在那里有几位格朗松太太的女友，都穿着黑衣，戴着面纱；还有几位年轻人，也曾与这位死去的才子交往密切。棺材上罩着黑纱，上面点着四只大蜡烛。在一位嘴很严实的唱诗班孩子的协助下，教士做了追思弥撒。然后，人们无声地将自杀者的棺材抬到了墓地的一角。那里竖着一个发黑了的木头十字架，没有墓志，作用就是告诉母亲，这里以后就是死者的位置了。阿塔纳斯生前不被人关注，死后也不引人注目。没有人责备神父，主教也对此保持沉默。母亲的虔诚补救了儿子自杀的大不敬行为。
en: Toward midnight a coffin was clandestinely borne to the parish church by four young men, comrades whom Athanase had liked the best.A few friends of Madame Granson, women dressed in black, and veiled, were present; and half a dozen other young men who had been somewhat intimate with this lost genius.Four torches flickered on the coffin, which was covered with crape.The rector, assisted by one discreet choirboy, said the mortuary mass.Then the body of the suicide was noiselessly carried to a corner of the cemetery, where a black wooden cross, without inscription, was all that indicated its place hereafter to the mother.Athanase lived and died in shadow.No voice was raised to blame the rector; the bishop kept silence.The piety of the mother redeemed the impiety of the son’s last act.

zh: 几个月后，这可怜的女人，痛苦得几乎精神失常，像不幸的人渴望把嘴唇探进他们的苦杯中一样，决定要去看看儿子投水自尽的地方。也许是她的本能告诉她，在那株白杨树下，还能勾起对儿子的思念；也许是她渴望能看看儿子生前最后一次看见的景物。有的母亲会触景伤情地死去，而有的母亲会沉湎于圣洁的爱慕之情中。对于有些事情，教育、法律和哲学体系都是说不通的，耐心的人性分析学者自然也不能确切地说明这样的事情。我们可以反复说：想把人的感情归入一种模式是很荒谬的。感情到了每一个人身上，都会与其自身特有的素质相结合，形成独特的形式。
en: Some months later, the poor woman, half beside herself with grief, and moved by one of those inexplicable thirsts which misery feels to steep its lips in the bitter chalice, determined to see the spot where her son was drowned.Her instinct may have told her that thoughts of his could be recovered beneath that poplar; perhaps, too, she desired to see what his eyes had seen for the last time.Some mothers would die of the sight; others give themselves up to it in saintly adoration.Patient anatomists of human nature cannot too often enunciate the truths before which all educations, laws, and philosophical systems must give way.Let us repeat continually: it is absurd to force sentiments into one formula: appearing as they do, in each individual man, they combine with the elements that form his nature and take his own physiognomy.

zh: 格朗松太太来到了阿塔纳斯丧命的地方，看见一个女子走过来，大声说道：
en: Madame Granson, as she stood on that fatal spot, saw a woman approach it, who exclaimed,—

zh: “是这里吗？”
en: “Was it here?”

zh: 那女人和这位母亲一样泣不成声。她就是苏珊。抵达摩尔旅店时，苏珊就得知了这件祸事。如果可怜的阿塔纳斯还活着，她会做出许多心灵高尚却身无分文之人幻想做的事，也是富人从未想过的事：她会给他寄上几千法郎，信封上会写着：“此为一同伴所欠令尊之款，现特奉还与你。”这是苏珊在旅途中便已想好了的。
en: That woman wept as the mother wept.It was Suzanne.Arriving that morning at the hotel du More, she had been told of the catastrophe.If poor Athanase had been living, she meant to do as many noble souls, who are moneyless, dream of doing, and as the rich never think of doing,—she meant to have sent him several thousand francs, writing up the envelope the words: “Money due to your father from a comrade who makes restitution to you.”This tender scheme had been arranged by Suzanne during her journey.

zh: 这个交际花远远望见格朗松太太便匆匆离去，走过她身边时低声说：“我是爱过他的！”
en: The courtesan caught sight of Madame Granson and moved rapidly away, whispering as she passed her, “I loved him!”

zh: 苏珊始终本性不改，她不把新娘头上的橙花变成睡莲花，是不会离开阿郎松城的。她是第一个扬言说，迪布斯基耶夫人将永远都只是科尔蒙小姐。她这一席恶言恶语算是为阿塔纳斯和亲爱的骑士报仇了。
en: Suzanne, faithful to her nature, did not leave Alencon on this occasion without changing the orange-blossoms of the bride to rue.She was the first to declare that Madame du Bousquier would never be anything but Mademoiselle Cormon.With one stab of her tongue she revenged poor Athanase and her dear chevalier.

zh: 社交界很快就忘记了他们当中死去的人，阿塔纳斯确实很快就被人们遗忘了。现在阿郎松城又在亲眼目睹另一桩性质不同于阿塔纳斯的可怜的慢性自杀。可怜的德瓦卢瓦骑士每天虽生犹死，他这十四年的生活都是在自杀。迪布斯基耶结婚三个月后，大家都惊讶地发现，骑士的衬衣变成了橙黄色，头发也不怎么梳理了。现在他已是蓬头垢面，从前的德瓦卢瓦骑士不复存在了。他的几颗象牙色的牙齿不见了，即使善于观察的人也不能发现那几颗牙齿到底是属于哪里的。是外部的还是自身的，植物性的还是动物性的，是年龄大了掉了，还是骑士将牙齿忘在他梳妆台的抽屉里了。他的领结也打歪了，完全不优雅了。黑人头耳环由于尘土和油脂而变得发白。骑士脸上的皱纹成了深沟，愈发黑了，皮肤也成了羊皮纸一般。那些经常被忽视的指甲，天哪！经常可以看到镶了一道黑丝绒的边。
en: Alencon now witnessed a suicide that was slower and quite differently pitiful from that of poor Athanase, who was quickly forgotten by society, which always makes haste to forget its dead.The poor Chevalier de Valois died in life; his suicide was a daily occurrence for fourteen years.Three months after the du Bousquier marriage society remarked, not without astonishment, that the linen of the chevalier was frayed and rusty, that his hair was irregularly combed and brushed.With a frowsy head the Chevalier de Valois could no longer be said to exist!A few of his ivory teeth deserted, though the keenest observers of human life were unable to discover to what body they had hitherto belonged, whether to a foreign legion or whether they were indigenous, vegetable or animal; whether age had pulled them from the chevalier’s mouth, or whether they were left forgotten in the drawer of his dressing-table.The cravat was crooked, indifferent to elegance.The negroes’ heads grew pale with dust and grease.The wrinkles of the face were blackened and puckered; the skin became parchment.The nails, neglected, were often seen, alas! with a black velvet edging.

zh: 马甲上一条条没有擦掉的鼻涕就挂在那里，好像秋天的落叶一般。耳朵里的棉花也是难得换一次。忧伤停在他的额头上，将黄色注入每条皱纹的深沟里。总之，透过这栋漂亮的建筑物的千疮百孔，从前被十分巧妙地遮掩住的废墟，现在已经一览无遗，这足以说明人的精神力量对身体的影响有多大。一旦希望破灭，曾经的金发美男子、骑士、青春少年都死亡了。在那以前，骑士的鼻子一直是很优雅的，从没有出现过鼻屎或是流过鼻涕。可是现在，鼻烟蔓延到了鼻孔下面，到处都是；鼻涕利用嘴巴上面的天然滴水管流下来，非常不雅——这个鼻子再也不在乎是否显得可爱了。可见骑士从前对自己的外表是多么讲究呀，人们也可以从中了解到，他对科尔蒙小姐是多么用心良苦，投入了多大的毅力。
en: The waistcoat was tracked and stained with droppings which spread upon its surface like autumn leaves.The cotton in the ears was seldom changed.Sadness reigned upon that brow, and slipped its yellowing tints into the depths of each furrow.In short, the ruins, hitherto so cleverly hidden, now showed through the cracks and crevices of that fine edifice, and proved the power of the soul over the body; for the fair and dainty man, the cavalier, the young blood, died when hope deserted him.Until then the nose of the chevalier was ever delicate and nice; never had a damp black blotch, nor an amber drop fall from it; but now that nose, smeared with tobacco around the nostrils, degraded by the driblets which took advantage of the natural gutter placed between itself and the upper lip,—that nose, which no longer cared to seem agreeable, revealed the infinite pains which the chevalier had formerly taken with his person, and made observers comprehend, by the extent of its degradation, the greatness and persistence of the man’s designs upon Mademoiselle Cormon.

zh: 哎，连他的牙齿人们也编出了很多逸闻趣事；骑士诙谐的言谈也越来越少了。尽管如此，他的胃口却没变，骑士把他的肠胃从这希望全毁的浩劫里给救出来了。虽然他准备鼻烟时有气无力，可是饭量倒是挺惊人的。骑士现在很少和戈里扎公主谈话了，由此诸位可以了解到科尔蒙小姐的婚事在思想和精神上对他造成了多大的灾难。
en: Alas, too, the anecdotes went the way of the teeth; the clever sayings grew rare.The appetite, however, remained; the old nobleman saved nothing but his stomach from the wreck of his hopes; though he languidly prepared his pinches of snuff, he ate alarming dinners.Perhaps you will more fully understand the disaster that this marriage was to the mind and heart of the chevalier when you learn that his intercourse with the Princess Goritza became less frequent.

zh: 一天，他到阿芒德小姐家，他裤子的小腿肚子部分扭到了小腿前头。骑士如此不修边幅，我向你保证，这惊恐了整个阿郎松城。这个原本还是小伙子的人突然变得老态龙钟了，内心的消沉让他从五十岁一下变成了九十岁，吓坏了所有的人。而且，他也道出了自己的秘密，说他曾经等待科尔蒙小姐，希望能娶到她。他就像是个耐心的猎手，花了十年的时间来瞄准自己的目标，却最终没有击中猎物！总之，并不强大的共和国在复辟时期打败了勇敢的骑士！形式取得了胜利，物质战胜了精神，暴动胜过了外交。
en: One day he appeared in Mademoiselle Armande’s salon with the calf of his leg on the shin-bone.This bankruptcy of the graces was, I do assure you, terrible, and struck all Alencon with horror.The late young man had become an old one; this human being, who, by the breaking-down of his spirit, had passed at once from fifty to ninety years of age, frightened society.Besides, his secret was betrayed; he had waited and watched for Mademoiselle Cormon; he had, like a patient hunter, adjusted his aim for ten whole years, and finally had missed the game!In short, the impotent Republic had won the day from Valiant Chivalry, and that, too, under the Restoration!Form triumphed; mind was vanquished by matter, diplomacy by insurrection.

zh: 还有更致命的一击呢！一位自尊心受伤的女工，泄露了骑士每天上午怎样度过的秘密，现在大家都把他当作一个浪荡子。现在自由党人把以前说是迪布斯基耶的那些私生子栽赃到骑士的头上。阿郎松的圣日耳曼区倒是很得意地接受了这种传言，他们说：“这可怜的骑士，他还能干什么别的事呢？”他们很可怜骑士，把他纳入他们的圈子，重新唤起了他脸上偶尔的微笑，同时也激起了他对迪布斯基耶的痛恨。有十一个人离开了科尔蒙沙龙，转而加入德埃斯格里尼翁家去了。
en: And, O final blow! A mortified grisette revealed the secret of the chevalier’s mornings, and he now passed for a libertine.The liberals cast at his door all the foundlings hitherto attributed to du Bousquier.But the faubourg Saint-Germain of Alencon accepted them proudly: it even said, “That poor chevalier, what else could he do?”The faubourg pitied him, gathered him closer to their circle, and brought back a few rare smiles to his face; but frightful enmity was piled upon the head of du Bousquier.Eleven persons deserted the Cormon salon, and passed to that of the d’Esgrignons.

zh: 老姑娘的婚事产生的一个重要的影响是，阿郎松明显分出了两党派。德埃斯格里尼翁家代表着高等贵族（特雷维尔一家人回来以后也归附那边了）；科尔蒙家在迪布斯基耶巧妙的影响下，代表着既不完全的自由派，又非忠贞的保王派，产生了二百二十一名反对党议员那种糟糕的见解。当时，最有尊严的、最伟大的、唯一真正的政权——王权，与最虚假的、最不可捉摸的、最压榨人的政权——经过选举产生的议会所行使的所谓议会权利，这二者在那著名的一天公开斗争，于是在这种情形下，产生了二百二十一人。迪龙瑟雷沙龙暗中和科尔蒙沙龙联盟，属于大胆的自由派。
en: The old maid’s marriage had a signal effect in defining the two parties in Alencon.The salon d’Esgrignon represented the upper aristocracy (the returning Troisvilles attached themselves to it); the Cormon salon represented, under the clever influence of du Bousquier, that fatal class of opinions which, without being truly liberal or resolutely royalist, gave birth to the 221 on that famous day when the struggle openly began between the most august, grandest, and only true power, ROYALTY, and the most false, most changeful, most oppressive of all powers,—the power called PARLIAMENTARY, which elective assemblies exercise.The salon du Ronceret, secretly allied to the Cormon salon, was boldly liberal.

zh: 德斯蓬德神父从普雷博戴回来后，一直闷闷不乐。他将这所有的不快都压在心底，不会在他外甥女面前提半句。但是他却对阿芒德小姐敞开心扉，坦白说，就算是荒唐，他总觉得德瓦卢瓦骑士比迪布斯基耶先生好得多。他这可怜的老头也活不了多少天了，换作是亲爱的骑士，就绝对不会情调低下地使他烦闷了，而迪布斯基耶把好好的老宅中的一切都破坏了。神父已经无神的眼中淌着几滴老泪，说道：
en: The Abbe de Sponde, after his return from Prebaudet, bore many and continual sufferings, which he kept within his breast, saying no word of them to his niece.But to Mademoiselle Armande he opened his heart, admitting that, folly for folly, he would much have preferred the Chevalier de Valois to Monsieur du Bousquier.Never would the dear chevalier have had the bad taste to contradict and oppose a poor old man who had but a few days more to live; du Bousquier had destroyed everything in the good old home.The abbe said, with scanty tears moistening his aged eyes,—

zh: “小姐，现在连我自由行走了五十年的小树林都没有了。我最心爱的菩提树全被砍掉了！等我闭眼的时候，共和国也会以这种搅得天翻地覆的形式出现在我面前的。”
en: “Mademoiselle, I haven’t even the little grove where I have walked for fifty years.My beloved lindens are all cut down!At the moment of my death the Republic appears to me more than ever under the form of a horrible destruction of the Home.”

zh: “您要原谅您的外甥女，”德瓦卢瓦骑士说，“共和思想是追求自由的年轻人误入歧途的第一步，他们后来发现自由是最残暴的专横，是那些没有本事的无赖的专长。您可怜的外甥女会从她开始犯罪的地方受到惩罚的。”
en: “You must pardon your niece,” said the Chevalier de Valois.“Republican ideas are the first error of youth which seeks for liberty; later it finds it the worst of despotisms,—that of an impotent canaille.Your poor niece is punished where she sinned.”

zh: “墙上画的都是赤裸的女人，这样的房子我怎么能呆呀？”可怜的神父说，“哪里还有菩提树可以让我在树阴下念日课经呀？”
en: “What will become of me in a house where naked women are painted on the walls?” said the poor abbe.“Where shall I find other lindens beneath which to read my breviary?”

zh: 就像惯于凝望一株冷杉思考的康德一样，当那棵冷杉被砍倒以后，康德再也找不到他的思路了。善良的神父穿过没有树阴的小路时，再也没有原来那股祷告的热忱了。迪布斯基耶在那里修起了英国式的花园。
en: Like Kant, who was unable to collect his thoughts after the fir-tree at which he was accustomed to gaze while meditating was cut down, so the poor abbe could never attain the ardor of his former prayers while walking up and down the shadeless paths.Du Bousquier had planted an English garden.

zh: “这样更好了。”迪布斯基耶夫人不经思考地说。库蒂里耶神父准许她做了很多错事以取悦她的丈夫。
en: “It was best,” said Madame du Bousquier, without thinking so; but the Abbe Couterier had authorized her to commit many wrongs to please her husband.

zh: 这番修葺完全破坏了这所老房子原本古朴恬静的风貌，使其失去了原来的风采。像不修边幅、可以说是放弃了自己权利的德瓦卢瓦骑士一样，科尔蒙沙龙原来的市民阶级的庄重气派也荡然无存了。现在客厅已经变成了雪白、金黄的颜色，摆上了桃花心木的土耳其长沙发，装上了蓝色丝绸的帷幔。饭厅被装饰成了现代化的风格，色调不如以前温暖了，饭菜也不像以前一样吃得那么舒服了。迪库徳赖先生甚至说他感觉墙上画的人像是惊恐地瞪着他，以至于他的俏皮话都被卡在喉咙里，说出不来了。房屋的外部仍然是外省的风格，但是房屋内已经完全是执政府时期商人的风格，散发的全都是经纪人的低俗趣味——例如，粉饰灰泥廊柱、镜子门、希腊式模具、毫无意义的装饰轮廓，各类风格掺杂，透着不合时宜、不合时令的华丽。
en: These restorations destroyed all the venerable dignity, cordiality, and patriarchal air of the old house.Like the Chevalier de Valois, whose personal neglect might be called an abdication, the bourgeois dignity of the Cormon salon no longer existed when it was turned to white and gold, with mahogany ottomans covered in blue satin.The dining-room, adorned in modern taste, was colder in tone than it used to be, and the dinners were eaten with less appetite than formerly.Monsieur du Coudrai declared that he felt his puns stick in his throat as he glanced at the figures painted on the walls, which looked him out of countenance.Externally, the house was still provincial; but internally everything revealed the purveyor of the Directory and the bad taste of the money-changer,—for instance, columns in stucco, glass doors, Greek mouldings, meaningless outlines, all styles conglomerated, magnificence out of place and out of season.

zh: 足有半月之久，阿郎松城的人对于这过分的奢侈纷纷加以恶评。可是几个月以后，他们又以此为傲了，有几家富商也重新装修了他们的房子，布置了漂亮的客厅。时髦的家具开始在城里出现，而且还能看到无影灯了！
en: The town of Alencon gabbled for two weeks over this luxury, which seemed unparalleled; but a few months later the community was proud of it, and several rich manufacturers restored their houses and set up fine salons.Modern furniture came into the town, and astral lamps were seen!

zh: 德斯蓬德神父是第一个看透这桩婚事已经给他心爱的外甥女带来不幸的人。婚后的第一个冬天，迪布斯基耶每月举办两次舞会，彻底地抹去了主宰神父和外甥女过去生活的那种高贵而单纯的特点。唉，在这神圣的老房子里，竟然听得到小提琴和交际场那种世俗的音乐！在他们寻欢作乐的时候，神父始终跪在地上祈祷。后来，这个严肃沙龙的政治体系也逐渐变味了。神父看透了迪布斯基耶的心思；他一听见迪布斯基耶专横的语调就浑身战栗。他看见外甥女眼中的泪光，因为她现在已经失去了对自己财产的控制权，她的丈夫只让她管理衣物、饭菜和其他女人应管的事情。罗丝现在已经没有发号施令的机会了。雅克兰已经成为专职车夫，勒内是专职马夫，玛丽埃特现在只是个厨房的女佣，再加上从巴黎请来的主厨，这几个人现在都只听从先生一人的命令。迪布斯基耶夫人现在只有若赛特一人可以自由使唤了。要放弃行使权利的愉悦，那会让人有多难过呀？意志的胜利对于伟大的人来说是一种令人陶醉的快乐，而对于心胸狭隘的人来说，这便是生活的全部。一定要当过失了宠的大臣，才能理解迪布斯基耶夫人被贬为完完全全的奴仆身份时所感受到的辛酸滋味。她经常违心地坐上马车，被自己不喜欢的仆人围绕，她再也不能掌管她宝贵的金钱了，虽然以前她也不怎么花钱，但是那时她知道如果她想就可以随便花。
en: The Abbe de Sponde was among the first to perceive the secret unhappiness this marriage now brought to the private life of his beloved niece.The character of noble simplicity which had hitherto ruled their lives was lost during the first winter, when du Bousquier gave two balls every month.Oh, to hear violins and profane music at these worldly entertainments in the sacred old house!The abbe prayed on his knees while the revels lasted.Next the political system of the sober salon was slowly perverted.The abbe fathomed du Bousquier; he shuddered at his imperious tone; he saw the tears in his niece’s eyes when she felt herself losing all control over her own property; for her husband now left nothing in her hands but the management of the linen, the table, and things of a kind which are the lot of women.Rose had no longer any orders to give.Monsieur’s will was alone regarded by Jacquelin, now become coachman, by Rene, the groom, and by the chef, who came from Paris, Mariette being reduced to kitchen maid.Madame du Bousquier had no one to rule but Josette.Who knows what it costs to relinquish the delights of power?If the triumph of the will is one of the intoxicating pleasures in the lives of great men, it is the ALL of life to narrow minds.One must needs have been a minister dismissed from power to comprehend the bitter pain which came upon Madame du Bousquier when she found herself reduced to this absolute servitude.She often got into the carriage against her will; she saw herself surrounded by servants who were distasteful to her; she no longer had the handling of her dear money,—she who had known herself free to spend money, and did not spend it.

zh: 所有这些强加的限制，都让人产生想要越过这些限制的强烈欲望。最强烈的痛苦便是对自由意志的阻挠。然而，所有这一切开始时都还算顺利。对丈夫做出的每一个让步，都是出于老姑娘对丈夫的爱。最初，迪布斯基耶对待妻子的做法是很讨她欢心的。他做得很聪明也很漂亮，每次他践踏女权，都给出了很充分的理由。因此，迪布斯基耶夫人婚后头两年都显得很满意。她故意显出谦恭的样子，这是为爱而结婚的少妇的特点。她也不再受血热的折磨了。这种满足的表现与关于迪布斯基耶的流言蜚语相矛盾，让那些专爱讥讽的人很狼狈，而善于观察人心灵的人也感到困惑不解。罗丝-玛丽-维克图瓦很害怕做出让丈夫不高兴的事或是冲撞他而失去他的欢心，失去他的朝夕相伴，所以她愿意为他牺牲所有，甚至包括她的舅父。她那愚昧的小小欢乐甚至也骗过了可怜的德斯蓬德神父，老人想着毕竟外甥女感到幸福，那他也就应该忍受自己的痛苦。
en: All imposed limits make the human being desire to go beyond them.The keenest sufferings come from the thwarting of self-will.The beginning of this state of things was, however, rose-colored.Every concession made to marital authority was an effect of the love which the poor woman felt for her husband.Du Bousquier behaved, in the first instance, admirably to his wife: he was wise; he was excellent; he gave her the best of reasons for each new encroachment.So for the first two years of her marriage Madame du Bousquier appeared to be satisfied.She had that deliberate, demure little air which distinguishes young women who have married for love.The rush of blood to her head no longer tormented her.This appearance of satisfaction routed the scoffers, contradicted certain rumors about du Bousquier, and puzzled all observers of the human heart.Rose-Marie-Victoire was so afraid that if she displeased her husband or opposed him, she would lose his affection and be deprived of his company, that she would willingly have sacrificed all to him, even her uncle.Her silly little forms of pleasure deceived even the poor abbe for a time, who endured his own trials all the better for thinking that his niece was happy, after all.

zh: 阿郎松人最初也都是这么想的。但是有一个人，你就是骗得了全城的人，也骗不过他。德瓦卢瓦骑士躲在高等贵族的圣山上，终日在埃斯格里尼翁家里打发时间。他听着人们各式各样的饶舌和流言蜚语，日夜想着他应该怎样复仇。他想打击迪布斯基耶，正中其心脏。
en: Alencon at first thought the same.But there was one man more difficult to deceive than the whole town put together.The Chevalier de Valois, who had taken refuge on the Sacred Mount of the upper aristocracy, now passed his life at the d’Esgrignons.He listened to the gossip and the gabble, and he thought day and night upon his vengeance.He meant to strike du Bousquier to the heart.

zh: 可怜的神父也完全明白了外甥女在这第一次也是最后一次恋爱中的怯弱，他正一点一点地看透这个外甥女婿的虚伪本性和毒辣手段，气得浑身战栗。尽管迪布斯基耶因为想到要继承舅老爷的财产，还是比较克制自己，不想激怒他，但还是给了这老神父致命的一击，将他送进了坟墓。如果你用“有坚强的原则”来解释“偏狭”一词，如果你不想谴责德斯蓬德神父的禁欲主义（瓦尔特·司各特曾通过珍妮·迪恩斯的父亲这个清教徒，使人们对禁欲主义非常敬佩），如果你想在罗马教会中理解“宁死不受辱”的精神——你很欣赏共和派见解中的这一点，当斯蓬德神父看见那个离经叛道、归属异端、信奉异教的神父、教会的敌人、宣誓忠于《教士的公民组织法》的那个家伙出现在他外甥女婿的客厅里时，你就能够理解他的心情了。迪布斯基耶怀着要在这地方称王称霸的野心，想要促成圣莱奥纳尔教堂的主持和郊区的神父和解，并以此作为他能力的初步证明，他的目的达成了。他的妻子以为他是完成了一桩促进和平的大业，而坚定不移的神父只认为这是离经叛道。主教来到迪布斯基耶家中，似乎很满意双方敌对行为的终止。高乃依的剧本中有一句台词是：“主呀，你使我憎恨多少高尚的品德呀！”除了可以和高乃依一起高喊这句话的老罗马天主教徒之外，弗朗索瓦教士的高尚品德已经战胜了偏见。正教在教区里消亡的时候，德斯蓬德神父便去世了。
en: The poor abbe fully understood the baseness of this first and last love of his niece; he shuddered as, little by little, he perceived the hypocritical nature of his nephew and his treacherous manoeuvres.Though du Bousquier restrained himself, as he thought of the abbe’s property, and wished not to cause him vexation, it was his hand that dealt the blow that sent the old priest to his grave.If you will interpret the word INTOLERANCE as FIRMNESS OF PRINCIPLE, if you do not wish to condemn in the catholic soul of the Abbe de Sponde the stoicism which Walter Scott has made you admire in the puritan soul of Jeanie Deans’ father; if you are willing to recognize in the Roman Church the Potius mori quam foedari that you admire in republican tenets,—you will understand the sorrow of the Abbe de Sponde when he saw in his niece’s salon the apostate priest, the renegade, the pervert, the heretic, that enemy of the Church, the guilty taker of the Constitutional oath.Du Bousquier, whose secret ambition was to lay down the law to the town, wished, as a first proof of his power, to reconcile the minister of Saint-Leonard with the rector of the parish, and he succeeded.His wife thought he had accomplished a work of peace where the immovable abbe saw only treachery.The bishop came to visit du Bousquier, and seemed glad of the cessation of hostilities.The virtues of the Abbe Francois had conquered prejudice, except that of the aged Roman Catholic, who exclaimed with Cornelle, “Alas! what virtues do you make me hate!”The abbe died when orthodoxy thus expired in the diocese.

zh: 到了一八一九年，德斯蓬德神父的遗产让迪布斯基耶夫人的土地收入增加到了二万五千法郎，这还没有包括普雷博戴的土地和瓦诺布勒的房产。这时，迪布斯基耶把从前她妻子交出的积蓄还给了她，让她用这笔钱去购买普雷博戴四周的地产。如此，就把这片领地扩大成全省最大的领地了，因为德斯蓬德神父的土地也与之相毗连。于是迪布斯基耶成了全省最大的财主之一。这个精明人一直是自由党的候选人，却在复辟时期的每次竞选中都以七八票之差落选。后来他干脆公然抛弃自由党，想被选为保王党大臣。虽然圣会和司法界都支持他，但他却从来未能克服国家行政管理部门对他的厌恶。这个满怀仇恨和疯狂野心的共和党人，决心在保王党与贵族在当地获胜的时候，和他们争个高低。他通过假装虔诚的一系列行为赢得了教会的支持：他陪妻子去弥撒，他给该城的修道院捐款，他支持圣心派教会，在每个教会和城镇、省或国家对立的场合中他都表态支持教会。于是他暗中受到自由党的支持，又受到教会的保护，他一直保持君主立宪派的立场，不断地与省内的贵族竞争，以期搞垮贵族，并最终将贵族搞垮。他时刻留心贵族老爷们和政府犯下的错误，逐步有计划地实施他对那些拥有城堡的人，特别是埃斯格里尼翁家族的报复，有朝一日他要将蘸着毒汁的匕首刺进这些人的胸膛。
en: In 1819, the property of the Abbe de Sponde increased Madame du Bousquier’s income from real estate to twenty-five thousand francs without counting Prebaudet or the house in the Val-Noble.About this time du Bousquier returned to his wife the capital of her savings which she had yielded to him; and he made her use it in purchasing lands contiguous to Prebaudet, which made that domain one of the most considerable in the department, for the estates of the Abbe de Sponde also adjoined it.Du Bousquier thus passed for one of the richest men of the department.This able man, the constant candidate of the liberals, missing by seven or eight votes only in all the electoral battles fought under the Restoration, and who ostensibly repudiated the liberals by trying to be elected as a ministerial royalist (without ever being able to conquer the aversion of the administration),—this rancorous republican, mad with ambition, resolved to rival the royalism and aristocracy of Alencon at the moment when they once more had the upper hand.He strengthened himself with the Church by the deceitful appearance of a well-feigned piety: he accompanied his wife to mass; he gave money for the convents of the town; he assisted the congregation of the Sacre-Coeur; he took sides with the clergy on all occasions when the clergy came into collision with the town, the department, or the State.Secretly supported by the liberals, protected by the Church, calling himself a constitutional royalist, he kept beside the aristocracy of the department in the one hope of ruining it,—and he did ruin it.Ever on the watch for the faults and blunders of the nobility and the government, he laid plans for his vengeance against the “chateau-people,” and especially against the d’Esgrignons, in whose bosom he was one day to thrust a poisoned dagger.

zh: 他对阿郎松的贡献包括慷慨地捐助阿郎松制造业的复兴，振兴了布匹贸易，并在城里建立了一个工厂。通过将自己的利益和大众利益联系起来，做这些保皇党派不会做的事，迪布斯基耶没有冒一个子儿的风险就赢得了大众人心。有他的财产作为靠山，他可以等到别人弄出成果而又因为手头拮据需要放弃的时候，再做个幸运的接手人。
en: Among other benefits to the town he gave money liberally to revive the manufacture of point d’Alencon; he renewed the trade in linens, and the town had a factory.Inscribing himself thus upon the interests and heart of the masses, by doing what the royalists did not do, du Bousquier did not really risk a farthing.Backed by his fortune, he could afford to wait results which enterprising persons who involve themselves are forced to abandon to luckier successors.

zh: 迪布斯基耶现在摆出银行家的架势。这个小号的拉斐特很有把握将各新兴产业先预定下来。他自己发财的同时，也明显给大众带来了利益。他是成立保险公司的主使者，是新公共运输企业的保护人；他建议写请愿书，要求国家管理部门修建必要的道路和桥梁。政府因此受到了警告，并认为这是对其权威的侵犯。这样的争执实在很笨拙，因为当地的利益迫使政府权威最终还是必须让步。迪布斯基耶加深了外省贵族与宫廷贵族、贵族院之间的矛盾。最后，他为君主立宪派的一大部分人参加《辩论报》和夏多步里昂先生发起的反对王权的斗争做好了思想上的准备。这《辩论报》和夏多布里昂先生，是忘恩负义、以卑劣的个人利益为出发点的反对派，也是促成一八三零年资产阶级和新闻界获得胜利的原因之一。
en: Du Bousquier now posed as a banker.This miniature Lafitte was a partner in all new enterprises, taking good security.He served himself while apparently serving the interests of the community.He was the prime mover of insurance companies, the protector of new enterprises for public conveyance; he suggested petitions for asking the administration for the necessary roads and bridges.Thus warned, the government considered this action an encroachment of its own authority.A struggle was begun injudiciously, for the good of the community compelled the authorities to yield in the end.Du Bousquier embittered the provincial nobility against the court nobility and the peerage; and finally he brought about the shocking adhesion of a strong party of constitutional royalists to the warfare sustained by the “Journal des Debats,” and M. de Chateaubriand against the throne,—an ungrateful opposition based on ignoble interests, which was one cause of the triumph of the bourgeoisie and journalism in 1830.

zh: 因而，迪布斯基耶和他所代表的阶级一样，很满足地看着君主政体的丧礼。这个在人群中压抑的老共和党，演了十五年的戏剧以便成功解决他的积怨。现在他在民众的掌声中，亲手将市政府的白旗打翻在地。对于一八三零年八月在法国竖起的新宝座，没有人会投以他那样的目光，那种陶醉于痛快的复仇之中的目光了。幼支的登台就是法国革命的胜利。对他来说，三色旗的胜利就是山岳派的复活。因为这次的行动没有从前那样粗暴，所以山岳派将以比断头台更加可靠的手段将贵族打倒。贵族院已取消了世袭权，国民自卫军将街角上的食品杂货商和侯爵安置在同一张行军床上，由一位资产阶级律师提出并取消了贵族的长子世袭财产制度，天主教会被剥夺了至高无上的权利；在迪布斯基耶看来，一八三零年八月各种立法上的新条例，就是一七九三年那些条例最明智的应用。
en: Thus du Bousquier, in common with the class he represented, had the satisfaction of beholding the funeral of royalty.The old republican, smothered with masses, who for fifteen years had played that comedy to satisfy his vendetta, himself threw down with his own hand the white flag of the mayoralty to the applause of the multitude.No man in France cast upon the new throne raised in August, 1830, a glance of more intoxicated, joyous vengeance.The accession of the Younger Branch was the triumph of the Revolution.To him the victory of the tricolor meant the resurrection of Montagne, which this time should surely bring the nobility down to the dust by means more certain than that of the guillotine, because less violent.The peerage without heredity; the National Guard, which puts on the same camp-bed the corner grocer and the marquis; the abolition of the entails demanded by a bourgeois lawyer; the Catholic Church deprived of its supremacy; and all the other legislative inventions of August, 1830,—were to du Bousquier the wisest possible application of the principles of 1793.

zh: 这个人自从一八三零年就当上了税务局局长。为了他的高升，他一直依附于和路易-菲力浦国王的父亲——奥尔良公爵的关系，以及和国王的母亲——奥尔良公爵夫人的前总管福尔蒙先生的关系。他的年收入有八万法郎左右。在人们的眼中，迪布斯基耶已经是一位有钱人，一位可敬之人，他坚守他的原则，为人正直，乐于助人。多亏了他，阿郎松才得以加入工业运动的行列，并且因此整个布列塔尼才与人们所谓的现代文明相连接起来。到一八一六年，阿郎松城已经看不见两辆干净的马车了。在这十年间，当看见敞篷四轮马车、双座四轮轿式马车、双棚四轮马车、有蓬的双轮轻便马车和两人乘坐的轻便双轮马车在街上奔驰的时候，阿郎松人也不再感到惊讶了。资产阶级和地主最初对物价上涨吓得要命，后来也意识到生活方式的提高对于他们的收入有反冲击作用。当地人都接受了迪龙瑟雷院长富有预见性的那句话：“迪布斯基耶是个非常能干的人！”
en: Since 1830 this man has been a receiver-general.He relied for his advancement on his relations with the Duc d’Orleans, father of Louis Philippe, and with Monsieur de Folmon, formerly steward to the Duchess-dowager of Orleans.He receives about eighty thousand francs a year.In the eyes of the people about him Monsieur du Bousquier is a man of means,—a respectable man, steady in his principles, upright, and obliging.Alencon owes to him its connection with the industrial movement by which Brittany may possibly some day be joined to what is popularly called modern civilization.Alencon, which up to 1816 could boast of only two private carriages, saw, without amazement, in the course of ten years, coupes, landaus, tilburies, and cabriolets rolling through her streets.The burghers and the land-owners, alarmed at first lest the price of everything should increase, recognized later that this increase in the style of living had a contrary effect upon their revenues.The prophetic remark of du Ronceret, “Du Bousquier is a very strong man,” was adopted by the whole country-side.

zh: 但是，这句话对于他妻子来说，却很不幸地具有双重意义。作为丈夫，他可完全不像那个公共政治家。这位伟大的公民，在外面那么主张自由，对当地的事业那么有热情，那么和蔼可亲，可是在家里却是专制暴君，完全缺少夫妻恩爱。这个如此奸诈、虚伪、狡猾的人，这个瓦诺布勒的克伦威尔，在家里的做法和他对贵族的做法一样，给予爱抚以期能够将其扼杀。像他的朋友贝纳多特一样，他给自己的铁手掌戴上了丝绒手套。他的妻子没有给他生下一儿半女。苏珊的话和骑士的暗示如此得到了证实。但是自由派资产阶级、君主立宪派资产阶级、乡绅、司法界和《宪政报》所说的教士派，都说是迪布斯基耶夫人的错。“她太老了，”他们说，“迪布斯基耶娶她的时候，她就很老了。况且，对于这可怜的女人来说也是幸运的，她这个年纪生孩子多危险呀！”当她在迪库徳赖夫人、迪龙瑟雷夫人面前，哭着坦白自己阶段性的失望时，这些太太们总是说：
en: But, unhappily for the wife, that saying has a double meaning.The husband does not in any way resemble the public politician.This great citizen, so liberal to the world about him, so kindly inspired with love for his native place, is a despot in his own house, and utterly devoid of conjugal affection.This man, so profoundly astute, hypocritical, and sly; this Cromwell of the Val-Noble,—behaves in his home as he behaves to the aristocracy, whom he caresses in hopes to throttle them.Like his friend Bernadotte, he wears a velvet glove upon his iron hand.His wife has given him no children.Suzanne’s remark and the chevalier’s insinuations were therefore justified.But the liberal bourgeoisie, the constitutional-royalist-bourgeoisie, the country-squires, the magistracy, and the “church party” laid the blame on Madame du Bousquier.“She was too old,” they said; “Monsieur du Bousquier had married her too late.Besides, it was very lucky for the poor woman; it was dangerous at her age to bear children!”When Madame du Bousquier confided, weeping, her periodic despair to Mesdames du Coudrai and du Ronceret, those ladies would reply,—

zh: “亲爱的，你疯了吧！你不知道你想要的是什么！生一个孩子可能会要了你的命呢！”
en: “But you are crazy, my dear; you don’t know what you are wishing for; a child would be your death.”

zh: 许多将自己的希望寄托在迪布斯基耶的胜利之上的那些男人，都在妻子们面前给他唱赞歌，因而这些妻子们也对这可怜的老姑娘说这样的话：
en: Many men, whose hopes were fastened on du Bousquier’s triumph, sang his praises to their wives, who in turn repeated them to the poor wife in some such speech as this:—

zh: “亲爱的，你真有福气呀，嫁了一个这么能干的人；你不会像别的女人那样受罪，嫁给了没有魄力的男人，既不能理财也不懂教养孩子。”
en: “You are very lucky, dear, to have married such an able man; you’ll escape the misery of women whose husbands are men without energy, incapable of managing their property, or bringing up their children.”

zh: “你的丈夫让你成了当地的皇后呀，亲爱的。他永远不会让你陷入窘境，绝对不会。哎呀，他可领导着整个阿郎松城呢！”
en: “Your husband is making you queen of the department, my love.He’ll never leave you embarrassed, not he!Why, he leads all Alencon.”

zh: “但是我希望，”可怜的妻子说道，“他能少为公众的事操心，并且——”
en: “But I wish,” said the poor wife, “that he gave less time to the public and—”

zh: “你真是太挑剔了，亲爱的迪布斯基耶夫人。我敢说，全城的女人都羡慕你有这样的好丈夫。”
en: “You are hard to please, my dear Madame du Bousquier.I assure you that all the women in town envy you your husband.”

zh: 人们不理解她并开始责怪她，于是这虔诚的基督徒在她家里给自己的美德找到了广阔的天地来表现。她生活在泪水中，但是她始终在人前露出温和的面容。对此这个基督徒一直受着一个念头的折磨：“我本来爱的是德瓦卢瓦骑士，却嫁给了迪布斯基耶。”这个念头在她的内心无异于一桩罪过。可怜的阿塔纳斯对她的爱情也像是悔恨的幽灵，一直追随她到梦中。舅父在去世之时终于迸发了他的悲伤，他的亡故使她的生活更加悲痛，因为她现在也感受到舅父看着家中的政治和宗教气氛变化时所承受的痛苦。不幸的事往往有如晴天霹雳突然袭来，就像格朗松太太遭受的不幸那样；但是不幸发生在老姑娘身上，却像一滴油慢慢渗入衣料那样缓慢而持久。
en: Misjudged by society, which began by blaming her, the pious woman found ample opportunity in her home to display her virtues.She lived in tears, but she never ceased to present to others a placid face.To so Christian a soul a certain thought which pecked forever at her heart was a crime: “I loved the Chevalier de Valois,” it said; “but I have married du Bousquier.”The love of poor Athanase Granson also rose like a phantom of remorse, and pursued her even in her dreams.The death of her uncle, whose griefs at the last burst forth, made her life still more sorrowful; for she now felt the suffering her uncle must have endured in witnessing the change of political and religious opinion in the old house.Sorrow often falls like a thunderbolt, as it did on Madame Granson; but in this old maid it slowly spread like a drop of oil, which never leaves the stuff that slowly imbibes it.

zh: 正是德瓦卢瓦骑士这狡猾的操纵者铸成了迪布斯基耶夫人的莫大不幸。骑士一心要让老姑娘破除对宗教的幻想，他这位恋爱专家，对于不管是结了婚的还是之前单身的迪布斯基耶的心思，都看透了。但这非常警惕的共和党人很不好对付。他们刚结婚时，有些人与科尔蒙家不再往来。对于这些人，迪布斯基耶的沙龙自然关上了门，同样也不再对德瓦卢瓦骑士开放。而且这个人完全不怕成为笑柄。他有巨额财富，他领导着阿郎松，他对自己的老婆毫不关切，就像理查三世对待助他夺得战役胜利后死去的战马一样。为了讨丈夫欢心，迪布斯基耶夫人早已和德埃斯格里尼翁家断绝了关系，再也不去拜访了。偶尔当她丈夫留她一人在家到巴黎小住的时候，她会去短暂地拜访阿芒德小姐。
en: The Chevalier de Valois was the malicious manipulator who brought about the crowning misfortune of Madame du Bousquier’s life.His heart was set on undeceiving her pious simplicity; for the chevalier, expert in love, divined du Bousquier, the married man, as he had divined du Bousquier, the bachelor.But the wary republican was difficult of attack.His salon was, of course, closed to the Chevalier de Valois, as to all those who, in the early days of his marriage, had slighted the Cormon mansion.He was, moreover, impervious to ridicule; he possessed a vast fortune; he reigned in Alencon; he cared as little for his wife as Richard III. cared for the dead horse which had helped him win a battle.To please her husband, Madame du Bousquier had broken off relations with the d’Esgrignon household, where she went no longer, except that sometimes when her husband left her during his trips to Paris, she would pay a brief visit to Mademoiselle Armande.

zh: 在她婚后三年、德斯蓬德神父去世的时候，她们在圣莱奥纳尔教堂参加为神父做的追悼弥撒。走出教堂时，阿芒德小姐走到迪布斯基耶夫人身边。善良的阿芒德小姐认为，她应该在这种情况下去安慰下这位悲痛的外甥女。他们一边走着，一边谈着亲爱的故人，一直走到迪布斯基耶夫人禁止入内的公馆。他们正谈在兴头上，于是阿芒德小姐就把迪布斯基耶夫人拉进公馆。这可怜而孤独凄凉的女人是多么高兴能和她舅父所喜欢的人一起谈论她的舅父呀。并且，她也想问候下老侯爵，她已经将近三年没有见过老侯爵了。当时是中午一点半，她在埃斯格里尼翁公馆见到了来吃晚饭的德瓦卢瓦骑士。骑士握着她的双手向她鞠躬问好。
en: About three years after her marriage, at the time of the Abbe de Sponde’s death, Mademoiselle Armande joined Madame du Bousquier as they were leaving Saint-Leonard’s, where they had gone to hear a requiem said for him.The generous demoiselle thought that on this occasion she owed her sympathy to the niece in trouble.They walked together, talking of the dear deceased, until they reached the forbidden house, into which Mademoiselle Armande enticed Madame du Bousquier by the charm of her manner and conversation.The poor desolate woman was glad to talk of her uncle with one whom he truly loved.Moreover, she wanted to receive the condolences of the old marquis, whom she had not seen for nearly three years.It was half-past one o’clock, and she found at the hotel d’Esgrignon the Chevalier de Valois, who had come to dinner.As he bowed to her, he took her by the hands.

zh: “啊，亲爱的德高望重的夫人，”他语气激动地对她说道,“我们失去了我们圣洁的朋友，我们分担了您的哀痛。是的，人们在这里也和您家里一样，深切地感受到您的损失，甚至更感悲痛.”他补上一句，暗指迪布斯基耶。
en: “Well, dear, virtuous, and beloved lady,” he said, in a tone of emotion, “we have lost our sainted friend; we share your grief.Yes, your loss is as keenly felt here as in your own home,—more so,” he added, alluding to du Bousquier.

zh: 在场的每个人都说了几句表示哀悼安慰的话。之后，骑士十分殷勤地拉过迪布斯基耶夫人的手臂，挎在自己的胳膊上，非常疼爱地按着她的手臂，将她带到一扇窗户前。
en: After a few more words of funeral oration, in which all present spoke from the heart, the chevalier took Madame du Bousquier’s arm, and, gallantly placing it within his own, pressed it adoringly as he led her to the recess of a window.

zh: “你过得幸福吗？”他以慈父般的语气说道。
en: “Are you happy?” he said in a fatherly voice.

zh: “是的。”她眼帘低垂着说道。
en: “Yes,” she said, dropping her eyes.

zh: 赛布洛夫公主的女儿、德特雷维尔夫人和年迈的德卡泰朗侯爵夫人和阿尔芒德小姐一起走到骑士这边，她们正好听到了这句“是的”。他们在晚饭开始前都到花园去散步。迪布斯基耶夫人完全没有发现有一个小阴谋正在进行。
en: Hearing that “Yes,” Madame de Troisville, the daughter of the Princess Scherbellof, and the old Marquise de Casteran came up and joined the chevalier, together with Mademoiselle Armande.They all went to walk in the garden until dinner was served, without any perception on the part of Madame du Bousquier that a little conspiracy was afoot.

zh: “我们现在逮到她了，让我们来弄清真相吧。”所有在场之人的眼神中写着这样一句话。
en: “We have her! Now let us find out the secret of the case,” were the words written in the eyes of all present.

zh: “如果你要十全十美的幸福，”阿尔芒德小姐说道，“你必须要生个孩子，一个像我那可爱的侄子那样的男孩——”
en: “To make your happiness complete,” said Mademoiselle Armande, “you ought to have children,—a fine lad like my nephew—”

zh: 迪布斯基耶夫人的眼中开始泛着泪光。
en: Tears seemed to start in Madame du Bousquier’s eyes.

zh: “我听说这都是您一个人的过错，听说您害怕会怀孕？”骑士说道。
en: “I have heard it said that you were the one to blame in the matter, and that you feared the dangers of a pregnancy,” said the chevalier.

zh: “我？”她毫无遮掩地说道，“如果可以的话，哪怕是要用下一百年炼狱作为代价来换一个孩子，我也愿意！”
en: “I!” she said artlessly.“I would buy a child with a hundred years of purgatory if I could.”

zh: 这个问题引发了一场争论，在德特雷维尔子爵夫人和年迈的德卡泰朗侯爵夫人引导下，争论进行得非常巧妙，以至于老姑娘不知不觉便将她家的秘密泄露了出来。阿芒德小姐挎着骑士的胳膊走开了，好让这三位妇女自由谈论婚姻生活。迪布斯基耶夫人那时已经从自己婚姻的种种骗局中醒悟过来了，但她还是那样愚昧，说了很多天真幼稚的话，让那几位听众觉得特别有滋有味。
en: On the question thus started a discussion arose, conducted by Madame de Troisville and the old Marquise de Casteran with such delicacy and adroitness that the poor victim revealed, without being aware of it, the secrets of her house.Mademoiselle Armande had taken the chevalier’s arm, and walked away so as to leave the three women free to discuss wedlock.Madame du Bousquier was then enlightened on the various deceptions of her marriage; and as she was still the same simpleton she had always been, she amused her advisers by delightful naivetes.

zh: 尽管最初科尔蒙小姐捏造的婚事让全城的人都觉得可笑，但是之后大家又听到迪布斯基耶采取的伎俩，就对迪布斯基耶夫人给予了所有女人应有的尊敬和同情。科尔蒙小姐迫切想嫁人却嫁不出去的那段时间，人们都嘲笑她，但是当他们了解到她严格的宗教原则使她处于如此不同寻常的境地时，大家又都很敬佩她。“那个可怜的迪布斯基耶夫人”的称呼取代了“那位好心的科尔蒙小姐”的称呼。
en: Although at first the deceptive marriage of Mademoiselle Cormon made a laugh throughout the town, which was soon initiated into the story of the case, before long Madame du Bousquier won the esteem and sympathy of all the women.The fact that Mademoiselle Cormon had flung herself headlong into marriage without succeeding in being married, made everybody laugh at her; but when they learned the exceptional position in which the sternness of her religious principles placed her, all the world admired her.“That poor Madame du Bousquier” took the place of “That good Mademoiselle Cormon.”

zh: 因此，有一段时间，骑士把迪布斯基耶搞得那样滑稽可笑，令人讨厌。但是，当所有坏话都说尽了的时候，那些流言蜚语也就慢慢消失了，所有滑稽的事也逐渐不那么可笑了。后来，在许多人看来，那位不声不响的共和党人到了五十七岁的时候似乎要隐退了。这种情况让迪布斯基耶加深了对德埃斯格里尼翁家的仇恨，以至于在报仇之日来临时，迪布斯基耶是那么冷酷无情（参看《古董艺术馆》）。迪布斯基耶夫人得到命令，永远都不许再踏进那家的门槛。为了报复德瓦卢瓦骑士过去整他的种种，迪布斯基耶刚刚创立《奥恩通讯》时，便在该刊物上加了这么一个小通告：
en: Thus the chevalier contrived to render du Bousquier both ridiculous and odious for a time; but ridicule ends by weakening; when all had said their say about him, the gossip died out.Besides, at fifty-seven years of age the dumb republican seemed to many people to have a right to retire.This affair, however, envenomed the hatred which du Bousquier already bore to the house of Esgrignon to such a degree that it made him pitiless when the day of vengeance came.(See “The Gallery of Antiquities.”）Madame du Bousquier received orders never again to set foot into that house.By way of reprisals upon the chevalier for the trick thus played him, du Bousquier, who had just created the journal called the “Courrier de l’Orne,” caused the following notice to be inserted in it:—

zh: “兹有德蓬布勒通先生，如能揭示其流亡国外之前、流亡期间或是流亡之后的生活，将获得一年一千法郎的固定收入。”
en: “Bonds to the amount of one thousand francs a year will be paid to any person who can prove the existence of one Monsieur de Pombreton before, during, or after the Emigration.”

zh: 尽管迪布斯基耶夫人的婚姻基本上是失败的，但是她也从中看到了一些好处：能对城市里最出类拔萃的男人表示关切，总好过自己一个人孤孤单单地过日子吧？迪布斯基耶总比那些老姑娘所喜欢的猫啊、狗啊、金丝雀什么的强吧。比起女佣、听忏悔的神师和窥视其遗产的人，迪布斯基耶对妻子的感情要更加真实一些，也没有那么的自私。此后，老姑娘把丈夫当成是神发怒的工具，因为她意识到了自己因对婚姻的欲望而犯下了无数的罪过。她认为这是在惩罚她，因为是她导致了格朗松太太的不幸和自己舅父的早逝。宗教里的信条是要人去亲吻用来惩罚你的笞杖，她信奉这个信条。因而她在公开场合赞美她的丈夫，支持他的观点。但是在忏悔室或是晚上，她常常痛哭流涕地祷告，祈求上帝饶恕她丈夫的背教行为。她丈夫总是口是心非，希望看到贵族和教会的灭亡，而这两件事正是科尔蒙家的信仰。
en: Although her marriage was essentially negative, Madame du Bousquier saw some advantages in it: was it not better to interest herself in the most remarkable man in the town than to live alone?Du Bousquier was preferable to a dog, or cat, or those canaries that spinsters love.He showed for his wife a sentiment more real and less selfish than that which is felt by servants, confessors, and hopeful heirs.Later in life she came to consider her husband as the instrument of divine wrath; for she then saw innumerable sins in her former desires for marriage; she regarded herself as justly punished for the sorrow she had brought on Madame Granson, and for the hastened death of her uncle.Obedient to that religion which commands us to kiss the rod with which the punishment is inflicted, she praised her husband, and publicly approved him.But in the confessional, or at night, when praying, she wept often, imploring God’s forgiveness for the apostasy of the man who thought the contrary of what he professed, and who desired the destruction of the aristocracy and the Church,—the two religions of the house of Cormon.

zh: 在她的内心，她的全部感情都受到了践踏和殉葬，但是她的义务又迫使她去造就她丈夫的幸福，要用一种难以形容的爱去依恋他，久而久之就成了一种习惯，于是她的生活就成了永无休止、不合逻辑的矛盾混合物。她嫁了一个行为和见解都令她憎恨的人，但是她又要按照宗教义务规定的柔情去照顾他。当迪布斯基耶吃她做的果酱的时候或是觉得晚餐可口的时候，她总是欣喜若狂。她时刻留意要满足他每一个最细小的愿望。如果他将邮寄报纸的封套撕开后留在桌上了，女主人往往不会将它扔掉，她会说：
en: With all her feelings bruised and immolated within her, compelled by duty to make her husband happy, attached to him by a certain indefinable affection, born, perhaps, of habit, her life became one perpetual contradiction.She had married a man whose conduct and opinions she hated, but whom she was bound to care for with dutiful tenderness.Often she walked with the angels when du Bousquier ate her preserves or thought the dinner good.She watched to see that his slightest wish was satisfied.If he tore off the cover of his newspaper and left it on a table, instead of throwing it away, she would say:—

zh: “勒内，留在那儿吧。先生不会是无意放在那里的。”
en: “Rene, leave that where it is; monsieur did not place it there without intention.”

zh: 如果迪布斯基耶要出门旅行了，她会为他的衣箱衣物而忙里忙外；她为他的物质生活提供最细心周到的照料。如果他要去普雷博戴，她会头一天晚上就看气压表，好了解第二天的天气怎么样。她从他的眼神里窥伺他的意愿，就像一条狗在睡觉的同时，也能听见和看见主人有什么要求。当肥胖的迪布斯基耶为这种恪守宗教信条的爱情所感动时，他便搂住她的腰，亲吻着她的额头，对她说：“你真是一个好妻子！” 这时候，这个可怜的女人便感动地眼里涌上快乐的泪水。迪布斯基耶很可能也自认为有义务要补偿罗丝－玛丽－维克图瓦的一些损失，因而赢得了她的尊重。天主教的美德并不要求迪布斯基耶夫人如此彻底地掩饰自己。这位圣洁的女子经常沉默地坐在一旁，听着那些披着君主立宪保皇党的伪装的人抒发他们的仇恨。每当她预见到教堂要垮台的时候，就会浑身战栗。偶尔她壮胆说上一句愚蠢的话，提出一个观点，而迪布斯基耶瞪她一眼，她就将下半截话咽下去了。
en: If du Bousquier had a journey to take, she was anxious about his trunk, his linen; she took the most minute precautions for his material benefit.If he went to Prebaudet, she consulted the barometer the evening before to know if the weather would be fine.She watched for his will in his eyes, like a dog which hears and sees its master while sleeping.When the stout du Bousquier, touched by this scrupulous love, would take her round the waist and kiss her forehead, saying, “What a good woman you are!” tears of pleasure would come into the eyes of the poor creature.It is probably that du Bousquier felt himself obliged to make certain concessions which obtained for him the respect of Rose-Marie-Victoire; for Catholic virtue does not require a dissimulation as complete as that of Madame du Bousquier.Often the good saint sat mutely by and listened to the hatred of men who concealed themselves under the cloak of constitutional royalists.She shuddered as she foresaw the ruin of the Church.Occasionally she risked a stupid word, an observation which du Bousquier cut short with a glance.

zh: 如此左右为难的痛苦生活终于让迪布斯基耶夫人变得痴痴傻傻了。她觉得如果只将她的思考集中在内心，甘心过着纯粹动物一样的生活，她会生活得更加简单而有尊严。因此她表现出奴隶般的顺从，并且当她的丈夫将她置于屈从的地位时，她也将其认为是一件值得称赞的行为。执行丈夫的旨意从未引起她的半句怨言。牧羊人一指出道路，这只胆小的羔羊便立刻走上去。她接受各种最严格的天主教徒的修行，她再也没有想过撒旦以及他创造的一切世俗浮华和虚荣。因此，她展现给世人的是集基督徒所有美德于一身的形象，而迪布斯基耶自然成了法兰西和纳瓦尔王国中最幸福的男人之一了。
en: The worries of such an existence ended by stupefying Madame du Bousquier, who found it easier and also more dignified to concentrate her intelligence on her own thoughts and resign herself to lead a life that was purely animal.She then adopted the submission of a slave, and regarded it as a meritorious deed to accept the degradation in which her husband placed her.The fulfilment of his will never once caused her to murmur.The timid sheep went henceforth in the way the shepherd led her; she gave herself up to the severest religious practices, and thought no more of Satan and his works and vanities.Thus she presented to the eyes of the world a union of all Christian virtues; and du Bousquier was certainly one of the luckiest men in the kingdom of France and of Navarre.

zh: “她要傻到咽下最后一口气了。”前抵押品总保管说道。他虽然已被撤职，但每周还是在她家吃两次饭。
en: “She will be a simpleton to her last breath,” said the former collector, who, however, dined with her twice a week.

zh: 如果不交代一下德瓦卢瓦骑士和苏珊的母亲在同一天去世的事，这个故事就太不完整了。骑士于一八三零年八月和君主政体一同死亡。他到诺南库尔去和国王查理十世一行人会合，他和特雷维尔家族、卡泰朗家族和韦纳伊等家族一同虔诚地将国王护送到瑟堡。这位年迈的贵族当时带着他的全部积蓄五万法郎。他将这笔钱交给国王的一位忠实朋友，请他将这笔钱转交给国王，说他已经行将就木，不需要这笔钱了，还说这钱本来也是来自国王陛下的恩赐，并且瓦卢瓦家族最后一员的财产是属于王权的。他这份狂热是否战胜了波旁国王的不情不愿，人们就无从得知了。不过，这位波旁国王放弃了他美丽的法兰西王国，一个子儿也没有带，但是骑士的忠心应该感动了国王。然而，骑士的遗赠财产承受人赛查丽娜确实每年只得到六百法郎的固定收入。骑士由于悲痛和疲惫而变得极其虚弱不堪，回到阿郎松后便卧床不起。在查理十世踏上外国领土的那一天，骑士就断气了。
en: This history would be strangely incomplete if no mention were made of the coincidence of the Chevalier de Valois’s death occurring at the same time as that of Suzanne’s mother.The chevalier died with the monarchy, in August, 1830.He had joined the cortege of Charles X. at Nonancourt, and piously escorted it to Cherbourg with the Troisvilles, Casterans, d’Esgrignons, Verneuils, etc.The old gentleman had taken with him fifty thousand francs,—the sum to which his savings then amounted.He offered them to one of the faithful friends of the king for transmission to his master, speaking of his approaching death, and declaring that the money came originally from the goodness of the king, and, moreover, that the property of the last of the Valois belonged of right to the crown.It is not known whether the fervor of his zeal conquered the reluctance of the Bourbon, who abandoned his fine kingdom of France without carrying away with him a farthing, and who ought to have been touched by the devotion of the chevalier.It is certain, however, that Cesarine, the residuary legate of the old man, received from his estate only six hundred francs a year.The chevalier returned to Alencon, cruelly weakened by grief and by fatigue; he died on the very day when Charles X arrived on a foreign shore.

zh: 瓦诺布勒夫人和她的保护人当时正害怕会受到自由党的报复。正好苏珊母亲在农村病故，他们俩便高兴地以此为借口，隐姓埋名地去了那个村庄。同时，德瓦卢瓦骑士的遗物正在转卖中，苏珊很想得到她第一个好友也是最后一个好友的一件纪念品，于是骑士那个有名的鼻烟盒的价钱被哄抬起来了，最后她以一千法郎将鼻烟盒买到手。事实上，光是戈里扎公主的肖像就值这个价钱了。两年后，一位专门收集上一世纪精美鼻烟盒的纨绔子弟从瓦诺布勒夫人那儿得到了骑士的那件珍宝。现在这见证了许多爱情和晚年乐事的可爱密友，正陈列在某个私人博物馆里。如果死者能够知道他们死后发生的事，估计骑士连左半边脸都要红了。
en: Madame du Val-Noble and her protector, who was just then afraid of the vengeance of the liberal party, were glad of a pretext to remain incognito in the village where Suzanne’s mother died.At the sale of the chevalier’s effects, which took place at that time, Suzanne, anxious to obtain a souvenir of her first and last friend, pushed up the price of the famous snuff-box, which was finally knocked down to her for a thousand francs.The portrait of the Princess Goritza was alone worth that sum.Two years later, a young dandy, who was making a collection of the fine snuff-boxes of the last century, obtained from Madame du Val-Noble the chevalier’s treasure.The charming confidant of many a love and the pleasure of an old age is now on exhibition in a species of private museum.If the dead could know what happens after them, the chevalier’s head would surely blush upon its left cheek.

zh: 如果这个故事只是让拥有某些纪念品的人感到对神圣的敬畏，或是让他们采取行动纪念这些曾遗赠给他们幸福的纪念品，那这个故事倒也对骑士风度和爱情问题有很大的昭示作用，但是实际上，这个故事包含的寓意要深刻得多。难道这不表明人们需要接受新型的教育吗？难道这不是在启示公共教育部部长们设立人类学的讲坛吗？他们确实已经感到焦虑了。德国已经在这一门科学上走在我们的前面了。虽然我们已遭受各类神话的困扰，但是现在的神话比古代的神话还更让人难以理解。神话从各方面包围着我们，它们包含各种理论，它们解答所有问题。根据人类的看法，它们是历史的火炬；只要历史教师稍微给外省人们的头脑中灌输一些对于神话的解释，这些神话就能够将王国从各种革命中解救出来了。如果科尔蒙小姐能读书或上学，如果奥恩省里有一位人类学教授，或者科尔蒙小姐读过奥利奥斯托的著作，那她就不会遭受夫妻生活中骇人听闻的种种不幸了。她也许就能知道为什么意大利诗人会安排安杰丽卡更喜欢梅多罗，而不是奥兰多。梅多罗就相当于金发的德瓦卢瓦骑士，而奥兰多对于死去的马却只知道发疯。梅多罗不正是各种女性王国中殷勤臣子的神话形象吗？而奥兰多，不正是混乱、愤怒、破坏一切却无法生产的无力革命的神话象征吗？此为巴郎什先生的一个门徒的见解，我们发表了他的见解，不过不会对此负任何责任。
en: If this history has no other effect than to inspire the possessors of precious relics with holy fear, and induce them to make codicils to secure these touching souvenirs of joys that are no more by bequeathing them to loving hands, it will have done an immense service to the chivalrous and romantic portion of the community; but it does, in truth, contain a far higher moral.Does it not show the necessity for a new species of education?Does it not invoke, from the enlightened solicitude of the ministers of Public Instruction, the creation of chairs of anthropology,—a science in which Germany outstrips us?Modern myths are even less understood than ancient ones, harried as we are with myths.Myths are pressing us from every point; they serve all theories, they explain all questions.They are, according to human ideas, the torches of history; they would save empires from revolution if only the professors of history would force the explanations they give into the mind of the provincial masses.If Mademoiselle Cormon had been a reader or a student, and if there had existed in the department of the Orne a professor of anthropology, or even had she read Ariosto, the frightful disasters of her conjugal life would never have occurred.She would probably have known why the Italian poet makes Angelica prefer Medoro, who was a blond Chevalier de Valois, to Orlando, whose mare was dead, and who knew no better than to fly into a passion.Is not Medoro the mythic form for all courtiers of feminine royalty, and Orlando the myth of disorderly, furious, and impotent revolutions, which destroy but cannot produce?We publish, but without assuming any responsibility for it, this opinion of a pupil of Monsieur Ballanche.

zh: 关于那雕刻成黑人头形状的钻石耳环的去向，我们则一无所知。至于瓦诺布勒夫人，也许您晚上能在歌剧院里见到她。多亏德瓦卢瓦骑士给予她的启蒙教育，现在她几乎具备了受过良好教养的女人的气质。
en: No information has reached us as to the fate of the negroes’ heads in diamonds.You may see Madame du Val-Noble every evening at the Opera.Thanks to the education given her by the Chevalier de Valois, she has almost the air of a well-bred woman.

zh: 迪布斯基耶夫人还在世，这岂不是说她还在受苦吗？女人们上了六十岁的年纪，就可以向别人坦白一切了。迪布斯基耶夫人六十岁之后，对迪库徳赖夫人吐露心声说，她从来都不能接受自己要做一辈子老姑娘的想法。
en: Madame du Bousquier still lives; is not that as much as to say she still suffers?After reaching the age of sixty—the period at which women allow themselves to make confessions—she said confidentially to Madame du Coudrai, that she had never been able to endure the idea of dying an old maid.
